pages.title: Convergent Billing Overview
pages.text: Convergent Billing is designed for new generation customer care and billing environments to increase competitive advantage by making it easier to design, deliver, and bill products and services required by customers.    Billing environments are rapidly changing to support complex products and product packaging, consolidated billing (single bill), rapid tariff definition, integrated customer care systems, and billing support for targeted services.  Sophisticated billing is a key factor in customer retention and acquisition of new customers.  Convergent Billing provides modules for balance management, billing mediation, rating, discounting, and bill production.  Convergent Billing is based on industry standard architecture, relational database technology, and interfaces, to ensure portability across operating platforms.

pages.title: The Convergent Billing Solution
pages.text: Convergent Billing offers a competitive advantage by making it easier to design, deliver, and bill the products and services required by customers.  The core technology is the high performance, highly flexible rating and discounting engine, used for construction of arbitrary tariff and discount rules based on customer data, and call and other events.  Convergent Billing offers unrivalled support for:  Flexible tariffing, discount, and product packaging that allow tailoring of solutions to customers' requirements.  Rapid configuration of new products and tariffs.  Consolidated (single) billing so that customers view their total costs at a glance.  Real-time customer balance management (only available as part of the separate Singleview Commerce Engine licence option).  Online access to customer account, product, and tariff information for instant response to customer enquiries.  Financial reporting including accounts receivable sub-ledger, Sales and Cash Receipts Journal, and automated upload to external general ledger systems.  Comprehensive security features for controlling access to information and use of Convergent Billing, including extended authentication with password expiry, password reuse, account locking and the use of third party authentication systems.  High availability of the Commerce Engine and Online Transaction Processing (OLTP), such as user transactions.  Multi-server billing and OLTP scalability.  Continuous availability of the Commerce Engine.  Tracking and monitoring Convergent Billing system components.  Convergent Billing provides the features and facilities required to change the concept of billing and customer service from a costly, labour-intensive, and repetitive function to a streamlined, automated business process suitable for all service providers.

pages.title: Key Features of Convergent Billing
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides the following key features:  Product management  Customer care  Real-time account management  Convergent Billing customisation  Billing  Financial support  System administration  High availability of the Commerce Engine and Online Transaction Processing (OLTP)  Continuous availability of the Commerce Engine  Multi-server billing and OLTP scalability  Scalability suitable for all service providers, including Tier 1 providers.  Interfaces to external systems  Integration with Process Engine  Internationalisation support  Reporting  Tracking and monitoring.

pages.title: Reference Information
pages.text: This section contains reference information about Convergent Billing entities and concepts.

pages.title: Account Types
pages.text: Account types are associated with payment types, adjustment types, customer types, and charge categories used in a product’s tariff definition; all these elements, when used for the same customer, must reference the same account type.  Account types are used in the definition of charge categories, payment types, adjustment types, and customer types to specify the type of account to which charges are applied.  The following table lists account type examples.  Account Type  Description  Creditors  Creditor account, for accounts payable; used for suppliers and vendors owed money as accounts payable by a business entity.  Debtors  Debtor account, for accounts receivable; used for customers who owe money to the business entity.  Deposit  Deposit account, used for customers who have deposited money with the business.  Before an account type can be defined, the appropriate currency must be defined.  An account type can also have aging classification criteria defined.  The aging classifications determine how the groups of transactions are classified.  Expressions are used to calculate the total amount for each classification.  Aging details are displayed in the Account History form.

pages.title: Accounting Calendars, Years, and Periods
pages.text: Multiple accounting calendars can be defined in Singleview.  An accounting calendar groups one or more accounting years.   In a Singleview implementation that requires multiple overlapping accounting years or periods. The overlapping years or periods must belong to different accounting calendars. That is, no accounting year or period belonging to the same accounting calendar can overlap.  A reporting entity references an accounting calendar to determine the accounting period to use for financial reporting.  An accounting period is a period of time for which a set of financial statements is generated.  Within an accounting year, the length of the accounting period is arbitrary and fixed, based on the reporting requirements of the company (for example, day, week, month, quarter, or year).  Accounting years and accounting periods in Convergent Billing must reflect the financial years and accounting periods of the service provider; however, this restriction is not enforced by Convergent Billing.  Accounting years in Convergent Billing are normally broken down into smaller accounting periods.  Start and end dates for accounting years and periods are flexible; therefore, Convergent Billing supports any type of accounting period.  Examples are:  Calendar months  Calendar quarters  Twelve periods following a 4-4-5 week profile, ending on any day of the week (that is, a four week period, followed by a four week period, followed by a five week period).   Thirteen periods of four weeks.   Accounting periods are used by Convergent Billing during the:  Rating process, to group the effects of rating charges on GL codes.  GL upload process, to report the accounting period in which a set of uploaded transactions were posted to the Sales Journal.  Accounting years and periods support date and date-time granularity.  Although accounting years and periods have a duration, neither entity has history records (that is, date ranging is not supported and modifications are made directly on the entity).  Accounting years and periods have a status of Open or Closed.  After a period is closed, journal entries cannot be added to the period; the journal entries are reflected in the current period.  An accounting year is automatically closed if all of its accounting periods are closed.  More than one accounting period can be open at any one time, in which case a journal entry is posted to the period to which it logically belongs.

pages.title: Accounts
pages.text: Each customer must have one primary account, the invoice account, which is the account to which invoiced amounts, payments, and adjustments are posted.  The primary account is automatically created when a customer is created.  Additional accounts, referred to as secondary accounts, can also be assigned to customers, depending on their requirements.  Secondary accounts are set up by clicking the Other Accounts... button on the Customer Detail form.  Examples of secondary accounts include:   Deposit accounts, for recording customer deposits.  Loyalty accounts, for recording loyalty or frequent user points.  Each account has an account type that defines the different types of accounts to which charges are applied. The account type defines whether the account is an asset or a liability, its currency, and aging criteria.  The account type of the primary account is determined by the Prime Account Type field on the Customer Type Definition form.  Account numbers are assigned automatically by Convergent Billing if an account number is not specified when a customer’s details are first recorded.  The format of the automatically assigned account number (for primary accounts) is predefined in the selected customer type.  The format of the automatically assigned account number (for secondary accounts) is predefined in the selected account type.  Customer accounts can be viewed using the Customer Detail form.

pages.title: Address Formats
pages.text: An address format definition is used to define the style of address displayed on the customer care forms.  One of the following styles of address can be chosen for an address format definition:  5 lines, which include the following fields: Line 1, Line 2, City, Province, Country, and Postcode.  6 lines, which include the following fields: Line 1, Line 2, Suburb, City, State, Country, and Postcode.  Choosing an address validation can customise the fields included in the style selected.  When customising any of the address fields, the appropriate entity validation definition must be defined before the address format is defined.

pages.title: Adjustment Batches
pages.text: Entering adjustments in batches is simply an alternative method of entering and processing adjustments of the same adjustment type.  Once created, individual adjustments can be added to and removed from the adjustment batch.  Each adjustment that is added to the adjustment batch is assigned an adjustment number when that adjustment is saved.  The adjustment batch is assigned an adjustment batch number when the first adjustment within the adjustment batch is saved.  While the adjustment batch is being created, the batch status is set to ‘Entered’.  Adjustments within an adjustment batch are posted to the relevant customer accounts only when the adjustment batch is applied.  Once an adjustment batch is applied, the batch status is set to ‘Applied’.  Details of individual adjustments within a batch can now be viewed.  Individual adjustments within an adjustment batch can be modified either before or after applying the batch.  If errors are discovered in an adjustment when that adjustment is posted (for example, the adjustment was posted to the wrong account), the adjustment batch can be un-applied (restrictions apply).  Un-applying an adjustment batch results in all adjustments included in the batch being un-posted.  Individual adjustments can then be modified and the adjustment batch re-applied.  Facilities are provided to:  An adjustment batch can only be un-applied if an adjustment within that batch was not:  Included on (appeared on) an invoice or statement.  Posted to the Sales Journal.  Change the allocation of the adjustment to an invoice.  Reverse the adjustment.  Delete the adjustment.

pages.title: Adjustment Types
pages.text: An adjustment type is used to define common parameters for adjustment records.  Adjustment type examples are listed in the following table.  Adjustment Type  Description   Cancellation Charges  Apply cancellation charges.  Call Disconnected  Adjustment for a charge for a disconnected call.  Calls not recognised  Adjustment for calls listed on the invoice but not recognised by the customer.  The adjustment type relies on a number of items being defined and available in the system; these include the appropriate currency, general ledger codes, and account types.  If customising any of the fields on the Individual Adjustment Detail form for a specific adjustment type, the appropriate entity validation definition, attribute types, reference types, and context-sensitive help must be defined before the adjustment type.  For more information about adjustment types, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Field Customisation
pages.text: Attribute types can be used to:  Customise the name of a generic Convergent Billing field without changing its original functionality.  Define a field with a drop-down list of options.  Creating a drop-down list uses a reference type containing the required item list.  Define a data entry field based on a specific data type.  Specify the name and the width of the field.  Specify the alignment of the data in the field.  Define the format in which entered data is displayed.  Define the format of the field while it is being edited.  For example, if the display format specifies that commas are displayed as part of numeric values in the thousands, the edit format could specify that the commas are not displayed while the field is being edited.  Specify an edit mask (characters used as part of the field format).  Define the hint text (maximum 255 characters) that is displayed in a pop-up box when the cursor is placed over the associated data entry field.  Select an appropriate help entry help definition to display a pop-up help window when the cursor is positioned in the field and F1 is pressed.  Define a default for the field.  Specify whether a field is mandatory or optional.  Specify whether the values defined in a reference type or SQL query is denormalised.  Specify that the user can also enter data manually even if the field has a drop-down list.  Configure the field to be visible, enabled, or able to be updated.  Specify the case in which the entered data is displayed.  Specify the maximum number of characters that can be entered.  Specify the minimum and maximum amounts that can be entered if the field is configured for the entry of numbers.  Define a list of conditional expressions to be used to validate the data entered in the field.  Set up field security to determine whether a field is visible, enabled, or able to be updated for users with specific security privileges.

pages.title: Adjustments
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, any transaction outside of the normal billing cycle transactions (namely, invoices and payments) that affects the outstanding balance of an account, is referred to as an adjustment.  For example, an adjustment may be required to refund a client for a service not disconnected at the correct time.  An adjustment can be allocated (either fully or partially) to a specific invoice, split and allocated to multiple invoices, or simply credited (or debited) to a customer’s account.  Adjustments can be classified into a number of different adjustment types.  For example, they can be classified as adjustments relating to billing errors, service calls, or goodwill credits.  To ensure that limits are imposed on the amounts and currencies in which adjustments can be entered, each user is given a predefined adjustment limit.  The predefined limit determines the maximum amount of any adjustment entered by that user.  A user is further restricted in that they are only permitted to enter adjustments in a single, predefined currency.  Adjustments can be entered in either of the following ways:  Individually  In batches of the same adjustment type.  See Adjustment Batches.  The system assigns an adjustment number to every recorded adjustment irrespective of whether that adjustment was entered as an individual adjustment or entered as part of an adjustment batch.  In addition, each adjustment batch is assigned an adjustment batch number by which it can be referenced.  Set of individual adjustments of the same type processed at the same time.  Each adjustment within the batch can be viewed or modified until the batch is applied (processed).  An adjustment batch can be created incrementally (one or more adjustments at a time) over a period of time.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Adjustment.  The adjustment type determines the format of each adjustment number and adjustment batch number.  The format for an adjustment number usually includes a unique prefix so that, when viewing a customer’s account details, adjustments of a specific type can be more readily identified in the list of transactions.  If errors are discovered in an adjustment when that adjustment is posted for example, the adjustment was incorrectly allocated), facilities are provided to:  Change the allocation of the adjustment to an invoice.  Reverse the adjustment.  Delete the adjustment.  Facilities are provided in the system to search for and view specific adjustments and specific adjustment batches.

pages.title: Anonymous Arrays
pages.text: Anonymous arrays are arrays without a name.  The syntax of anonymous arrays is defined as follows:  [ <expression>, <expression>, ... ]  The type of the expressions the array contains (providing the expressions are all the same type) defines the type of an anonymous array.  If the expressions are not of the same type, the type of anonymous array is Unknown.  An empty anonymous Array can be of any type required (as the type is dependent on where it is used).  An anonymous array can itself contain anonymous arrays, or expressions returning hashes.  If all elements in an anonymous Array are constants, the array is constructed at parse time (rather than runtime) for improved performance.  For example:  var FieldNames$[];  FieldNames$[] := ['SERVICE_ID', 'SERVICE_NAME',                    'GENERAL_1', 'GENERAL_2'];  Anonymous arrays support the concept of array slices in Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Archiving
pages.text: The terms 'archiving' and 'un-archiving' imply the exporting or importing of data relating to specific database entities, taken from one or more tables in the database.  For example, the entity customer contains information about the individual customer, the customer hierarchy, the people nominated as contacts, the accounts involved, invoice details, and much more.    An entity is made up of the base level data (for example, customer details) plus all dependent data, wherever it is stored in the database.  Archiving is not synonymous with backup and restore, which are generally carried out on one or more complete tables (if not the entire database), and are used to provide a means of recovering from any damage the database may suffer as a result of hardware or software failure.    Archiving is more generally used to remove and archive database entities no longer required; for example, customers who have permanently closed their accounts, people who have moved away, or products no longer available.  As data of this kind is archived, it can also be automatically purged from the database.  Another common use for archiving is the transfer of entity data, spanning several tables, from one database to another.  For example, a subset of data from an operational database might be archived, then imported into a training database, to provide realistic dummy data for students to work on.  In this case, the original data would not be purged after archiving.  The archiving feature can be used to purge unwanted data from the database, such as dummy data entered by students in a training database when their training is complete and the data is no longer required.  Purging is done by using the archiving feature with no output file specified and the purge option turned on.  Data purged in this way is lost forever, so the technique should only be used on unwanted data.  The archiving feature is not designed to archive large volumes of configuration or operational data.  For example, the archiving feature should not be used to archive or remove a large set of subscribers from a production system.  Not only does archiving or purging large volumes of data take considerable time, but it is likely that system performance is significantly degraded during the archiving period.    In some systems, even archiving the operational data associated with a single customer may not be advisable.  For example, a customer with a high volume service (such as a government body) may have millions of entries in the normalised event table.  Charge and normalised event tables contain the highest volume of data in the system and the period to archive the customer node and its associated data may be lengthy.   Archiving can be carried out from the client workstation by scheduling a task, or from the UNIX command line.  All options available from the command line are also available through the scheduler.  In either case, the key parameter that the archiver needs is an Archive type, which specifies all the tables and dependencies that make up the entity being archived.  Archive types are provided with the base installation, and cannot be defined or changed by users.  Convergent Billing archiving uses either the Oracle imp and exp utilities, or sqlimport and sqlexport if the archive files are required in ASCII format.

pages.title: Arithmetic Operators
pages.text: Arithmetic Operators for Scalar Types  Operator  Integer  Real  String  Date  Blob  +, +=  Addition  Addition  Concatenation  Addition  Concatenation  ++  Increment  Increment  -, -=  Subtraction  Subtraction  Subtraction  --  Decrement  Decrement  *, *=  Multiplication  Multiplication  /, /=  Division  Division  %, %=  Modulus  Modulus  ^, ^=  Power  Power  ::=  Equivalence  Equivalence  Equivalence  Equivalence  Equivalence  The '++' and '--' operators work in the same way as in the C programming language.  That is, if placed before a variable, they increment or decrement the variable before returning the value, and if placed after the variable, increment or decrement the variable after returning the value.   Notes on the Equivalence Operator  The equivalence operator makes the local variable on the left-hand side of the operator equivalent to the expression on the right-hand side.  Subsequent accesses or assignments to the local variable are equivalent to accessing or assigning to the expression on the right-hand side.  The following restrictions apply to the reference operator:  The left-hand side must be a local variable.  The right-hand side must be an expression that returns a variable reference.  The data types of the left-hand and right-hand sides must match exactly.  An object referenced by an equivalence operator must never be undefined.  After undefining an array or hash containing an element that is referenced, using the reference to update the element's value gives an indeterminate result.  Arithmetic Operators for Composite Types  Operator  Array  Hash  +, +=  Concatenation  Join  It is important to be aware of the details of the 'join' operation carried out when hashes are aggregated using the + and += operators.  When two hashes are aggregated within a subtotal, the following algorithm applies:  If the hashes both contain a specific key, the values from the two hashes for the key are added to form the value for that key in the result hash.  If only one of the hashes contains a specific key, the value for the key in the original hash becomes the value for that key in the result hash.  When two hashes are aggregated within an expression, the following algorithm applies:  If the hashes both contain a specific key, the value from the second hash (the hash on the right side of the operator) becomes the value for that key in the result.  If only one of the hashes contains a specific key, the value for the key in the original hash becomes the value for that key in the result.

pages.title: Array Slices
pages.text: Array slices are supported in a named array.  For example:  <array name><scalar type>[<expr1> .. <expr2>]  An array slice returns an array of the elements in <array name> from the element identified by <expr1> to the element identified by <expr2> inclusive.  If the value of <expr1> is greater than the value of <expr2>, the order of the elements in the result array is reversed.  Array slices are not assignable, they cannot appear on the left-hand side of the assignment operator (:=), and cannot be passed by reference to a function.  If <array name> is of unknown type, providing that all elements in the slice are of the same type, an array slice can be successfully cast to a different type (the type checking is performed at runtime).

pages.title: Arrays
pages.text:
Arrays can be defined in Convergent Billing as local variables in expression blocks and functions, subject to the following conditions: Arrays are defined using the following syntax: [] The defines the data type of each element in the array. For example, var charges#[] defines an array of real data type. Array elements are referenced using the following syntax: [] The must evaluate to an integer. For example, charges# [1] := '5.25' assigns the value '5.25' to the second element of the array (the first element is charges# [0]). The following table lists examples of array usage. Example Description a$[10] Accesses the array element. a$[] Accesses the array as a whole. var b?[];b$[0][] := a$[]; Assigns an array to an array element. b$ [0][0] := 'expression'; Assigns an element in a two-dimensional array. var b?[];b$[0]{} := a${}; Assigns a hash to an array element. b$[0]{'First'} := 'FirstValue'; Assigns an element of a hash within an array. Array variables expand dynamically to accommodate new elements, limited only by available memory. Only arrays with the 'unknown' scalar type support nested arrays and hashes. Nested arrays and hashes are implicitly created as they are referenced. There is no limit to the depth at which arrays or hashes can be nested. An array cannot be declared with multiple dimensions. For example, the following is incorrect: var a?[ ][ ]; To create a multi-dimensional array, a single-dimensional array of unknown type must first be declared, and then the nested arrays (or hashes) are accessed as required. An array variable is uniquely identified by its name only, as opposed to scalar variables, which are uniquely identified by name and type. For example, the following is incorrect: var a&[ ], a$[ ]; The variable a has already been declared to be of type integer array, and cannot be declared to be of type string array in the same scope. Arrays, hashes, and scalar variables have their own namespaces. For example, var a&[ ],a${ }, a$, a&, a#, a~, is sound, but to avoid confusion it is not recommended. To access or assign a value as a specific type in an unknown array, use the appropriate data type suffix; for example: var a?[];
a$[0] := 'Sample String';
#Assign string value to first element of a?[] a$[0] is not equivalent to to_string(a?[0]). The expression a$[0] results in a runtime error if the value stored in the first element of the a?[] is not a string, whereas to_string(a?[0]) converts the value to a string (using default formats for integers, reals, and dates) if it is not already a string. In general, the value accessed must be of the type specified, or a runtime error occurs, although casting between integer and real values is permitted. However, accessing a real value as an integer changes the value stored in the element to an integer, and accessing a integer as a real value changes the value stored in the element to a real value; for example: var a?[];
a#[0] := 1.1;
if (a&[0] > 0) then # Implicit casting to Integer
print(a#[0]); # This prints 1, NOT 1.1 Data types in an anonymous array determine the data type of the array. If the data types are not all the same, the data type of the anonymous array is unknown.

pages.title: Attribute Types
pages.text: An attribute type controls the representation of an entity's attributes.   For users of Singleview Convergent Billing, an attribute type defines the format, characteristics, and validation rules for a form field.   For external systems, attribute types control representation of an entity's data model.  In this context, attribute types can define:   Fields that uniquely identify an entity instance  Labels that can be used to access fields of an entity  A field's value as a reference to another Convergent Billing entity  A non-stored attribute that is derived from an entity's stored fields.   Attribute types are defined independently of the data entry fields to which they relate, so the same attribute type to be used for multiple fields.  Attribute type configuration can be used to add security to a field using any of the following features:  Adding encryption  Adding data masking   Restricting view and update access for specific security groups  Enabling or disabling access for specific security groups.  In conjunction with reference types, attribute types allow generic Convergent Billing fields to be customised using entity validation.  Customising fields includes adding new fields.  The customer care forms include a General tab, which contains invisible general fields that can be customised to become visible.  To speed up data entry and reduce the scope and level of validation required, a reference type can be specified in an attribute type so the user can select one of a number of pre-defined values rather than having to determine, and then enter, an appropriate value in the correct format.  For more information on attribute types, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Derived Non-Stored Attributes
pages.text: Derived non-stored attributes are derived from an entity's stored attributes.  They can be added to an entity validation without a corresponding validation table column.  To external systems using the Entity Validation Server, derived non-stored attributes appear the same as stored attributes.  Derived non-stored attributes can tailor an entity's data model for integration with external systems.   Derived non-stored attributes are defined on the Integration tab of the Attribute Type Definition form.  The Derived? check box enables the details of the derivation to be configured.  [[TableXref:50079-1]] lists three types of derived non-stored attributes.  [[Table:50079-1]]  Types of Derived Non-stored Attributes  Type  Description  Specified on Input  The Specified on Input? check box is selected.  External systems can insert or update the attribute value, but are not able fetch it or generate a view that contains it.  How the supplied value is broken down into values for stored attributes is defined in the validation expressions of the entity's entity validation.  Specified on Output  The Specified on Output? check box is selected.  External systems can fetch the attribute value or generate a view that contains it, but are not able to insert or update it.  The derivation of the attribute value from stored attributes for a fetch is defined in the Output EPM Expression field.   The derivation of the value for a generated view is specified in the Output SQL Expression field.  Specified on Input and Output  The Specified on Input? and Specified on Output check boxes are selected.  External systems can fetch, insert, and update the attribute's value. They can also generate a view that contains the attribute's value.  Derivation of the output value is defined as per Specified on Output.  Breaking down the input value is defined as per Specified on Input.  Derived non-stored attributes can be referenced in EPM expressions using a direct variable.  The name of the direct variable is configured in the Variable Name field.

pages.title: Audit Records
pages.text: Audit records are used to track changes to selected tables in the database.  The Audit Search form is used to search the audit records of a specific table and restrict the records based on a specific user, an open or closed date and time range, or the additional criteria specified by a Where clause.  Reuse the last audit form rather than opening a new audit form every time a search is performed.  For information about enabling auditing of a table and viewing the audit records generated, refer to the System Administration Guide for Singleview.  Choosing a Table  The form provides a drop-down list of the tables that can be queried for audit records.  The list contains only tables configured for auditing.   Choosing an User  The search for audit records can be restricted to those created by a specific operator.  Database changes that have been made automatically by the system (for example, as part of the billing cycle), are assigned the user associated with the billing process.  Choosing an Open or Closed Date and Time Range  The search for audit records can be restricted to those created before or after a specific date and time or between.  If the time field is left blank, the selected time defaults to one second past midnight on the chosen day.  As an example, to restrict the date range to a single day, the start time could be left blank but an end time of 23:59:59 entered.  Using an SQL Where Clause  The search for audit records can be restricted to those matching additional criteria by entering an SQL Where clause.  The clause entered must be valid within the context of the table being examined and the syntax of SQL.  The clause must not contain the Where keyword.  It is necessary to be familiar with the database table structure and SQL to be able to use this feature of the search form.  Reuse Last Audit Form  More than one audit record can be open at the same time.  Enter new selection criteria in the Audit Search form and click the Audit button.  However, if the new selection should overwrite the previous selection, select the Reuse last audit form check box before clicking the Audit... button.

pages.title: Authentication
pages.text: Authentication is the process of identifying a user. In Singleview, users are authenticated using internal or external authentication.   A user can log in to Singleview using single sign-on if external authentication is configured.   Authentication services are managed by the Authentication server (authsvr).  Login details are hidden in all function calls (including external function calls), and debug, print and trace outputs.

pages.title: Automation Interface
pages.text: The automation interface provides a mechanism for server processes and client expressions to automate functions, and control entities and forms on the Convergent Billing client.  Available entities and forms are obtained at runtime using either the EPM Automation Interface, or the OLE Automation Interface.  The details on the forms are then manipulated using Form Automation Parameters.

pages.title: Balance Management
pages.text: Balance management is the process by which real-time account management is achieved.    The following balance management services are possible:  Real-time service authorisation  Event authorisation provides real-time account balance management.  When an event is established, and during pre-determined intervals within an event, the balance manager uses cached service, customer, account and entitlement information to determine the appropriate credit amount to reserve for that event.  Once the event is complete, the unused reserved amount is returned to the customer's account credit, so that the next event can be accurately processed.  Customer controlled account selection and advice of charge  Subscribing customers can control which of their accounts is used on a per session basis.  A subscriber can request the cost of a specific item or service, including rates for volume-based or duration-based services.  Customer controlled service-specific spending limits  Subscribing customers can specify spending limits specific to a service.  For example, a mobile phone can be limited to a specified amount per month or restricted from making international calls.  Real-time rating  Both event establishment and event completion are immediately communicated and processed.  Account credits and credit limits are updated as events occur.  Real-time credit limit checks  Credit limits are checked when events are generated for real-time tariffs, reservations are created against account balances, and the unbilled amount of the account is updated with a charge generated by a tariff configured for real-time account aggregation.  Consistent rating performance  The rating engine performs consistently to provide real time account processing and queries.  Caches can be pre-loaded.  Cache misses are prevented during dynamic configuration or system re-start.  High and continuous availability of Commerce Engine  A system that offers cost authorisation and advice of charge information needs to be effectively and consistently available, and should not be disturbed by planned or unplanned outages.  Redundant components and multiple processes are supported for both Commerce Engine and user transactions.  Both Convergent Billing and third party upgrades can be performed without interruption of the Commerce Engine service.

pages.title: Batch File Processing
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a flexible solution for batch file processing.  The solution has the following components:   Batch Extractor  Batch Loader.

pages.title: Batch Extractor
pages.text: The Batch Extractor extracts Singleview data using the following:  External definitions   Search external definition to determine the required records.  Fetch external definition to retrieve the records.  Interface definition based on the BatchOutbound interface type.  Batch Extractor schedule type to run the configured batch extraction.  The results of the batch extraction can be checked using the File Processing Details form.  For more information about the Batch Extractor, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Batch Loader
pages.text: The Batch Loader loads data into Singleview using the following:  External definitions  A search external definition to translate the tags in the file to be loaded to the corresponding fields in the database.   Interface definition based on the BatchInbound interface type.  Batch Load schedule type to run the configured batch load.  The results of the batch load can be checked using the File Processing Details form.  For more information about the Batch Loader, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Bill Runs
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, bill run types are used to configure what tasks run together for a specific bill run.  Bill run types offer the option of running a range of billing operations, from adjusting rental events to un-applying invoices.  Generating rental events (RGP), generating invoices (BGP) and invoice images (IGP), and outputting those results (GOP) are all possible tasks for a bill run.  For example, a standard bill run schedule could be configured to perform an immediate bill run consisting of the BGP, IGP, and to apply invoices, but not to run the RGP or the GOP.  If required, the apply invoices and revoke invoices processes can also be run as individual schedules.  For example, if a daily cycle bill run fails and it is determined that one customer caused the failure, the whole bill run does not have to be revoked and rerun; only the customer who caused the failure needs to be revoked and rerun.  Using bill runs, it is possible to generate invoices, which are sent out to the customer for payment, and temporary statements, which can be used for quality assurance purposes or for customer information.  Invoices can also be generated for designated interim rental events (tariffs), so a customer can be invoiced for a specific product or service (using the Interim Bill Run schedule type).  Processing multiple customer nodes speeds up the bill run process, and controls the quality of the process.  For example, the user can review initial invoices before the majority of customer nodes have been processed; if the first invoices contain errors, the bill run can be stopped.  Statistical information for each billing operation is recorded, including the success or failure of the operation and its duration.  For bill runs processing multiple customers, the statistical information is recorded for each operation and summarised for the overall bill run.  Billing personnel also have complete control over how many errors can occur before the bill run is aborted.  If errors occur, it is necessary only to revoke the billing operations on the customer nodes that failed.

pages.title: Built-in Decoding
pages.text: Built-in decoding methods decode events in the specified format into direct variables that make up normalised events in the database.  The variables then receive any additional processing that may be defined in the normalised event file type.  The built-in decoding method is Convergent Billing native format, used for internal events such as rental events, and by external applications (for example, real-time rating).

pages.title: Call TRE Database Functions
pages.text: TRE database functions provide access to Convergent Billing database tables to insert, update, and delete Convergent Billing entities.  Generally, TRE database functions are one of the following types:  Search Functions  Data Retrieval Functions  Insert Functions.  For information on the TRE views accessed by the TRE database functions, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).

pages.title: Call Usage
pages.text: Convergent Billing enables searching for, viewing, and printing a customer’s usage details.  The usage details display exactly what charges a customer has accrued, both billed (reported) and unbilled (outstanding in the account).    If a customer has more than one service, the exact charges (billed and unbilled) for each service number can be identified.  The normalised event type associated with each event determines the type of additional usage details displayed.  Specifies the type of normalised event used to generate normalised events based on transactions occurring in Convergent Billing.  An event type is also used to derive additional information about a normalised event from the information supplied by external systems.   Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Normalised Event and Normalised Event File Type.

pages.title: Category
pages.text: A category is a grouping of entities within Process Engine (for example, classes, facts and objects) which facilitates easy transfer, filtering and general manipulation of the group.  Categories are assigned only to Convergent Billing users with access to Process Engine.

pages.title: Charge Categories
pages.text: Charge Category Examples  A charge category specifies an account type and, optionally, an account, to which a tariff’s charge or benefit is posted, and is an essential part of tariffing.  Another account type can also be defined and, optionally, an account, to which a balancing (opposite) entry can be posted (known as the ‘from’ account).  The term ‘tariff/charge category pair’ is often used to emphasise that the two objects are independent, but always go together.  Charge categories cannot reference account types that permit multiple accounts of the same type on a customer node.  The account inferred from an account type assigned to a charge category must be unambiguous.  A charge category instance is created for every tariff used by a service whenever a product containing the service is sold, creating a product instance.  The charge category instance is located at the customer node, the customer (root node), or the service level, depending on the context defined for the associated tariff.  A different instance of the charge category can exist at each level, for use by tariffs with different contexts.  A charge category instance is created using values from the default charge category specified in the appropriate tariff configuration.  The values used can be overridden.  Only one instance of the charge category is created at each location, no matter how many services reference the tariff.  Any defaults for services after the first are ignored.  A charge category instance can be re-defined so that proportions of a charge are posted to more than one account.  They can also be edited after creation, to redirect payments to a different account.  When the rating or billing engine processes an event, the process involves looking up details of the service stored at the customer node, identifying the applicable tariffs, and then using the tariffs to calculate the value of each charge or benefit.  The appropriate charge category instance is then used to identify the account.  The combination of the charge and the account information makes up the charge record in the CHARGE table of the database.  A charge category instance can also define a GL code to assign to the charge or benefit, if required.  However, using charge categories to assign GL codes is deprecated and provided for backward compatibility only. GL codes are assigned to charges using GL guidance (for more information, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview).

pages.title: Default Charge Categories
pages.text: When working with charge categories, it is important to distinguish between the charge category instance, defined with the product instance, and the default charge categories, which are used to provide default values when the instance is created.  The charge category instance is defined automatically when the product instance is defined, using values from the default charge category specified in the tariff definition.  If necessary, these values can be overridden at the customer node, or by modified default charge categories specified in the customer type or the service type.  Changing values in this way gives provides much flexibility in deciding which account is to be used for a specific event.  Examples of the use of these defaults are provided separately.  Default charge category definitions do not, in general, define an account number, because the account to use is often not known until the charge category instance is defined.  At that time, the appropriate account number is determined, based on the account type defined in the charge category default.  For example, a charge or benefit should be posted to the primary account belonging to the customer node.  To achieve this, the account type in the charge category default must be the same as the account type of the primary account.  However, it may sometimes be necessary to define a specific account number in a default charge category.

pages.title: Override Charge Categories
pages.text: When a base charge category is defined, overriding default versions of the same charge category at the customer node, customer type, and service type can be defined.  These overriding charge categories are definted only when and where they are required.  If overriding charge categories change the default account number or GL code, the following priorities are used to determine which to accept:  Customer node  Customer type  Service type.  Using charge categories to assign GL codes is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  GL codes are assigned to charges using GL guidance.

pages.title: Charge Category Examples
pages.text: The following table lists examples of how charge categories can be defined, overridden, and used.  Example 1  Basic Charge Category  Requirement  Costs and benefits are to be posted to the primary account of the customer node.  GL codes are not used.  Solution  Define the base default charge category without specifying either an account number or a GL code, but specifying the same account type as the primary account.  The account number of the customer node's primary account is selected automatically when the charge category instance is defined.  Example 2  Assigning Charges to Another Customer Node  Requirement  Another department (with its own customer node) agrees to pay the charges for a service defined at a customer node.  Solution  Amend the charge category instance for the service, by replacing the account number with the primary account number of the other customer node.  Example 3  Splitting a Charge between Customer Nodes  Requirement  Two customer nodes share a service defined at one of the nodes.  The other customer node agrees to pay 30% of the charges for the service.  Solution  Define a duplicate of the charge category instance, with the account number set to the primary account of the other node, and the proportion set to 0.3 (the proportion this node will pay).  Amend the existing charge category instance, by changing the proportion to 0.7 (the proportion paid by this customer node).  When charges are split in this way, the sum of all the proportions defined must be 1.  Example 4  Using a different Account Type  Requirement  The company awards loyalty points based on usage.  The number of points accumulated is to be recorded in an account of type Loyalty, defined at the customer node.  Solution  Define the base charge category with the account number empty, and the account type set to Loyalty.  When the charge category instance is defined, the number of the Loyalty account at the customer node is entered automatically.  The appropriate account type must be defined before it can be used in the default charge category.  The service instance cannot be activated if the customer node does not have an account of the appropriate type.  Example 5  Tracking Payments Owing to a Supplier  Requirement  Another service provider provides a service being sold to customers, and it is necessary to track the payments due to this provider.  Solution  Create a customer node for the supplier.  Payments due to this supplier can then be accumulated in the primary account.  Define a tariff for the charges to be paid by customers in the usual way and include it in the product definition.  A charge category instance at each customer node posts charges to the appropriate account.  Define another tariff to calculate the payment due to the provider, and include it in the product definition.   Set the account number of its default charge category to point to the primary account of the provider's customer node.  The charge category instance for this tariff then posts charges to the supplier's account.  Example 6  Using the ‘From’ Account  Requirement  A tax based on usage is payable by the customer.  The tax due to the tax authority, for whom the company is acting as a collecting agent, must be recorded.  Solution  Create a customer node for the tax authority.  Define a tariff for the tax payable, and add it to the product definition.  Define the base default charge category with the 'to' account number empty (for automatic assignment of the customer's account number when the charge category instance is created), and the 'from' account number set to the primary account number of the tax authority's customer node.  The charge type of the base default charge category should be set to 'Charge Transfer'.  Example 7  Charge Category for a Global Tariff  Requirement  The company wants to keep a record of all calls to a specified destination switch.  Solution  Define:  A global tariff with context Normalised Event that calculates the desired quantity.  Set the eligibility for this tariff to identify the calls to be recorded.  The base default charge category for this tariff to point to the account in which to store the call information.  The solution is one of the few times when an account number is defined in the base default charge category, because a global tariff uses this default directly, rather than an instance of it.  If the base default charge category does not include an account number, the tariff does not work.

pages.title: Charge Output
pages.text: A charge output defines the order and values to be stored for each charge record output by an Event Rating Process (ERT) and passed into a real-time rating output feed.  The charge output definition is created as part of the three stage process in configuring a Charge Data Record format to suit requirements.  The process is as follows:  Decide on the contents of each field in the Charge Data Record, and the order in which they will appear.  Create direct variables in the database to match the fields in the Charge Data Record, both in data type and in order of appearance.  Create the Charge Output definition by writing expressions to populate the direct variables with values derived from the rating process.

pages.title: Charge Data Record Format
pages.text: Charge data records conform to the Event Rating Protocol (ERP).  In particular, they have the following characteristics:  The start of a record is indicated by a byte of value 254 (0FEH), represented by @.  Records take the form of a byte stream with no parity.  All fields are ASCII characters as supported by the character set installed on the machine on which the database is installed.  All fields are terminated by a byte of value 255 (0FFH), represented by |.  Fields in the event data record map to the direct variables defined by the charge output definition.  The ordering of the fields is the same as the column number in the notional view to which the direct variable is attached.  A field exists in the record for each direct variable defined; an empty field will be represented by its terminating | byte immediately following the | byte of the preceding field.

pages.title: Commerce Engine
pages.text: Commerce Engine is an additional component supplied as separate Convergent Billing licence option and is designed to work seamlessly with the Convergent Billing product.   Commerce Engine provides real-time responses and transaction management, necessary for transaction authorisation and real-time account balancing.  Key attributes include:  Real-time balance management and budget controls before, during, and after a transaction.  Commerce Engine also enables multiple content and voice transactions to occur simultaneously in parallel.  Discounts and volume-based pricing to competitively differentiate prepaid service offerings.  Commerce Engine empowers service providers to offer the best of each payment approach (postpaid or prepaid) to effectively support subscribers.  Interactive and real-time cost control for service authorisation.  Customer-controlled dynamic account selection and spending limits.  Advice of charge so customers can request the cost they may incur for an item or service.  Real-time, event-driven billing for the convergence of content and usage.  A common revenue management framework for Intelligent Network servers, commerce servers, and other requesting applications.

NOT IN  Not equal to any member of a set or sub-query.  Also equivalent to '!= ALL'.  ANY,SOME  True if the condition is satisfied by one or more values contained in a list of expressions or returned by a sub-query.  ALL  True if the condition is satisfied by all values contained in a list of expressions or returned by a sub-query.  BETWEEN x AND y  Greater than or equal to x and less than or equal to y. Lexicographical ordering (or 'dictionary' ordering) requires that spaces are positioned before other characters, symbols are positioned before alphanumeric characters, and the remaining characters are placed in alphanumeric order.  Conditional Operators for Composite Types  Operator  Array  Hash  =  Equal  Equal  != or <>  Not Equal  Not Equal  <  Less  >  Greater  <=  Less or Equal  >=  Greater or Equal  <=>  Array Element Comparison  Notes on the Comparison Operator  The EPM comparison operator (<=>) compares two values if they are of the same data type.  Zero is returned if the values being compared are the same.  A positive integer is returned if the first value is greater than the second.  A negative integer is returned if the first value is less than the second.  Notes on Array and Hash Operations  Arrays are compared by examining corresponding elements, or by comparing with an undefined value if there is no corresponding element in one of the arrays.  An undefined value is compared after all other values, which is consistent with the ordering of NULL values by Oracle.  An undefined value is not equivalent to the default value for an undefined element.  A runtime error is raised if Array elements cannot be ordered.  For example, an integer cannot be compared to a string, and a string cannot be compared to a hash.  A runtime error is also raised if a comparison is made between unequal hash elements.  Arrays are equal if they are the same size, and each element is equal with the corresponding element in the second Array.  Two hashes are equal if they are the same size, they have the same set of keys, and the corresponding key values in each hash are equal.

pages.title: Configuration Explorer
pages.text: Convergent Billing is a highly configurable system designed to increase competitive advantage by making it easier to design, deliver, and bill the products and services customers require.  Convergent Billing offers support for rapidly configuring new products and tariffs to meet customers’ changing requirements.  Configuring products involves a combination of service types, equipment types, tariffs, subtotals, facility groups, derived attributes, and product offers. The combination of these elements provides the flexibility required to deliver a product offering tailored to specific customer requirements.  Convergent Billing is also designed to meet the growing demands for a more personalised service.  The customer care environment allows users to respond to new and existing customers promptly, consistently, and professionally.  However, the system also provides the capability of customising the customer care forms to perform functions to manage specific business requirements.  Administrators of the system therefore have control over the information captured by users.    Configuring the customer care environment involves a combination of reference types, attribute types, help entry definitions, entity validation, address formats, and customer care types.  In addition, comprehensive security features enable the control of access to information and the use of the system.  Configuring security settings involves a combination of security groups, form roles, function roles, work groups, profiles, and user definitions.  To manage the extensive configuration options available, the system provides the capability of viewing the entire configuration in an environment similar to Windows Explorer or FrontPage Explorer.  The Configuration Explorer (see the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing) enables the viewing of the contents of a configuration object, all the references to the object, and the properties of the object.  Viewing the configuration of the system from a central area enables administrators to:  Investigate the effects of changes to the configuration.  Quickly examine the entire configuration of a configuration object.  Customise the configuration from the Configuration Explorer.  Copy and print diagrams of the configuration.  Search for specific configuration information.

pages.title: Configuration Items
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, configuration items are used to specify which server processes are to be started and maintained, and to define the attributes for each process.  Configuration items are also used to define the checks performed to enforce the system licensing conditions, defining Oracle triggers for database auditing, setting up system wide defaults used in entity validation.  Configuration item types are used to define generic and default values for the configuration items associated with the configuration type.  The configuration item types provide default values that can be applied to configuration items when creating a new configuration item.

pages.title: Contacts
pages.text: Details can be recorded about any person, position, or organisation that, during normal business, may need to be contacted.  One of the main reasons for recording a contact is to assign that contact to a customer, which can be regarded as simply creating a 'link' between that contact and a specified customer.  The link effectively defines a relationship between contact and customer.  If the link is no longer required, the link can be removed by unassigning the contact.  The same contact can be assigned to more than one customer.  Each assignment is independent of each of the other assignments.  Unassigning a contact therefore has no effect on the links to any other customer.  Unassigning a contact simply removes the link between the contact and a specified customer and is therefore not the same as deleting the contact  A contact can be assigned as a primary customer contact (typically the person to whom the customer’s invoice is sent) or as a secondary customer contact.  To ensure integrity of customer data, the system only permits a primary customer contact to be replaced or modified.  A contact assigned as a primary customer contact can therefore only be deleted after it is replaced (if it is not specified as a primary customer contact for another customer).  A contact assigned as a secondary customer contact can be unassigned, replaced, modified, or deleted whenever required.  Details for a contact can be maintained whenever required.  For example, update a contact by modifying or deleting details, or adding details.  If a contact is no longer required, it can also be deleted (if it is not assigned as a contact for a customer).

pages.title: Contact Examples
pages.text: This facility is usually used to record details of a person to be assigned as the contact for a customer; for example, recording details of the Accounts Payable clerk of a corporate customer who is responsible for handling invoices.  In many organisations, a function such as Accounts Payable is carried out by a number of different people.  In such cases, it is more appropriate to record the details of a specific position, rather than a specific person.  Details of any organisation to be contacted during normal day-to-day activities can be recorded.  It could be another department or division within a company, or an external organisation.  For example, as a result of a fault inquiry, an organisation that services a specific equipment item has to be contacted to arrange a customer callout, or the address and phone number of a specified equipment supplier’s Help Desk may need to be recorded.

pages.title: Context-sensitive Help
pages.text: Context-sensitive help is a feature that provides:  Context-sensitive form help for each form.  Context-sensitive field help for each form component (fields, buttons, check boxes, and options).    Customising Context-sensitive Help  Convergent Billing context-sensitive help can be customised in the following ways:  Convergent Billing forms can have a customised HTML page associated with them.  Dynamic forms can have customised field or form help.  Field help can be customised for core Convergent Billing forms and dynamic forms.  Field help can be associated with an attribute type.  The help entry associated with an attribute type overrides the context-sensitive help for fields to which the attribute type is applied.  Customising context-sensitive help is performed in Convergent Billing using the following forms:  Help Entry Definition form, which is used to define the help text for fields.  Form Definition form, which groups the help entry definitions for forms and allows alternative HTML files to be specified.  Attribute Type Definition form, which can associate a field help entry with the attribute type.  For more information about customising context-sensitive help, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Continuous Availability
pages.text: Convergent Billing offers support for Commerce Engine (or rating modules) to be continually available.  That is, rating modules can be configured and upgraded in a highly available environment without interrupting service to the customer.  Support is offered only for the continuous availability of Commerce Engine components.  Continuous availability is not provided for user access, transactional services, or billing operations.  Commerce Engine is available as a separate licence option.  A continuously available system requires that configuration and upgrades not interfere with the highly available system.  The following items support Commerce Engine continuous availability:  Database access  Convergent Billing supports running Commerce Engine in a mode where it is disconnected from the database, either as a planned or unplanned outage.  The non-database mode enables upgrades to the database software while keeping Commerce Engine online.   Archiving data  Data is kept consistent during the archiving process.  If the archiver should fail, data remains consistent in the database.   Cache capacity  With a 64-bit implementation, Convergent Billing supports rating cache sizes that can handle rating in non-database mode.   Configuration Upgrades  When the configuration for rating modules is changed, the biRatingRestart&() function can be used to initiate controlled restarts of the rating servers (or rating streams).

pages.title: Contract Type
pages.text: Special terms and conditions can be applied to a set of products and services for any root customer by using contracts.  The contract functionality enhances the product administrator's ability to design flexible products by enabling them to include features such as the following:  Legal agreement between the organisation and the customer to apply special terms and conditions to products and services for a specific duration.  Context:  Convergent Billing  Provides a specific component of the overall product for which the customer is charged.  Each service has an associated service type, and unique service number against which usage is charged.  One or more facilities (service options) or items of equipment, or both, can be associated with each service.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Equipment, Facility, and Service Type.  Refer to Base Product and Companion Product.  Products at a discount price for a specified period of time  Discounts for selected ranges of numbers (for example, a company's calls between offices)  Fixed prices for specific products  Specific contracts to meet requirements for an individual customer.  A contract is implemented by defining a base product (to include the basic product requirements) and a companion product and associating them with a contract type.  The companion product is used to modify the costing attributes of the base product for the term of the contract.  The companion product can be used to add tariff definition/charge category pairs and subtotal definitions used in conjunction with those in the base product.  Discount tariffs can also be added to change the charges calculated as a result of applying the base product tariffs.  Identifies the default account type to which a calculated tariff charge or benefit is posted (allocated).  For services, the charge category also identifies a specific account number.  The association between a tariff and a charge category is specified when the tariff is defined and is referred to as the tariff/charge category pair.  By default, the charge category associated with a tariff is used each time that tariff is used.  However, the charge category can be overridden when defining a customer type, service type, customer node, or service.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Account Type and Tariff.  Table of conditions and associated charges.  The table is used to determine the charge values to be substituted into the charge expression to calculate the value of the specified tariff.  The charge values used for the substitution are those associated with the conditions in the tariff table that match the conditional expressions used as keys into the tariff table.  The structure of the tariff table is created during tariff configuration and the appropriate conditions and charges entered into the table during tariff definition.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Tariff, Tariff Configuration, and Tariff Definition.  Product used to add tariffs, subtotals, and derived attributes to a base product.  Allows an alternative costing regime to be applied to an existing product.  A companion product cannot exist in isolation; it must be associated with an existing base product.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Base Product, Base Product Compatibility, Companion Product Compatibility and Feature.  Combination of service types, equipment types, tariffs, subtotals, facility groups, and derived attributes required to deliver a competitive product offering.  A product is the only entity sold to a customer.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Base Product Compatibility, Companion Product, and Companion Product Compatibility.  For example, a twelve month contract is defined to offer a discount, to large corporate customers, on mobile calls if a certain usage for their standard business touch phones is reached.  A companion product is defined with a discount tariff that overrides the usage tariffs, and any subtotals, specified in the base product.  Tariff eligibility criteria is applied to determine whether the set amount of usage has been reached and whether or not the discount is applied.  To define a product that includes a contract, a base product and companion product are defined and then applied to a specific contract type.  When a user applies a contract to a customer record, the selected contract type determines the products and companion products used for the contract.  When the contract is assigned to one or more service instances on the base product instance, the companion product is created automatically.  The contract type is also used to define the following defaults for contracts of that type:  Duration of the contract.  Grace period (the amount of time after the expected expiry date that the contract can remain active before being cancelled or re-negotiated).  Account manager responsible for the contract.  Re-negotiation period (the period of time before the contract expires that the account manager is notified re-negotiation is required).  Expiry warning period (the period of time before the expiry of the contract when the account manager is warned that the contract is about to expire).  Sales channel (the method by which the contract was obtained).  The contract type is also used to define the defaults for contracts of that type and to apply entity validation to the Contract Detail form.

pages.title: Contracts
pages.text: Special terms and conditions can be applied to a set of products and services for any root customer by using contracts.  Any services associated with a root customer that are related to the products used for the contract, can be linked to the contract (except if they are used by another contract).  Convergent Billing also offers the option of associating all the customer's available services with the contract.  Legal agreement between the organisation and the customer to apply special terms and conditions to products and services for a specific duration.  Context:  Convergent Billing  Provides a specific component of the overall product for which the customer is charged.  Each service has an associated service type, and unique service number against which usage is charged.  One or more facilities (service options) or items of equipment, or both, can be associated with each service.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Equipment, Facility, and Service Type.  Refer to Base Product and Companion Product.  A contract has one or more base products and product offers associated with it.  Each companion product in a product offeris used to modify the costing attributes of the base product for the term of the contract.  The contract functionality enhances the ability to offer:  Products at a discount price for a specific period of time.  Discounts for selected ranges of numbers (for example, a company's calls between offices).  Fixed prices for specific products.  Specific contracts to meet requirements for an individual customer.  For example, a twelve month contract is defined to offer a discount on mobile calls to large corporate customers if a certain usage for their standard business touch phones is reached.  A companion product is defined with a discount tariff that overrides the usage tariffs (calculates a negative amount to counteract the usage tariff), and any subtotals, specified in the base product.  Tariff eligibility criteria is applied to determine whether the set amount of usage is reached and whether or not the discount is applied. A product offer is created containing the discount companion product, and set as a child of the product offer associated with the base product.

pages.title: Convergent Billing Native Format
pages.text: A native format used for internal events, such as rental events, and for external applications such as real-time rating.  The SingleView CB Native built-in format should be used when mapping to the current version's NORMALISED_EVENT_V view.   All other native formats (3.03, 4.00, and 4.02) are present only for backward compatibility.   Event data records using the native format must have the following characteristics:  All fields consist of 8-bit ASCII characters, as supported by the character set installed on the machine on which the database is installed.  An ASCII 0 (null) character terminates all fields for the following Convergent Billing versions:  SingleView CB Native  SingleView CB V4.00 Native  SingleView CB V4.02 Native.  For this reason, the null character cannot be included in event data.  In the format SingleView CB V3.03 Native, all fields are terminated by a byte of value 255 (0FFH).  Both field terminators are represented by | in Convergent Billing documentation.  Fields in the event data record must be a one-to-one mapping to the direct variables defined for the NORMALISED_EVENT_V view.  The ordering of the fields should be the same as the column number in the view from which the direct variable is derived.  The listing of all direct variables defined in NORMALISED_EVENT_V in the Convergent Billing base installation represents all the relevant fields that can be defined for a Convergent Billing normalised event, and can be regarded as the default event data record definition.  A field must exist in the record for each direct variable that is defined; an empty field should be represented by its terminating | byte immediately following the | byte of the preceding field.  Values in fields must evaluate to the correct data type for the variable to which they map.

pages.title: Currencies
pages.text: Currencies are defined to provide international customers with invoices and statements in the appropriate currency.  A currency definition specifies the currency and the conversion (exchange) rate to other specified currencies defined in Convergent Billing.  A currency defined in Convergent Billing does not necessarily need to be monetary.  Non-monetary currencies such as frequent flyer points can be defined.

pages.title: Customer Hierarchies
pages.text: A customer hierarchy is a representation of a customer’s hierarchical organisational or account structure.  It consists of one or more customer nodes, each representing a customer account to which charges can be accrued.  Corporate customers often require multiple billing/reporting points.  For example, if an account is required for each division in a multi-national company, a separate customer node is used to represent each division’s account.  The customer nodes in the customer hierarchy are organised into a structure (very often mirroring the company’s organisational structure) that is similar to a family tree.  Like a family tree, a customer hierarchy displays the relationship between customer nodes.  A relationship exists between Node A and the two nodes directly below it, namely Nodes B and C.  In terms of the hierarchy, Node A is said to be the parent of Nodes B and C.  Nodes B and C are said to be children of Node A.  A similar parent-child relationship exists between Node B and Nodes D and E, and between Node C and Nodes F and G.  Notice that Node B is both a child (of Node A) and a parent (of Nodes D and E).  Similarly, Node C is both a child (of Node A) and a parent (of Nodes F and G).  The node at the top of the customer hierarchy is unique in that it has no parent node.  It is considered as the root of the hierarchy and is referred to as the root customer node.  Associated with each customer node within the hierarchy is a reporting level, which determines whether that node is to receive an invoice, statement, or neither.  The root customer node must have a reporting level of ‘Invoice’.  A customer can receive either a statement or an invoice if the required invoice and statement formats are defined.  Convergent Billing provides a facility to display single or multiple instances of a customer hierarchy using the Customer Search form.  Convergent Billing provides facilities to create, view, and modify each customer node forming a specific customer’s accounting hierarchy.  In addition, facilities are provided to re-organise the hierarchy to meet changing customer requirements.  For more information about configuring the Customer Hierarchy form, refer to the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Customer Nodes in a Hierarchical Structure
pages.text: [[FigureXref:1780-1]] displays customer nodes in a simple hierarchical structure.  [[Figure:1780-1]]  Customer Nodes in a Hierarchical Structure  A relationship exists between Node A and the two nodes directly below it, namely Nodes B and C.  In terms of the hierarchy, Node A is said to be the parent of Nodes B and C.  Conversely, Nodes B and C are said to be children of Node A.  A similar parent-child relationship exists between Node B and Nodes D and E, and between Node C and Nodes F and G.  Notice that Node B is both a child (of Node A) and a parent (of Nodes D and E).  Similarly, Node C is both a child (of Node A) and a parent (of Nodes F and G).

pages.title: Assign Products to Customers
pages.text: A product and its associated service or services can be assigned (attached) to any customer node.  By default, a service is billed in the primary account on the customer node to which it is assigned, but this can be overridden.  Charges associated with services on nodes that have reporting levels of Statement or None can be rolled up to a node in the hierarchy that has a reporting level of Invoice.

pages.title: Expand and Collapse a Customer Hierarchy
pages.text: The nodes displayed at each level of a hierarchy can be controlled by expanding or collapsing nodes associated with each level.  Expanding a parent node displays each of the child nodes associated with that node.  When every parent node is expanded, a customer hierarchy is said to be in a fully expanded state.  Collapsing a parent node 'hides' (removes from the display) each of the child nodes associated with that node.    When a customer search is performed, all customer nodes that match the search criteria are displayed hierarchically in the Customer Hierarchy form.  If a customer node has a parent node that does not match the search criteria, the parent node is displayed (to reflect the hierarchical relationship).   If a parent node is collapsed and expanded again, all child nodes of the parent node are fetched regardless of whether a child node matches the search criteria.  To limit the number of child nodes displayed, configure the MAX_TREE_CHILD_NODES attribute of the SYSTEM_CLIENT configuration item.  If a parent node that has more child nodes than the limit is expanded, a warning message is displayed.

pages.title: Customer Query Types
