pages.text: A customer query type is used to define common parameters for customer query detail records.  For example, a customer query type can be used for customers complaining about their account.  The following table lists examples of query types.  Query Type  Description  Bill complaint  Customer has a problem with the charges or payments listed on their invoice.  Fault report  Customer’s line or equipment is faulty.  Invoice Not Received  Customer has not received their monthly invoice.  Service Query  Customer has a query about their service.  Service Cancellation  Customer wants to cancel their service.  A customer query type relies on a number of items being defined and available within Convergent Billing.  Available items include work group, and icon.  If the Customer Query form for a customer query type is being customised, the appropriate entity validation definitions, attribute types, reference types, and context-sensitive help must be defined before the customer type is defined.

pages.title: Customer Types
pages.text: A customer type is used to define common parameters for customer records.  For example, when account details for several residential customers are recorded, it is likely that the same values are entered for the reporting level, GL code, period of payment, and work group handling residential queries.  The use of the GL code specified on customer types is deprecated and provided for backward compatibility only.  GL codes are assigned to charges using GL guidance.  The following table lists examples of customer types.  Customer Type  Description  Corporate  Services for a business with more than 12 employees.  Residential  Services for domestic use, not for business use.  Small Business  Services for a business with 12 or fewer employees.  The customer type relies on a number of items being defined and available within Convergent Billing.  Available items include address format, account type, GL code, work group, and icon.  If customising the Customer Detail form for a specific customer type, the appropriate entity validation definitions, attribute types, reference types, and context-sensitive help must be defined before the customer type is defined.

pages.title: Customers
pages.text: Details specific to each customer are recorded by Convergent Billing; for example, name, address, preferred format, frequency of invoicing, credit limit and credit rating, and account information such as their account number, and their preferred method of payment and payment location.    Person or organisation using one or more products.  Each customer is given a unique primary account against which invoices are raised.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Account, Contact, Customer Node, Customer Type, Product, and Product Offer.  For corporate customers, company number, the industry they are involved in, region in which they operate, and expected annual turnover can be recorded.  Customer hierarchies can also be created for corporate customers.  When recording a customer’s details, a person must be assigned to act as the customer contact.  For personal customers, the person assigned is likely to be the actual customer.  For corporate customers and network providers, the person assigned as the customer contact is more likely to be a person in that company responsible for arranging services on behalf of other employees.  Details about the person nominated as the customer contact must therefore also be recorded in Convergent Billing.  A person's details can be recorded either before or during the creation of a customer record.  Provides a specific component of the overall product for which the customer is charged.  Each service has an associated service type, and unique service number against which usage is charged.  One or more facilities (service options) or items of equipment, or both, can be associated with each service.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Equipment, Facility, and Service Type.  Person assigned as a contact for a customer and who can be contacted about the customer's account or services.  The contact person can be the customer, or a person working within an organisation.  At least one contact person (referred to as the primary contact) is required per customer, but more than one contact can be recorded.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Customer, Primary Contact, and Secondary Contact.  More than one customer contact can be assigned to a customer, which is useful for corporate customers where there may be more than one person to be contacted.  If more than one customer contact is assigned to a customer, one contact is referred to as the primary contact; the remaining contacts being referred to as secondary contacts.  The correct contact must be used for the primary contact, as it is this person to whom invoices, statements, and other correspondence about the customer’s account are sent.  Person, other than the primary contact, assigned as an additional contact for a customer.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Customer Contact and Primary Contact.  Main or initial contact associated with a customer.  If more than one contact is listed for a specific customer, one of those contacts is specified as the primary contact.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Contact and Secondary Contact.  In Convergent Billing, the process of recording a customer’s details (including a primary contact) is referred to as creating a customer.  When a customer is created, Convergent Billing allows products and associated services to be assigned to that customer, and invoices detailing the charges for services to be raised against that customer’s account.  Convergent Billing also allows queries and contracts to be assigned to that customer   Legal agreement between the organisation and the customer to apply special terms and conditions to products and services for a specific duration.  Context:  Convergent Billing  Enquiry made by a customer or contact that is recorded.  The resolution of that enquiry generally results in information being passed back to that customer or contact.  A query can range from an enquiry about available products by a prospective customer, to a complaint from a customer about charges on an invoice.  If the query cannot be resolved immediately, it is progressed to a work group for resolution.  The query facility is also used to record internal enquiries.  For example, the query facility can be used to enquire about a customer's credit rating by raising a query and forwarding it to an organisation's finance department.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Progress, Progression, and Work Group.  Unique account to which financial transactions are posted.  Each customer has at least one account (known as the primary account) and optionally one or more secondary accounts.  Each account has a unique account number by which it is identified.  See also Account Type.  Legal document itemising charges (and possibly credits) accrued against that customer's account for services used by, or supplied to, that customer over a specified period.  Accrued charges for a customer node in a customer hierarchy can be 'rolled up' into the invoice for a node higher in the customer hierarchy.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Customer Hierarchy, Customer Node, Reporting Level, and Statement.  Refer to Base Product and Companion Product.  A customer’s details can be maintained whenever required.  For example, a customer can be updated by modifying or deleting details, or adding details such as one or more secondary accounts.  If a customer record is no longer required, it can also be deactivated.  Details associated with a deactivated customer can subsequently be archived.  If required, customers who are considered to be 'bad risks' can be blacklisted.

pages.title: Deactivate Customers
pages.text: A customer may need to be deactivated at their request, or because of a business decision by an organisation.  A customer is deactivated by setting the status of the customer’s account to Cancellation Requested or Cancelled.  Deactivating/cancelling a customer:  Allows the effective date of the cancellation to be specified.  Allows the account to be finalised and printed or the invoice cycle for the final invoice to be specified.  Sets the end date of the cancelled customer to infinity.  For prepaid without statements customers, the invoice cycle for the final invoice is not required.   A customer (or customer node) can only be deactivated if all of the following are cancelled:  Product instances  Child nodes (if any).

pages.title: Blacklist Customers
pages.text: Customers who continually default on payments and potential customers considered to be bad risks can be recorded in Convergent Billing with a status of Black-listed.  Customers having this status can only be assigned products and services by users having appropriate security privileges.  An organisation’s policies and business practices determine the criteria for blacklisting a customer and whether such customers can be assigned products and services.  To blacklist a customer, the Mark Customer as Blacklisted security privilege must be available on the Customer Detail form.  To highlight a blacklisted customer, when that customer is displayed in the left-hand panel of the Customer Hierarchy form, their name and the associated icon are greyed-out.  If a blacklisted customer is selected in the left-hand panel of the Customer Hierarchy form, the details displayed in the right-hand panel depend on available security privileges.  If View Blacklisted Customer security privilege is:  Assigned on the Customer Detail form, all items (products, services, equipment, queries, and contracts) associated with the specified customer are listed in the right-hand panel.  The security privilege also allows the Customer Detail form for that customer to be displayed.  Not assigned on the Customer Detail form, only the customer’s name and status is displayed in the right-hand panel and the Customer Detail form cannot be displayed.  If, as a result of a customer search, only a single record is returned and that record is for a blacklisted customer, the Customer Hierarchy form is displayed regardless of the setting of the Always Display Hierarchy? option.  Displaying the Customer Hierarchy form ensures that details of the blacklisted customer are available only to users having the required security privileges.

pages.title: Data Interface Language
pages.text: The Convergent Billing Data Interface Language (DIL) is used to define the structure of an incoming event record data stream to the interpreter in the Event Normalisation (ENM) process.  The interpreter breaks the data stream down into its constituent records, and each record into its constituent fields.  Rules and expressions can then be used to perform calculations and assign data from these fields into direct variables.    The ENM uses these direct variables to construct normalised events, which can then be rated and stored in the database.  If no rules or expressions have been defined for an input field, the interpreter moves on to the next field; in effect, the value of such a field is ignored, though its length is used to advance through the data stream.  The DIL is loosely based on the protocol language known as Abstract Syntax Notation One (ASN.1), defined by the International Telecommunications Union (ITU).  For the complete definition of ASN.1, refer to the ITU-T Specification of Abstract Syntax Notation One (ASN.1) X.208 Fascicle VII.4.  Though primarily intended for parsing event data, the DIL is not limited to this sole function.  The DIL can be used, for example, to process payment records, calling TRE remote functions to insert the payment details into the database.  The DIL is used to decode a sequence of bytes that make up one or more event records, breaking each record up into its constituent fields.  Where necessary, these fields can be manipulated, using the Convergent Billing Expression Parser Module (EPM), and eventually converted to the Direct Variables that make up a Normalised Event.  The resulting event can then be rated, to generate charges for the appropriate service.  A DIL definition is made up of keywords, type definitions,	identifiers, semantics, and included definitions.

pages.title: Data Interface Language Decoding
pages.text: Data Interface Language (DIL) decoding provides a generic method for decoding events from any source.  DIL definitions can be created in Convergent Billing to convert byte-oriented events from any format into the direct variables that make up normalised events in the Convergent Billing database.  After processing by the DIL definition, the direct variables receive any other processing that may be defined in the normalised event file type.  The DIL built-in method decodes events in the specified format into the Convergent Billing direct variables that make up normalised events in the database.  The variables then receive any additional processing that may be defined in the normalised event file type.

pages.title: Data Records
pages.text: Convergent Billing stores three types of record for each database entity:  Current Record (the record with a start date before or equal to today and an end date equal to or after today).  One or more historical records (records with an end date before today).  One or more future records (records with a start date in the future).  Records of each type can be updated provided sufficient update privileges are available.  Update privileges required for types of update:  Type of Update  Privilege Required  Used To  Normal  Update  Update current and future records.  Historical Update  Update an historical record, or the current record and backdate the changes.  Date range  Date Range Update  Modify the date range of an historical record.  Convergent Billing supports two main types of update: normal and date range updates.  Type of Update  Used To  Normal  Update details of a specified record, but restricts movement of the start and end dates to within the date range specified for that record.  Date range  Modify the date range specified for a record (that is, start date and end date of a record can be moved.  Date range updates can only be performed using a history form.  Normal and date range updates to all record types (historical, current, and future) can be done, provided sufficient update privileges are available.  During day-to-day use of Convergent Billing, usually only current records need to be updated, and therefore only Update or Historical Update privileges are granted.

pages.title: Data Retrieval Functions
pages.text: Data retrieval functions are based on a table lookup using the ID of the item concerned (often obtained from a search function call).  In this case, the FieldNames$[] array is passed by value, and the other database arrays are passed by reference, so that the function can populate them with the required data.

pages.title: Data Types
pages.text:
A variable's data type can be either simple (for example, an integer or string) or composite (for example, an unknown hash or integer array). Simple variables can be of six data types: integer, real, string, date, blob (binary large object), and unknown. The EPM enforces strict typing, and the appropriate type declaration character must suffix variable names, as follows. Data Type Description Type Declaration Character Range INTEGER Equivalent to UNIX 'long'. Signed Integer. & -2,147,483,647 to 2,147,483,648 REAL Equivalent to UNIX 'double'. Floating point number. # (or none) -1.79 x 10308 to 1.79 x 10308 STRING Sequence of characters enclosed by single quotes. $ String size is limited only by the available memory. DATE Date and time. ~ 01 Jan 0001 00:00:00 to 30 Dec 9999 23:59:59
(24 hour time notation). BLOB Byte array. Maximum number of bytes is 232 –1. UNKNOWN Unknown scalar type. Values of any other scalar type may be assigned to a variable declared to be of this type. ? N/A If no type declaration character is appended to a variable name, the variable is assumed to be a Real value. The type declaration character forms part of the variable name; therefore, a$, a&, a#, and a~ are all distinct variables. In Convergent Billing, variables (except local variables) are subject to date ranging; this means that a variable has a start date and an end date, which together define the period for which the variable is applicable. Often the end date is not defined, which means that the variable is applicable indefinitely.

pages.title: Composite Data Types
pages.text:
Composite data types can be of two types: An array of scalar type A string hash of scalar type. The EPM enforces strict typing, so the appropriate type declaration character must suffix variable names. The following table lists examples. Data Type Description Type
Declaration
Character Examples ARRAY Order of sequence of elements of the declared type. Elements are stored and accessed using an integer 'index' value. The first element in an array has an index of 0. [ ] { var a&[], b?[];
a&[0] :=10;
b&[0] [0] :=10; HASH Unordered set of elements of the declared type. Elements are stored and accessed using a string 'key' value. Also known as an associative array. { } { var a&{}. b?{};
a&{'First'} :=10;
b&{'First'} [0] :=10;

pages.title: Date Ranging
pages.text: Date ranging is the mechanism for recording period-specific data for date-ranged entities (not all entities are date-ranged).  When a date-ranged entity is created, it is given an effective start date and an effective end date.  The dates define the period, or date range, for which data of the entity is effective and is represented as a date-range record.    The start date typically defaults to the current date and the end date is usually unspecified, signifying that the date range has no end.  Although an end date that spans to the end of time is displayed as blank, the field is recorded as the maximum date definable in the system (30-Dec-9999 23:59:59).  When an entity is updated, a number of different types of update can be performed depending on the user's access level.  The update usually applies to the current record (the date-range record that spans the current date).  The update sets the effective end date for the current record, closing that record, and a copy of the record with the specified changes is created with new start and end dates.    Security feature that determines what a user can do and what data they are permitted to access.  Security is based on form roles and groups, which in combination, determine a user's privileges.  Each user is assigned a specific profile that defines the level of access for each role and group.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Group, User, User Profile, and Form Role.  The start date defaults to the current date, and the end date is unspecified.  As a result of the update, the newly created date-ranged record is the current record, and the previous record is an historical record with a defined date range.  A user with the appropriate update access privilege can change an historical record (that is, backdate changes).  Update privileges required for types of update:  Type of Update  Privilege Required  Used To  Normal  Update  Update current and future records.  Historical Update  Update an historical record, or the current record and backdate the changes.  Date range  Date Range Update  Modify the date range of an historical record.  Over a period of time, an entity is likely to change a number of times.  For example, the contact person changes for a customer.  Each time an entity is updated, a new current record and another historical record are created.  The timespan of the entity is defined by contiguous date ranges that specify historical, current, and future versions of the data.  By creating date-range records, changes to an entity can be tracked, and the entity viewed as the entity exists at a specific point in time; that is, at an effective date.  The default granularity for date ranging is one day (date granularity).  That is, changes are recorded for specified effective start and end dates.  Some customer-related entities can support date ranging with a granularity of one second (date-time granularity).  For entities that support date-time granularity, the time can be specified for each of the effective start and end dates.  Date-time granularity allows Convergent Billing to reflect the status of an entity as it changes throughout a day.

pages.title: Date-time Granularity
pages.text: The granularity of specific date fields on a number of forms is configurable.  Date fields are treated as either a single component (date), or two components (date and time).  The granularity of the date fields is controlled by the Allow date range time granularity of less than one day check box, an access level setting for the form.    The finest granularity of the time component is one second.  If time granularity is disabled, the time defaults to 00:00:00 for start dates and 23:59:59 for end dates.   For more information on security, or form codes and the associated forms and fields controlled by the codes, refer to the Security and Auditing Configuration Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Debit and Credit Notes
pages.text: Debit and credit notes are represented by adjustments, and are maintained using the appropriate adjustment forms.  For example, use the Individual Adjustment form or the Adjustment Batch form to update a debit or credit note. Debit and credit notes are identified by an appropriate adjustment type.  The adjustment type is selected in the adjustment's Adjustment Type field of the appropriate adjustment form, and:  Specifies the format that controls content and layout of the printed note.  Enables additional fields for the adjustment, including the Image tab. The Image tab includes fields that indicate the processing status of the note; for example, if an image for printing has been generated or printed.  Individual notes can be generated or viewed using the Generate Image or View Image buttons on the Image tab of the Individual Adjustment form.  Notes can be generated or printed in bulk using tasks based on the Generate Adjustment Images and Print Adjustments schedule types.  Use the appropriate adjustment form to create, search, or view a debit or credit note.  More information about working with adjustments is available.

pages.title: Derived Attributes
pages.text: Derived attributes are used to derive a new variable based on the values of other variables.  Deriving new variables can be achieved using a simple expression, conditional evaluation (similar to functions), list evaluation type, or table lookup based on single, multiple, or range indexes.  Regardless of how it is derived, a derived attribute has the same basic properties as other variables and can be used in the same way.  In addition, however, a derived attribute possesses two further attributes: the Result Value Attribute Type and the Evaluation Type.  Specifies the mechanism used to derive the value returned by a derived attribute.  The value of the attribute is derived by evaluating one or more expressions, or by looking up the value in a predefined table of values.  If no value is derived, the value of a predefined default expression is used.  One of the following evaluation types can be specified:  Conditional:  Single Value Returned  Conditional:  Multiple Values Returned  List  Simple Expression  Table Lookup by Best Match  Table Lookup by Multiple (1-10) Keys  Table Lookup by Searching  Table Lookup by Single Range.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute, Conditional: Single Value Returned, Conditional: Multiple Values Returned, Lists, Simple Expression, Table Lookup by Best Match, Table Lookup by Multiple (1-10) Keys, and Table Lookup by Searching.  Specifies the data type of the result value returned by a derived attribute.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Attribute Type, Derived Attribute, and Result Value.  One of eight evaluation types can be specified:  Conditional: Multiple Values Returned  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Returns the value of the expression associated with each conditional expression that evaluates to TRUE.  The returned values are concatenated, separated by commas.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute and Evaluation Type.  Conditional: Single Value Returned  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Returns the value of the expression corresponding to the first conditional expression that evaluates to TRUE.  If none of the conditions evaluate to TRUE, the value of the specified default expression is returned.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute and Evaluation Type.  List  Derived attribute, with an evaluation type of List, can be used as a component of a product definition, customer type, or service type that defines the type of information to be held in an associated list.  The list defines a set of values that identify items having similar properties or uses (for example, frequently called numbers).  The values stored in the list are added in response to information obtained from the customer.  Generally this type of derived attribute is defined for special tariffs to be applied if one or more of the list items are matched during the rating process.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute and Evaluation Type.  Simple Expression  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Returns the value of a single expression; no other evaluation is performed.  Typically, this evaluation type is used to define a derived attribute from a direct variable.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute and Direct Variable.  Table Lookup by Best Match  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Table Lookup by Best Match allows up to ten indexes to be defined as the keys into the look-up table.  Any result value returned must match all of the indexes specified.    Table Lookup by Best Match compares the index expression with each predefined index value held in a table of values (known as a look-up table).  The best match (the value having the longest matching prefix) for the specified index is determined and the corresponding result value (also held in the look-up table) is returned.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute, Evaluation Type, Index Expression, Lookup Table, and Result Value.  Table Lookup by Multiple (1-10) Keys  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Table Lookup by Multiple allows up to ten indexes to be defined as the keys into the look-up table.  Any result value returned must match all of the indexes specified.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute, Evaluation Type, and Result Value.  Table Lookup by Searching  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Table Lookup by Searching allows up to ten indexes to be specified as the keys into the lookup table and supports population of wildcards.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute, Evaluation Type, Index Value, and Result Value.  Table Lookup by Single Range.  Evaluation type used to derive the value of a derived attribute.  Table Lookup by Single Range allows a single index expression to be defined as the key into a look-up table that contains one or more ranges of values.  When a table row is found with a range that includes the value of the index expression, the corresponding result value is returned.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Derived Attribute, Evaluation Type, and Result Value.  The value of the attribute is usually derived by evaluating one or more expressions or by looking up the value in a predefined table of values.  If no value is derived, the value of the specified default expression is used.  The name of a derived attribute must be unique for the date range of the function when compared to all other variables (for example, functions, derived attributes, subtotals, tariffs, and direct variables).    The rules for naming are:  For a scalar data type:   The name, data type, and interface number combination must be unique when compared to other functions.  The name and data type combination must be unique when compared to other (non-function) variables.  For a hash type, the name (excluding the data type) must be unique when compared to other hash type variables.  For an array type, the name (excluding the data type) must be unique when compared to other array type variables.  For more information about derived attributes, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Direct Variables
pages.text: A direct variable is a variable mapped to data held in a database table or to a column in a database view.  The value of the variable is determined by the context in which the variable is used. For example, each field of a normalised event record is mapped to a direct variable.  During normalisation of event data, each data field of a normalised event record is stored as a direct variable.  The variables into which the field values are mapped are defined specifically for the type of record being normalised.  Product Administrators do not need to know what these mappings are, but to know what direct variables are available.  For example, to define a usage tariff, call data information (for example, calling party ID, called party ID, and call duration) needs to be referenced.  Data information is stored in direct variables (for example, APartyId$, BPartyId$, and Duration#) when a call data record is normalised and is therefore available directly.  Direct variables therefore allow a field in a database record to be referenced, and the referenced value used in expressions.  Direct variables can also be used as the basis for other variable types.  If required, additional direct variables can be defined, which requires knowledge of SQL and the names and structure of the Convergent Billing database tables.  Like other variables, direct variables can be referenced in tariffs and subtotals by including the name of the variable.  Direct variables are always defined with an application environment of Data Entry.  Direct variables created during normalisation should usually cover most requirements.  However, if required, a direct variable can be defined.  This requires knowledge of the available Convergent Billing database tables and knowledge of SQL.  Specifically, a field/column in a database view needs to be identified by specifying a view name, column name, and column number.  The direct variable name must be unique for the date range of the direct variable when compared to all other variables (for example, functions, derived attributes, subtotals, tariffs, and direct variables).  The rules for naming are:  For a scalar data type, the name and data type combination must be unique when compared to other variables.  For a hash type, the name must be unique when compared to other hash type variables.  For an array type, the name must be unique when compared to other array type variables.

pages.title: Direct Variables Associated with Attribute Types
pages.text: Direct variables associated with attribute types are configured on the Integration tab of the Attribute Type Definition form.  The Variable Name field defines a direct variable that can be used to reference a derived non-stored attribute value in entity validation expressions.  Completing the Variable Name field automatically creates a direct variable with:  An application environment of Data Entry  A context of Any  Associated view names as appropriate for the entity.  Direct variables associated with attribute types can be viewed on the Variable Definition form, but cannot be updated.  They have no stored value, so the Column Name field is blank for these variables.

pages.title: Disconnection Procedures
pages.text: A connection between a remote source and the rating engine may be terminated at any time by one of the following methods:  The remote source closes the connection.  The rating engine closes the connection.  A network communications failure occurs.  A physical disconnection of either the remote source or the rating engine.  The remote source is required to attempt to re-establish the connection with the rating engine.  Any event record that is sent by the remote source, that was not acknowledged by the rating engine before the termination of the connection, is lost.  The remote source should re-transmit the event record once the connection is re-established.  A connection between the rating engine and a remote destination may be terminated at any time by one of the following methods:  The rating engine closes the connection.  The remote destination closes the connection.  A network communications failure occurs.  A physical disconnection of either the remote destination or the rating engine.  In the last three cases, the remote destination is required to resume waiting for a connection from the rating engine.  Any charges sent by the rating engine, which were not acknowledged by the remote destination before the termination of the connection, are re-transmitted once the connection with the remote destination is re-established.

pages.title: Disputes
pages.text: Disputes can be associated with an account or invoice and include any number of individual charge disputes.   Singleview provides support for:   Itemised disputes, allowing a list of individually-disputed items on an invoice or account to be associated with the dispute.   Non-itemised disputes, allowing an entire account or invoice to be associated with the dispute.  Account disputes are typically raised by prepaid customers, and includes billed or unbilled charges, whereas invoice disputes are typically raised by post paid customers following a receipt of an invoice.   Each dispute created can only contain disputed charges and events associated with a single account or invoice. Multiple disputes can be raised against an account or invoice if required.   The status of an invoice or account dispute cannot be changed after resolution.  Disputed amounts are not included in aged debt.

pages.title: ENM Configuration
pages.text: An ENM can be configured to process one of the following:   Events of a specified type from files on disk  Events from EventRateAndStore&() calls using named pipes  Real-time rating events from a local host using a named pipe connection.  If rental events are generated by the RGP, at least one ENM must be configured to process the rental events.  For more information, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Entitlements
pages.text: Entitlements are used in charging for products, and are time-based. They are associated with companion products used in product offers.  Entitlements can be one-off, recurring or dynamic.  Entitlements can be used to provide a service to a customer for a set period of time (for example, a discount service for three months).  Entitlements can also be set with no expiry date (for example, free minutes every month).  For example, if a customer has a companion product that provides 60 minutes of free call-time per month, and the first call made that month is a 70 minute call, they are only charged for the last 10 minutes, because the free minutes are consumed first.  Therefore, the recurring entitlement has an allocation (60 minutes) that is consumed, and the generated charge is less than it would normally be.  Entitlements are used by real-time charging, and are useful for pre-paid or post-paid accounts with credit limits. Singleview allows entitlements with real-time activation or recurring charges to be saved even if the account has insufficient funds.  For more information about entitlements, see the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Entity Saving Licence Checks
pages.text: When a user attempts to save an entity subject to licensing (that is, service instances, customer nodes, or customers), Convergent Billing checks the number of active entities against the licence.  The options are similar to those for user login.  That is, when the entity count is:  Below the warning level, the entity is saved.  Between the warning level and the licensed number, a warning message is displayed and the entity is saved.  Between the licensed number and the maximum level, a more strongly worded error message is displayed and the entity is saved.  Greater than the maximum level, the entity cannot be saved.  All saved entities are still available to this or any other user, even if new entities cannot be saved because the maximum level is reached.  The saving of entities is permitted again when the entity count falls below the licensed maximum.  Reducing the entity count might be achieved by archiving and purging redundant entities or by negotiating variations in the licence with CSG International.

pages.title: Entity Validation
pages.text: Entity validation is the key to extensively configuring the customer care environment of Convergent Billing to look and perform as required. Entity validation provides control over what information is captured by a user, and how it is captured. This is achieved by adding and removing fields from generic Convergent Billing forms, customising generic Convergent Billing fields, and adding field security, field validation, intelligent defaulting, and context-sensitive help.  Entity validation can tailor an entity's data model for integration with external systems. Non-stored attributes that are derived from an entity's stored attributes can be added, external aliases for attributes can be assigned, and the sets of key attributes that identify an entity instance can be configured.   Reference types, attribute types, and key field functions are components for entity validation. Customising a field using entity validation involves associating an attribute type with that field. Configuring the keys that identify an entity instance requires specification of new key field functions.  Customising fields includes adding new fields.  The customer care forms include a General tab, which contains invisible general fields that can be customised to become visible.  The attribute type defines many of the changes to the field such as whether it is based on a reference type, its format, characteristics, hint text, context-sensitive help, field security, field external alias, field validation, and field defaults (more extensive validation and field defaults can be set up within entity validation). The attribute also specifies the addition and defines the derivation of non-stored attributes.  After associating an attribute type with a field, the field can be customised further by entity validation. Fields can also be defined to change their characteristics or default values based on a value entered in a separate field.  An attribute type can be added to entity validation without a corresponding form field if it defines a derived non-stored attribute.  For more information on entity validation, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Entity Validation Features
pages.text: Entity validation is used to:  Customise generic Convergent Billing fields (including general fields) by associating attribute types to fields.  Configure a component by associating it to an attribute type that has the appropriate security settings, such as field encryption or masking.    Configure additional fields to be displayed only when the user (see Control Next Feature) selects a specific option (in a separate field).  Configure fields to change their characteristics when the user selects a specific option (in a separate field) (see Control Next Feature).  Define one or more expressions to populate a field with a default value (see Default Expressions).  Configure a field so that its initial value is defaulted automatically based on the data entered in a separate field (see Control Next Feature).  Define validation expressions and post-commit expressions to validate user actions, display information messages to the user, and to execute actions when a function is performed.  Add context-sensitive help to new or customised fields, or change the context-sensitive help associated with a generic Convergent Billing field by associating an attribute type that has the appropriate help entry definition linked to it.  Customise an entity's data model by adding derived non-stored attributes.  Define new key field functions for entity lookup and key validation.   Create validation expressions that define the decomposition of derived non-stored attributes into store attributes.

pages.title: Control Next Feature
pages.text: The Control Next feature is used to define intelligent defaulting and to configure fields to automatically change their configuration based on a value selected in another field.  For example, Control Next is used to configure the following scenarios if a user selects an option in one field:  More information is required based on that selection.  An additional field, used to enter further information, is displayed.    The characteristics of another field are inappropriate for the option selected, so the characteristics of the field are automatically modified.  The Control Next feature does not work on grids, except for derived attribute grids where child reference types are used.    Changing the configuration of fields based on the data entered in a separate field is achieved by allowing the attribute type assigned to one field to control the attribute type assigned to another field.    If the Control Next field (in an entity validation definition row) is set to Yes, the attribute type in that row has control over the attribute type in the row directly below it.  Depending on how the attribute types are set up, the Control Next feature can have the following effects:  If the controlling attribute type is based on a reference type that has a child attribute type associated with one of its reference items, that child attribute type overrides the attribute type in the next row when that reference item is selected.    The result is that the second field changes its configuration when an option is selected from the first field.  To display a new field on the form when an option is selected, an attribute type defining an invisible (or null) field must be defined.  The attribute type defining the blank field is then overridden and the new field is displayed.  If the controlling attribute is based on a reference type that has a child reference type associated with one of its reference items, that child reference type overrides any reference type specified in the attribute type in the next row when that reference item is selected.    The result is that the second field changes its reference list (drop-down list) when an option is selected in the first field.  Child reference types are supported only in derived attribute grids; they are not supported in other grids with entity validation.    For example, they are supported in the Derived Attribute Table form, Customer Lists, and Service Lists; they are not supported in the Payment Batch form, Adjustment Batch form, Customer Invoice Format form, and Customer Contacts form.  If the field being controlled has a default expression defined, that expression is evaluated when the field associated with the first attribute type is modified.  The above setup is used to define intelligent defaulting (automatically defaulting the value of a field based on data entered in a separate field).

pages.title: Default Expressions
pages.text: The default expression in entity validation can execute almost any action; for example, assigning a default to a field, and printing a message.  To define a default for a field, the expression must contain the direct variable for the field referenced in the expression.  For example, to define a default of ‘500’ for the General 4 field of the Customer Detail form, the entity validation defining that field would contain the following default expression:  evCustGeneral4$ := ’500’;  where   evCustGeneral4$ is the direct variable for the General 4 field on the Customer Detail form.  Direct variables from both the validation table or parent table can be included in default expressions.  Contains variables that can be used in the default expression of an entity validation definition.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Entity Validation and Validation Table.  Table used within entity validation that contains a group of generic fields, including general fields, which can be customised.  Each table represents a specific area such as accounts, addresses, adjustments, and so on.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Entity Validation and Parent Table.

pages.title: Post-commit Expressions
pages.text: Post-commit expressions are used to display messages to the user or to execute actions after a form is saved and the data committed to the database.  For example, a post-commit expression can be used to add the name of the record created to the message window that informs the user that changes have been made successfully.  Post-commit expressions are evaluated after the transaction is committed to the database, so if the post-commit expression fails, the transaction is not rolled back.  Therefore, post-commit expressions should not be used as validation expressions in circumstances where failure of the expression means the transaction should not be committed.

pages.title: Validation Expressions
pages.text: Validation expressions are used to validate user actions by displaying information messages or error messages to the user, or by executing actions.    Two different types of form validation can be defined:  Row validation, which is used to validate user actions when a form is saved, but before the data is committed to the database; its main purpose is to validate individual rows.  If the entity being validated is in a list, row validation is executed when moving away from a row that was edited.  Pre-commit validation, which is used to validate user actions when the form is saved, but before the data is committed to the database; its main purpose is to ensure that all entries in the form are valid as a group.  For example, a specific field may become mandatory as a result of completing another field.  Pre-commit validation also validates the rows included in grids.  When data is inserted or updated by an external system using the Entity Validation Server (EVS) interface, the validation expressions are executed by the EVS.  In this context, validation expressions can define mapping expressions for derived non-stored attributes that integrate Convergent Billing with external systems.  For more information about the EVS, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).

pages.title: Key Field Functions
pages.text: Key field functions are executed on sets of keys supplied by external systems to the Entity Validation Server (EVS).  The validation function returns true when supplied valid with keys that identify an instance of the entity that is the subject of the EVS function.  The entity lookup function returns the primary identifiers of a matching entity instance based on the supplied keys.  Key field functions allow the keys that identify entity instances to be configured. When used in conjunction with attribute types, the data model of an entity can be tailored for integration with external systems.   When a key field function is specified for an entity validation, all entity validations with the same validation table must share the must reference the same function or have no function specified.  For more information about key field function implementation and default behaviour refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).

pages.title: EPM to Java Type Mapping
pages.text: EPM parameters do not map directly to Java parameters.  The Java parameters occur in the same order, but have different types.  The mapping also depends on whether parameters are available; this is indicated by the var keyword before the parameter name.  The return type is mapped as a non-variable parameter.  EPM functions, whose parameters are of type unknown, must have appropriate overloaded Java functions for all basic types (blob, date, integer, real, and string).  If the EPM function has several parameters of type unknown, Java functions for all permutations of the five basic types for those parameters of type unknown must be written.    The following table lists EPM type to Java type mappings.  EPM to Java Type Mapping  EPM Type  Java Type for Non-variable Parameters  Java Type for Variable Parameters  Blob  com.adc.eji.tre.Blob  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarBlob  BlobArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  BlobHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  Date  java.util.Date  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarDate  DateTimeArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  DateTimeHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  Integer  java.lang.Long  If useInteger is set to True at factory creation, java.lang.Integer is used.  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarLong  If useInteger is set to True at factory creation, com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarInteger is used.  IntegerArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  IntegerHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  Real  java.lang.Double  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarDouble  RealArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  RealHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  String  java.lang.String  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarString  StringArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  StringHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  Unknown  java.lang.Object  com.adc.eji.tre.TreVarUnknown  UnknownArray  java.util.List  java.util.List  UnknownHash  java.util.Map  java.util.Map  The -h option can be used to suppress sensitive information from being output to debug or trace files.  If this option is specified when using the static interface, all string and string reference objects are assumed to contain sensitive information, and are wrapped in TRE_HIDDEN objects.  If a particular hash or array element needs to be hidden, then the caller must wrap the element in a TRE_HIDDEN object before calling the static interface.  When a parameter is hidden in this way, a mask of six asterisks ('******') is output to debug or trace files instead of the parameter's value.  No unwrapping of TRE_HIDDEN is required; the Java API automatically unwraps any TRE_HIDDEN objects returned to it.

pages.title: Equipment
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, equipment is regarded as the physical and/or logical component required to provide a service.    Components are of two types:  Physical (items that can be seen and touched), including handsets, SIM cards, and leased lines.  Logical (components that have identifiable characteristics, but do not exist in a physical form), including service numbers, International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI) numbers, and Mobile Subscriber ISDN (MSISDN) numbers.  Equipment details are stored in the Convergent Billing equipment inventory.  When these details are recorded, a specific item of equipment can be allocated to a service.  Equipment items can be configured using equipment types so that they belong to specific equipment pools.  The use of equipment pools allows the allocation of equipment items to be more tightly controlled.  Convergent Billing provides two methods in which equipment details can be recorded in the equipment inventory:  Individually  In bulk.  Entering equipment in bulk has the advantage of faster data entry, but is suitable only for items of equipment having the same equipment type and sequential service or network numbers.  The same two methods are provided to update equipment details.

pages.title: Example
pages.text: To obtain the make, model, status, and purchase date of a piece of equipment with EQUIPMENT_ID=13364, the following code could be used:  var FieldName$[0]:='MAKE';  var FieldName$[1]:='model';  var FieldName$[2]:='EQUIPMENT_STATUS_CODE';  var FieldName$[3]:='PURCHASE_DATE';  var StringFieldValues$[];  var IntegerFieldValues&[];  var RealFieldValues#[];  var DateFieldValues~[];  var rv&:=0;  rv&=biEquipmentFetchById&(13364, current_date( ), FieldNames$[ ],  StringFieldValues$[ ], IntegerFieldValues&[ ], RealFieldValues#[ ],  DateFieldValues~[ ]);  The required values are returned in the field values arrays.

pages.title: Equipment Types
pages.text: A service offered to a customer generally requires one or more items of equipment for the service to be used (for example, SIM card for a mobile phone).  Like service types, it is recommended that the type of equipment required be defined generically rather than defining specific manufacturer's components, which can change, become unavailable, or be superseded.  The details of equipment available for allocation to a customer are held in the Convergent Billing inventory, and it is from this list of equipment to allocate to a service offering is selected.  The equipment type associated with the specified service type only defines the type of equipment to be selected; the user selects the equipment of the specified equipment type to be used.  If configured to do so, the number of a service can be assigned based on the physical equipment used to provide the service.  The service number is typically based on the serial number of the equipment, but if the equipment also has a network address, the service number can be based on that.  The network address of the service can also be derived from the equipment serial number or network address.  The mechanism by which numbers are generated is defined under a series of conditions.  The defaulting facility for numbers in relation to the equipment/service type are provided in the product definition.  An example of a Service Number expression provides additional information on this process.  To define a service type or product, it is only necessary to define the equipment type to be used; it is not necessary to record the physical equipment to be used because it has no bearing on how the product is defined or rated.  The physical equipment to be used is specified in a separate procedure.

pages.title: Number Generation Mechanism
pages.text: The fields on the Encoding/Decoding tab are used to enter expressions to encode and decode equipment serial numbers and/or network addresses.  In each case, the make, model, and subtype codes of the equipment can be used in the expression.  The expressions for encoding and decoding must have a decoded serial number or network address of the same length.  The encode and decode fields for serial numbers are enabled only if the Allow ranges of equipment? option on the Settings tab is selected.  The encode expression defines the method by which to generate the serial number for each piece of equipment based on a single unique number (defined as a local variable, @value$) as input.  The expression returns the serial number as a string.  The decode expression defines the method by which to generate a unique number from the equipment's serial number.  The serial number is defined as the local variable @value$.  The Encode and Decode fields for the Network Address are enabled only if the Equipment has network address? option and the Allow Ranges of Equipment? check box on the Settings tab is selected.  The encode expression defines the method by which to generate the network address of the device based on a single unique number (defined as a local variable @value$) as input.  The expression returns the network address as a string.  The decode expression defines the method by which to generate a unique number from the equipment's network address.  The network address is defined as the local variable @value$.

pages.title: Number Expression Examples
pages.text: Serial Number  Encode Expression  ‘ABC-GSM-‘ + to_string(@value$,’000’)  Decode Expression  to_long(substr(@value$,8,3))  Network Address  Encode Expression  ‘ABC-GSM-NA-‘ + to_string(@value$,’000’)  Decode Expression  to_long(substr(@value$,11,3))

pages.title: Equivalent Interfaces
pages.text: Two functions have equivalent interfaces if all of the following four points are true:  The two functions have the same name (excluding return type).  The two functions have one of the following:  The same return type  One of the functions returns an unknown array and the other function returns an array of any type.  One of the functions returns an unknown hash and the other function returns a hash of any type.  The two functions have the same number of parameters.  Each corresponding parameter has one of the following:  The same type (ignoring pass-by-reference of constant settings).  One parameter is of type unknown and the corresponding parameter is of any non-composite (array or hash) type (and both parameters are not pass-by-reference).  One parameter is of type integer and the corresponding parameter is of type real (and both parameters are not pass-by-reference).  One parameter is of type unknown array and the corresponding parameter is of any array type (and both parameters are not pass-by-reference).  One parameter is of type unknown hash and the corresponding parameter is of any hash type (and both parameters are not pass-by-reference).

pages.title: Event Rating Output (ERO) Configuration
pages.text: Convergent Billing needs to have one ERO process configured for each ENM, with all data sent directly to the database.  The OUTPUT_METHOD parameter should be set to 'direct'.  For more information, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Configuring an ERO to output normalised events and charges to a remote host using a TCP/IP socket or to SQL*Loader files is deprecated and only provided for backward compatibility.

pages.title: Event Rating (ERT) Configuration
pages.text: Convergent Billing only needs to have a single ERT process configured to rate and store normalised events.  However, for performance reasons, additional ERT processes can be configured.    For more information, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Event Rating Broker (BKR)
pages.text: The Event Rating Broker (BKR) process manages the rating engine by controlling the ENM, ERT, and ERO child processes.  BKR startup  When it is started, the BKR process (with its CACHE_START configuration attribute set to 1) creates inter-process communication mechanisms for ENM, ERT, and ERO processes.  The BKR process then starts all the configured ENM, ERT, and ERO processes that have the ENABLED configuration attribute for each process set to TRUE.  If the CACHE_START configuration attribute is set to 1, the BKR process creates the service, customer node, account, rating subtotal, and temporal entitlement caches for the instance.  The BKR retrieves configuration details for the caches from the SERVICE_CACHE, CUSTOMER_CACHE, ACCOUNT_CACHE, SUBTOTAL_CACHE, and ENTITLEMENT_CACHE configuration items.  For single-instance environments, the BKR retrieves the configuration items for each cache with a sequence number of 1.  For multi-instance environments, the BKR retrieves the configuration items with the matching instance name based on the INSTANCE base attribute.  The event cache is started for each BKR process, regardless of the status of the CACHE_START configuration attribute.  The EVENT_CACHE configuration item used is based on the sequence number of the BKR.  BKR processing  The BKR manages the transmission of commands between the ENM, ERT and ERO processes.  If all rating engine processes are running on one machine, the BKR monitors the other processes and passes external commands to them.  If the ENM, ERT, and ERO processes are distributed over a number of machines, the BKR also acts as a message-passing intermediary between them.  The inter-process mechanisms created by the BKR process are used to transmit normalised events from ENM processes to ERT processes for rating, and to transmit normalised events, charges, and details of normalised event files to an ERO process for output.  Multiple BKR processes can exist for each Convergent Billing instance.  Each ENM process on the same machine as the BKR requires three semaphores, each ERT process requires three, and each ERO process requires five.

pages.title: Expressions
pages.text: The expressions defined in Convergent Billing (see the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing) consist of operators and variables that when evaluated return a single value.  The Expression Parser Module (EPM) which provides a set of built-in functions for both parsing and evaluating an expression performs the evaluation of expressions.  Expressions are used in Convergent Billing to:  Determine which tariff to apply.  Define and calculate tariffs.  Perform table lookup.  Validate raw event records as they are normalised.  Validate data entered by a user.  Define functions, derived attributes, and define subtotals.  Substitute values in an invoice template.  An expression can be defined whenever it is required.  When defining a tariff or subtotal and where a set of conditions or eligibility criteria need to be evaluated, an expression needs to be defined.  Expressions can be used in combination so that the result of one expression is used as input to another expression.  The Expression Test form can be used to validate expressions.  Operators can be arithmetic or relational.  Any type of variable can be used in an expression (direct variables, functions, derived attributes, tariffs, subtotals, and list types).  A variable can only be used in an expression, if it is the correct data type, has the correct syntax, and has the correct application environment.  The following expression types are available in Convergent Billing:  Control Expressions  Expression used to control the flow of processing using conditions.  A condition is an expression that returns 0 or 0.0 when the condition is FALSE, or a non-zero number if the condition is TRUE.  The condition need not be a conditional expression, formed by using conditional operators.  The following control expressions can be used:  if-then-else  if  while  try-except  for.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Expression and Expression Type.  Variable Definition Expressions  Used to define a local variable.  The scope of the variable begins when it is defined, and lasts to the end of the current expression block or function.  The variable can be assigned a value as it is declared.  Within its scope, this type of variable takes precedence over any other variable of the same name.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Expression and Expression Type.  Single Expressions.  Assignment, variable, function call, value, or two variables linked by an operator.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Expression and Expression Type.

pages.title: Operators
pages.text: Convergent Billing supports the following operators:  Arithmetic  Logical  Bitwise  Conditional.

pages.title: External Definition
pages.text: External definitions are a key component of the interface between Singleview and external systems. External definitions define the details of the data structure and the fields that must be supplied either to or from an external system, and how they map to Singleview entities and their fields.  External definitions do not include specific details on transport or encoding mechanisms.  These details are defined in a separate layer specific to the type of interface that is using the external definitions.  External definitions can map to a Convergent Billing entity or a Process Engine class; these are concrete external definitions. An external definition not mapped to a Convergent Billing entity or Process Engine class is an abstract definition.  External definitions generated from an abstract definition are automatically mapped to the Convergent Billing entity or Process Engine class of a parent definition.  External definitions can also be linked to create complex structures combining details from multiple entities.  Entities can be different, or belong to the same type (for example, customers and child customers). These are referred to as nested external definitions.  [[FigureXref:52455-1]] displays how external definitions link to create a nested external definition.  [[Figure:52455-1]]  Nested External Definition  XML Schema terminology has been adopted for representing components of an external definition. Terminology includes:  Namespace  Attributes  Elements  Content models (Simple Content, Sequence, Choice, and All).  External definitions are created and maintained in the External Definition form.    External definitions support combinations of the following basic operations on their underlying Convergent Billing or Process Engine entities:  Insert   Update   Delete   Search   Fetch.  To simplify the creation of external definitions, they can be generated:  For a Convergent Billing entity (using an entity validation)  For a Process Engine class  From XML schema files.  The generated external definition can be customised to suit requirements of the external interface that is to use it, and it can also be nested.  For more information about external definitions, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: External Definition Namespace
pages.text: An external definition namespace is an XML namespace used to create a logical grouping for a set of external definitions.  The namespace is given a name (usually a URI), which guarantees all external definitions that are members of the group are uniquely identifiable.   The namespace has an associated prefix that is applied to member names so that external definitions with the same names, but different contexts, can coexist without interfering with one another.  The association between an external definition and an external definition namespace is managed by settings on the external definition.  External definition namespaces with associated external definitions cannot be deleted.

pages.title: Facility Groups
pages.text: Facility groups are not compatible with product offers.  When a service instance is created as part of an overall product package, one or more service options can be included.  For example, if a GSM mobile phone service is included as part of the product package to a business customer, customer might also be offered Call Waiting and Call Diversion as service options.  In Convergent Billing, a service option is referred to as a facility.  Facilities can be offered individually or in combination, but must be offered as part of a service option package, more commonly referred to in Convergent Billing as a facility group.  A facility group must contain at least one facility.    Facilities cannot be added to a product directly; they can only be defined in a facility group and are commonly regarded as attributes of the service instance to which they apply.  A facility is defined and stored in the Convergent Billing database as a reference type of type 'FACILITY'.  In addition to facilities, a facility group can include one or more compatible facility groups that can be used in conjunction with (configured with) the current facility group.  In addition to determining the number, content, and compatibility of the facility groups to be provided, whether those facility groups are to be selected automatically by Convergent Billing when the service is created or selected manually must also be determined.  If automatic facility group selection is specified, the user has no control over the facility groups associated with the service they are creating.  If manual facility group selection is specified, the user can decide on whether to select a specific facility group for the service they are creating.  This decision is usually based on what the customer has requested.

pages.title: Tips for Designing Facility Groups
pages.text: When designing a facility group, careful consideration is required about which facilities to include, because incorrectly packaging facilities may prove to be too inflexible for customer requirements.  For example, a facility group that includes both Call Waiting and Call Diversion as facilities is defined.  When this option is offered to a customer, that customer only has the choice of accepting the whole facility group (that is, they accept both facilities) or rejecting the facility group (in which case they get neither facility).    The solution in this case is to create two facility groups, each containing a single facility.

pages.title: File Processing Manager (FPM)
pages.text: The File Processing Manager (FPM) maintains a register that records information about:  Files that are extracted from or loaded into Singleview  File processing statistics.    The FPM manages the interaction between Singleview and the local file system.  The FPM is responsible for:  Registering and updating file detail records  Controlling file logic to generate the file name from configuration  Managing file locations on local file systems  Moving files between different directories  Preventing duplication at file and audit level  Recording statistics of processed files (for example, input records, output records, error records, and skipped records)  Interacting with batch file processing to support batch extraction and loading with processing statistics.  For more information about the FPM, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Financial Capabilities
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides the following accounting functions:  Customer account management, including maintaining customer account balances and history.  Accounts Receivable (A/R) sub-ledger.  Sales and Cash Receipts Journal (in Singleview, referred to as a Sales Journal), including revenue recognition (revenue, accrued revenue, and deferred revenue).  Convergent Billing processes affecting Convergent Billing accounts and the Sales Journal are:  Rating  Billing  Payment processing  Adjustment processing.  When a transaction occurs during any of these processes, Convergent Billing records the effects of that transaction on both the internal Convergent Billing customer account balance and history, and the general ledger accounts (for later processing by the Sales Journal posting process).   When the Sales Journal posting process is run, transactions from rating, billing, payments, and adjustments are aggregated.  Aggregation is based on transaction type (for example, invoice or payment) and debit and credit GL codes, and an entry made in the Sales Journal.  Convergent Billing determines the GL code for:  Normalised event file and invoice transactions, during the Sales Journal posting process, using a process known as GL guidance.  Payment and adjustment transactions, when the payment or adjustment is applied.   At the end of an accounting period, the Sales Journal entries are aggregated and uploaded to the external general ledger system.  For more information about GL guidance, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.  Related Topics  General Ledger Guidance Entity  General Ledger Guidance Function  Sales and Cash Receipts Journal

pages.title: Forms
pages.text: Forms are used to enter data into the Convergent Billing database and to display data held in the Convergent Billing database.  Each form contains a number of fields, in which data can be entered or displayed, and one or more function buttons used to access other forms or that perform a specific operation.  In addition to function buttons, some forms also contain controls (for example, option groups and option check boxes) for selecting one or more options.  Option groups represent options that are mutually exclusive (that is, only one of the available options can be selected).  Option check boxes can be selected independently and therefore either one or both of the available options can be selected.  When first displayed, some fields contain default values.  Either accept these values, or enter new values.  Each data entry field can be mandatory or optional; mandatory fields must be completed before the form can be saved.  Mandatory fields can be represented by a different font or background colour by modifying User Preferences in Convergent Billing.  For example, the field label could be emphasised by bold, italic, or underlined text.  The field background colour can also be modified to emphasise the mandatory fields.  Some fields may be disabled.  Such fields are identified by their labels being greyed out.  A field may be disabled, either because it is a display-only field, or because information cannot be entered into this field (or data in this field selected) at the present time.  When a large amount of information is required to create a specific type of database entity, fields are grouped and displayed on a number of tab dividers (more commonly referred to as tabs), each tab containing fields that relate to a specific area of information.  Tabs may themselves contain other tabs.  A form can be displayed in one of three form modes, the mode being determined by how the form is accessed.  Facilities are provided to manually change the mode in which a form is displayed.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  Multiple forms can be displayed at the same time; only one form is active (has input focus) at any one time.  The active form is commonly referred to as the current form.  Facilities are provided to save, cancel, close, and manipulate (move, resize, minimise, and maximise) the current form.

pages.title: Functions
pages.text: A function is a specialised variable that takes zero or more parameters as input and returns a single value as output.  A function has the same basic properties as other variables (Name, Start Date, End Date, Description, Data type, Context, and Application Environment), but also includes properties specific to functions (for example, function definitions).  Syntax  Parameters  Calls.  In Convergent Billing, expressions and functions are similar, in that both process code to return a value, and both are evaluated by the EPM.  The difference between them is that a function is passed zero or more parameters.  Functions in Convergent Billing are similar to functions in other programming languages as they can:  Assign a name to a sequence of one or more expressions.   Be called and executed when required; for example, to validate a service number, a sequence of checks on an entered value must be performed.  Because the sequence of steps is required in more than one place, a function can be written to identify the sequence of steps and give the sequence of steps a name.  The function can then be called from multiple places within Convergent Billing.  The following types of function are available.  Type  Description  EPM built-in  Intrinsic part of EPM (for example, abs()).  EPM built-in functions are executed by the EPM parser within the current process.  EPM callback  EPM extensions built into various processes and TRE servers.  EPM callback functions are specific to particular server or client processes and execute locally within the specific process, if available in that process.  User-defined  Written using EPM (may be supplied with Convergent Billing or user created).  User-defined functions invoked by a remote function call can be called by external applications using the TRE Application Programming Interface (API).    Transaction Engine (TRE) Application Programming Interface (API).  The API provides the interface between the TRE and a remote host in the form of TRE function calls for the following programming languages:  C  Object Pascal  Perl  Java.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Transaction Engine.  Functions can be defined to execute locally or remotely:  Local execution occurs in the context of, or local to, the function caller (for example, the client or a TRE server).  Remote execution takes place outside the context of, or remote from, the function caller.    Remote execution occurs in a server of the TRE that is advertising the Tuxedo service associated with the function.    For more information about functions and function definition, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: EPM Function Syntax
pages.text: The syntax for defining a function is:  FunctionName  <T>([param1<T1>, param2<T2>, …, paramN<Tn>]) = FunctionBody  where:  FunctionName  Name for the function.  Excluding all return type characters, the name can have a length of up to 64 characters.  The first character of a function name must be an upper or lower case letter or the '_' character.  Subsequent characters can also include numbers, and the '.' and ':' characters.  The name must be unique for the date range of the function when compared to all other variables (for example, functions, derived attributes, subtotals, tariffs, and direct variables).  The rules for naming are:  For a scalar data type:   The name, data type, and interface number combination must be unique when compared to other functions.  The name and data type combination must be unique when compared to other (non-function) variables.  For a hash type, the name (excluding the data type) must be unique when compared to other hash type variables.  For an array type, the name (excluding the data type) must be unique when compared to other array type variables.  <T>  Type declaration character that indicates the type of data the function returns.  A <T> in a documented function name, instead of a return character, indicates that more than one function exists with this function name, each having a different return type.  (param1  <T1>, ..)  A function may take zero or more parameters.  The parentheses ( ) are always required, even if no parameters are passed.  The parameter type is indicated by the <Tn> character.  If a function is documented as:  MyFunction  &(const param1$, const param2<T>)  at least two functions exist with the name MyFunction&, but with different interfaces (that is, overloaded).  The description for param2<T> gives the possible parameter types.  FunctionBody  Expression block.  The data type returned by the final expression to be evaluated (either the last expression in the function or the expression immediately following the optional return keyword) must match the function's return type.  The function's return type is defined by the function's type declaration character.    Example  Functions can be overloaded.

pages.title: Example
