pages.text: The following function returns a minimum (flag-fall) charge for a call of less than 60 seconds duration, or the minimum charge plus a charge for each additional six seconds for longer calls:  ChargeExpression1# (Period  &, MinCharge#,   Add6Sec#) =  {  If Period  & = 0 then return 0.0;  If Period  & <= 60 then return MinCharge#   else return MinCharge# + ceil((Duration  &  -  60)/6) * Add6Sec#;  }  The above function uses ceil(), an EPM built-in function that returns the next whole number above the Real value passed to it.

pages.title: Function Parameters
pages.text: Function parameters can be passed in the following ways:  By value  As a constant value  By reference.  When a parameter is passed by value, the function receives a copy of the parameter; any change the function makes to this value does not affect the value of the parameter outside the function.  When a function parameter is preceded by the const keyword, it is treated as a constant and the function body is not allowed to modify its value.  Constants defined in a function can be made available to other functions or expressions using the import command.    When a parameter is passed by reference, the function has access to the original variable, and can change it.   A complete array is passed as a parameter (by value or by reference) by specifying the array name (including its base type), followed by square brackets ('[]').  Similarly, a complete hash is passed as a parameter by specifying the hash name (including its base type) followed by braces ('{}').  Only variables can be passed by reference.

pages.title: Function Calls
pages.text: Example  var result#;  result# := ChargeExpression1#(ceil(Duration#),   15.00, 2.15);  In this example Duration# is a direct variable based on the NORMALISED_EVENT_V view.  The application environment for this call must therefore be Rating, and the context must be Normalised Event.  The call to the ceil() EPM built-in function is required because the function is defined with the Period& parameter of type Integer.  A function call requires the statement of the function name, followed by any parameters in brackets.  The name and data type of the function must be compatible with those in the function definition, and the data types of any parameters passed must be compatible with those of the formal parameters in the function definition.  The number of parameters passed must match the number of parameters defined for the function.  For each corresponding parameter:  If the parameter is defined to be passed-by-reference (var prefix), the passed parameter must be a variable or non-constant function parameter of the same data type as the defined parameter.  If the parameter is defined to be passed-by-value (no prefix) or a constant (const prefix), the following applies:  The passed parameter must be an expression returning the same data type as the defined parameter.  If the defined parameter is defined to be of a real data type, the passed parameter can be an expression returning an integer value.  If the defined parameter is defined to be of type unknown (? suffix), the passed parameter must be an expression returning any scalar type.  If the defined parameter is defined to be of type unknown array (?[] suffix), the passed parameter must be an expression returning any array type.  If the defined parameter is defined to be of type unknown hash (?{} suffix), the passed parameter must be an expression returning any hash type.  Calling functions in a way that violates these guidelines is not supported.  Using parameters incorrectly can result in arbitrary or undefined behaviour; for example, the program may stop, exit, or produce unexpected or meaningless results.  To ensure that parameters behave correctly:  Pass parameters by reference, value, and constant as follows:  pass-by-reference parameters (var prefix) when the function modifies the parameter and the modified value is required by the function caller.    Pass-by-value (no parameter prefix) when the function modifies the value but the modified value is not required by the function caller.  Pass-by-constant (const prefix) when the function does not modify the parameter value.  Do not pass a hash or array by reference, and elements from the hash or array by reference or constant into the same function call.  For example, the FuncUpdate&(var Details?{}, var ServiceName$, var FunctName$) function called as follows could result in arbitrary or undefined behaviour:  {      var lData?{};      .      .      .      FuncUpdate&(lData?{}, lData${'SERVICE'}, lData${'FUNCTION'})  }  If a variable is set to an element of an array or hash using the equivalence operator (::=), the array or hash values must not be cleared, undefined, or reassigned while the variable is still in scope.  For example:  var x?[] := ['Text', 'Goobaa', ['a', 'b', 'c'], 10];  var a?{} := ['a', 1, 'b', 2, 'c', 3, 'rows', 4];  a?{'rows'}[] := x?[];  var b?[] ::= a?{'rows'}[2][];  undefine(a?{'rows'});  # Array referenced by b?[] has been freed.  # The following assignment causes a runtime error or undefined behaviour:  b?[2] := 's';

pages.title: Function Overloading
pages.text: Singleview supports the overloading of user-defined and registered functions.  A function is overloaded if the same function name and return type are used by more than one function.  Functions with the same name and return type can have different interface numbers, if the EPM parsing engine can determine which interface should be called in any given expression.  Such differentiation is guaranteed if the interfaces of the two functions are not equivalent.  The documentation for an overloaded function lists the separate interfaces in the syntax of that function.  For example:  MyFunction  &(a$, c$)  MyFunction  &(a$, b&, d&)  An overloaded function is called, like any other function, using the function name, return type, and the appropriate parameters.  For example:  MyFunction  &(a, b, d);  The EPM parser tries to determine the appropriate function to call by using a trial-and-error approach.  The parser tries each overloaded function until one is found that parses successfully.  If none of the functions are successful, the syntax error for the last function tried is returned.  Overloaded functions are identified in Configuration Studio by an interface number.

pages.title: General Ledger Codes
pages.text: Each account in a general ledger has an identifier known as a general ledger (GL) code (sometimes known as an account code).  A GL code is usually alphanumeric and typically composed of a number of segments, with each segment identifying an entity involved in transactions recorded against the account.  GL codes are typically structured in a hierarchy that enables creation of financial reports.    Convergent Billing uses GL codes to map transactions (for example, normalised events, and payments if GL functionality is enabled) to the appropriate account, or accounts, in the external GL system.  GL codes can be defined in a hierarchy, if required, to suit reporting requirements.  The GL codes in the hierarchy used when uploading to the external GL system must match the GL codes used by the external GL system.  Related Topic  Account Class.

pages.title: General Ledger Guidance
pages.text: GL guidance is the term used in Convergent Billing to describe the process of determining the GL codes (and those accounts in the external general ledger system) affected by a transaction to allow revenue recognition over time.  GL guidance allows the GL codes affected by a transaction to be determined when the Sales Journal posting process is run.  GL guidance is only used for normalised event and invoice transactions and not for payment and adjustment transactions.  GL guidance entities for a transaction are determined by the configurable GL guidance function.  The GL guidance entities are associated with transactions, which define the GL codes affected by a transaction.  GL guidance records are used to maintain a running history of the transactions that affect GL codes.  The history is later used during the Sales Journal posting process.  For more information about GL guidance, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.  Related Topics  Financial Capabilities  General Ledger Guidance Entity  General Ledger Guidance Function  Sales and Cash Receipts Journal

pages.title: General Ledger Guidance Entity
pages.text: General ledger (GL) guidance entities map charges associated with normalised event file and invoice transactions to the affected GL codes in the Sales Journal.  GL guidance entities define the GL codes affected by a specific type of transaction.  The GL codes affected by a transaction differ depending on the type of transaction and whether the transaction results in accrued, actual, deferred, or earned revenue.   GL guidance entities must be configured to define the GL codes affected by a specific type of normalised event file or invoice transaction when revenue is recognised.  GL guidance entities, rather than GL codes, are associated with normalised event file or invoice transactions.    Convergent Billing supports the following types of GL guidance entities:  Accrual  Actual  Deferral  Non-billable.  The types are not explicitly displayed in the Convergent Billing client.  Each type is distinguished by the combination of Earned But Unbilled (EBUB), Billed and Earned (BE), Billed but Unearned (BUE), and Earned but Unbilled (EBUB) Pending Consolidation GL code pairs.   For more information about GL guidance entities, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.  Related Topic  GL Code Pairs Rules and Validation

pages.title: General Ledger Guidance Function
pages.text: The GL guidance entity function (GLGuidance?[]()) is called during rating and billing, and returns GL guidance information for a specified transaction.  GLGuidance?[]() determines the allocation of a charge (generated from billable tariffs) to GL guidance entities.   Because the posting of amounts to GL codes is implementation-dependent, by default GLGuidance?[]() is an empty function returning an empty array and must be configured with the relevant guidance information.  For more information, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: GL Code Pairs Rules and Validation
pages.text: Convergent Billing uses a general ledger (GL) guidance entity to map relevant charges to GL codes.  ID that each account in a general ledger is identified by, and sometimes known as an account code.  GL codes are used to map transactions in Singleview to the appropriate account in the external general ledger system.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Adjustment Type and Payment Type.  The type of the GL guidance entity is not explicitly displayed in the Convergent Billing client.  Each type is distinguished by the combination of Earned But Unbilled (EBUB), Billed and Earned (BE), Billed but Unearned (BUE) GL, and Earned But Unbilled (EBUB) Pending Consolidation code pairs.  For more information about GL guidance entity types, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.  A GL guidance entity has either one or two pairs of GL codes, depending on the type.  Each GL code pair has a debit and a credit GL code.  Refer to the following table for the valid combination of GL code pairs for each type of GL guidance entity.  GL Guidance Type  GL Code Pair Specified  EBUB Pending Consolidation  EBUB  BUE  BE  Accrual  Yes  No  Yes  Not available  Actual  No  No  Yes  Optional  Deferral  No  Yes  Yes  Optional  Non-billable  Yes  No  No  Not available  In addition to the valid combinations of GL code pairs, the following rules apply to GL guidance entities:  All GL codes associated with a GL guidance entity must have the same reporting entity over the GL guidance entity's date range.  The Earned But Unbilled (EBUB) GL code pair cannot contain accounts receivable GL codes (an account category code of Receivable), and the debit GL code must be different from the credit GL code.  Category (or subclass) of one of the available account classes a Convergent Billing account belongs to.  Although account categories are extensible, Convergent Billing does not validate account categories against account classes.  The following table lists default account categories supported in Convergent Billing.  Account Category  Account Class  Receivable  Asset  Payable  Liability  Deposit  Liability  Credit  Liability  Bank  Asset  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Account Class, Account Type, and General Ledger Account Category.  Only one of the Billed and Earned (BE) GL codes can be an accounts receivable GL code; however, an accounts receivable GL code does not need to be specified.  Only one of the Billed but Unearned (BUE) GL codes can be an accounts receivable GL code; however, an accounts receivable GL code does not need to be specified.  If both a Billed and Earned (BE) GL code pair and a Billed but Unearned (BUE) GL code pair are defined, and the debit GL code for one pair represents an accounts receivable GL code, then:  The debit GL code of the other pair must be the same GL code.   Neither of the credit GL codes can represent an accounts receivable GL code.   If the credit GL code for one pair represents an accounts receivable GL code, then:  The credit GL code of the other pair must be the same GL code.  Neither of the debit GL codes can represent an accounts receivable GL code.  If the Billed and Earned (BE) GL codes are specified and the Earned but Unbilled (EBUB) GL codes are not specified, the Earned but Unbilled (EBUB) Pending Consolidation GL codes are enabled.  This cannot be an accounts receivable code.

pages.title: Hash
pages.text:
Hashes can be defined in Convergent Billing as local variables in expression blocks and functions, subject to the following conditions: Hashes are defined using the following syntax: {} The defines the data type of each hash element. For example, var charges#{} defines a hash of real data type. Hashes are referenced using the following syntax: {} where returns a string; for example, var custname${'name'} := 'Smith'; The following table lists examples for the usage of hashes. Example Description a${} Accesses the hash as a whole. var b?{};b${'SERVICE_NAME'}{} := a${}; Assigns a hash to a hash element. b${'SERVICE_NAME'}{'Old'} := 'Hello'; Assigns an element to a two-dimensional hash. var b?{};b${'SERVICE_NAME'}[] := a$[]; Assigns an array to a hash element. b${'SERVICE_NAME'}[0] := 'FirstValue'; Assigns an array element within a hash. There is no limit to the depth at which arrays or hashes can be nested. Nested arrays and hashes are implicitly created as required and are always of unknown type. Only hashes of unknown type support nested arrays and hashes. A hash cannot be declared with multiple dimensions. For example, the following is incorrect: var a?{}{};. To create a multi-dimensional hash, a single dimensional hash of unknown type must first be declared, and then the nested hashes (or arrays) accessed as required. A hash variable is identified by its name only, as opposed to scalar variables, which are identified by name and type. For example, the following is incorrect: var a&{}, a${}; The variable a has been declared to be of type integer hash, and cannot be declared to be of type string hash. The purpose of this is to allow hash elements to use the type character; for example: var a?{};
a?{'SERVICE_NAME'} := ' a string';
# Trim leading spaces from first Array element.
a${'SERVICE_NAME'} := ltrim(a${'SERVICE_NAME'});
#Could also say
a?{'SERVICE_NAME'} := ltrim(a${'SERVICE_NAME'});
#or
a?{'SERVICE_NAME'} := ltrim(to_string(a?{'SERVICE_NAME'})); a${'SERVICE_NAME'} is not equivalent to to_string(a?{'SERVICE_NAME'}). a${'SERVICE_NAME'} results in a runtime error if the value being accessed is not a string, while to_string(a${'SERVICE_NAME'}) converts the value to a string (using default formats for integers, reals, and dates) if it is not already a string. In general, the value accessed must be of the type specified, or a runtime error occurs. The exception is that casting between integers and reals is permitted; however, accessing a real value as an integer changes the value stored in the element to an integer, and accessing an integer as a real value changes the value stored in the element to a real value; for example: var a?{};
a#{'SERVICE_NAME'} := 1.1;
if (a&{'SERVICE_NAME'} > 0) then print(a#{'SERVICE_NAME'}); # This prints 1, NOT 1.1

pages.title: High Availability
pages.text: Convergent Billing supports an installation within a highly available system.  A system is highly available if the system has the backups or fail-safes to handle unplanned outages and ensure consistent availability.  High availability is necessary for systems that require real-time account maintenance and management.  For example, installations that use Commerce Engine require that user authentication and requests for account information are available, even if a power outage has occurred or if one of the servers has failed.  High availability is not usually considered to be necessary for the entire Convergent Billing system.  For example, batch processes and reports can be executed on redundant systems or other systems that do not need to be always available.  Commerce Engine is a separate licence option.

pages.title: Icons
pages.text: Icons are used to represent customer types, person types, contract types, products, service types, facility groups, and equipment types.  Assigning an icon enables the user to quickly identify the correct element when a number of elements are displayed in the Customer Hierarchy form.

pages.title: Importing Constants
pages.text: Constants defined in a function can be made available to other functions or expressions using the import command.  The syntax to import a function is defined as follows:  import <FunctionName>;  <FunctionName> is the full name of the function from which to import constants.  No opening or closing parenthesis are specified with the function name.  After using the import command, all constants defined in the imported function are available in the remainder of the current block and nested blocks. At parse time, any reference to a constant is resolved by checking for a local definition of it. If no definition is found, a definition is searched for in each imported function in scope, with the most recent imported function searched first. If there are multiple definitions, the first definition found is used.  Only constants in <FunctionName> whose value can be determined at parse time are available to be imported.  Constants whose value cannot be resolved until runtime are not available. They include constants whose value is dependent on the:  Value of a function parameter, local variable, or global variable  Result of a non-deterministic function  Deterministic function that could not be successfully evaluated at parse time.  All constants defined in the function, whose value can be resolved at parse time, are made available even if they were defined in an inner block of the function body.  The value of a constant imported from a function is not copied at parse time if it is referenced.  The following is an example of importing constants:  DataTypeConstants&() =  {      const DATA_TYPE_INTEGER& := 0;      const DATA_TYPE_REAL& := 1;      const DATA_TYPE_STRING := 2;      0;  }  MyFunction&() =  {      import DataTypeConstants&;      var Number& := DATA_TYPE_INTEGER&;      return Number&;  }  All constants defined in the imported function are available, even if they are in a nested loop in the imported function.  Only functions that are not overloaded (that is, have an interface number of 1) can be imported.  If a function that is imported by other functions is purged, all functions in the client or server process are purged.

pages.title: Incoming Responses
pages.text: Replies that the rating engine expects in response to its outgoing messages are:  Acknowledgement Message  Negative Acknowledgement Message.

pages.title: Insert Functions
pages.text: Functions that insert data pass all the database arrays by value, after populating them with the data for insertion.  For insertion, the following conditions apply:  All columns specified as not null in the appropriate view are mandatory.  Exceptions to this rule are:  The ID, which is optional.  If supplied, it must be unique; if not supplied, it is generated by the database.  The last modified date, which should not be supplied; it is normally returned to the caller in a pass-by-reference parameter.  The effective end date is optional.  If omitted, it defaults to the most future date possible (jtime_sunset).  Certain other values, dependent on the data concerned.  Some data items have two associated columns, one an identifier and the other a name (for example, CURRENCY_ID and CURRENCY_SYMBOL).  A value can be supplied for either one of these columns, or for both.  If values are supplied for both columns, they must match each other.  Because of the relatively large number of mandatory field values (not null columns), TRE insert functions, though straightforward, can be labour-intensive.  Therefore, no example is given in this section.

pages.title: Interface Components
pages.text: Additional Singleview components are supplied as separate Convergent Billing licence options and are designed to work seamlessly with Convergent Billing.  Additional components include Commerce Engine and the Invoice Design Tool.

pages.title: Interface Number
pages.text: To easily and uniquely identify specific instances of overloaded functions in Configuration Studio, all functions in Singleview also have an interface number associated with them.  The interface number is a small integer between 1 and 999.  The combination of function name, return type, and interface number uniquely identifies a function.  Functions that are not overloaded always have an interface number of 1.  Overloaded functions have interface numbers starting from 1 and increasing for each overloaded instance of the function.  Whenever Configuration Studio references a function with an interface number other than '1', it appends the interface number in brackets after the function name and return type (for example, MyFunction& (2)).

pages.title: Interface Definitions
pages.text: An interface definition is an instance of an interface template. Interface definitions store details of an interface in the database. These details provide a representation of the interface in a fixed and consistent format, and allows functionality to be used to manage and maintain interfaces.   Interface definitions:  Must be unique.  Must have an interface template specified.  Can specify configuration regeneration.  Can define operational parameters.  Supports validation for operational parameters.  Can be archived.  Static parameters defined in an interface template can only be viewed. Access to interface definitions can be restricted to groups to which a user is assigned.  For more information about interface definitions, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Interface Templates
pages.text: An interface template is an instance of an interface type. Interface templates provide static data that define the fundamental functionality of an interface, and operational data used to influence the operation of an interface. Interface templates derived from interface types supplied by Singleview are used in customisation and reuse of templates.   Interface templates:  Must be unique.  Must have an interface type specified.  Can specify external definitions.  Can define static and operational parameters.  Support validation for static parameters.  Interface templates are used to create interface definitions that store details of an interface in the database.  Interface templates cannot be deleted if one or more interface definitions based on the template exist.  For more information about interface templates, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Interface Types
pages.text: An interface type defines the format, characteristics, and details required to configure an interface. Interface types supplied by Singleview provide default values that can be applied to interface templates when creating a new interface definition. Changes made to an interface type are reflected in the associated templates and definitions.   Interface types:  Must be unique.  Allow grouping of attributes into multiple tabs.  Can classify tabs as containing static or operational parameters.  Can specify parameters in tabular structure.  Support full validation using entity validation.  Attributes used in interface type tabs are defined as the following derived attribute types:  Fixed, where fields are displayed on the tab, and only a single row of data is supported.  Table, where a grid is displayed on the tab, and multiple rows of tabular data can be entered.  Interface types cannot be deleted if one or more interface templates of that type exists.   For more information about interface types, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Invoice Design Tool
pages.text: The Singleview Invoice Design Tool is a Graphic User Interface application used for creating and updating the invoice templates that generate a Convergent Billing invoice format.  The Invoice Design Tool provides an efficient and convenient approach to managing invoice design in Convergent Billing.  For more information about the Invoice Design Tool, refer to the User Guide for Singleview Invoice Design Tool.

pages.title: Invoice Message
pages.text: Messages can be added to some or all invoices and statements (for example, to promote special offers, or remind selected customers of a service being promoted).  Positioning and formatting of the messages are defined in an invoice template, which must be at Level 8 (Invoice Messages).  The variable that contains the message text is InvInvoiceMessageText$; this can return multiple values (one for each eligible invoice message), so more than one message can be inserted.  Insertion of a message on an invoice can be controlled by field entries on the Invoice Message Definition form.  The options range from a global message that appears on every invoice, to a message that appears only once on one invoice for one customer.  The display messages can be controlled using TEX statements inserted into the InvInvoiceMessageText$ field.

pages.title: Invoice Types
pages.text: Invoice types are used to define generically the type of invoices required rather than defining a specific invoice format, which is likely to change, or be superseded.  The invoice type definition contains a name, validity dates, and any invoice assignment expressions or a consolidation expression used to further customise the invoice type.

pages.title: Invoices
pages.text: An invoice contains the charges owing for services the customer has used.  Convergent Billing is used to view:  Details of each invoice generated for a specific customer.  The details include invoice number, account number, invoiced amount, issue date, any early payment discounts, and details of subtotals and taxes (if any) displayed on the invoice.    An electronic copy (image) of the printed invoice sent to the customer to identify the charge or item being enquired about by a customer.  An image of the invoice immediately after it was generated.  Invoices are only generated (as part of a bill run) if the report level of the customer node is set to Invoice, and are only raised against the customer's primary account.  The frequency at which a customer is sent an invoice is determined by the invoice cycle requested by that customer.  Interim invoices (generated using the Interim Bill Run schedule type) only include rental events that have been designated as interim charges.  Generated at times other than the regular invoice cycle and includes charges defined as 'interim'.  Interim invoices are typically used for activation tariffs (when the service provider wants to charge the installation or activation fees as soon as the service is installed or requested).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Invoice, Invoice Cycle, and Tariff.  Invoices can be suppressed if they meet configurable criteria.  Invoice images are not produced for suppressed invoices.  The appearance of an invoice, the level of detail it contains, and the frequency at which it is generated are specified for a customer when that customer’s details are recorded in Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Java Bridge
pages.text: The Java Bridge is a collection of related classes that facilitate the creation of a Java TRE Server.

pages.title: Java Transaction Engine (API)
pages.text: The Java Application Programming Interface (API) to the Transaction Engine (TRE) is distinct from the C, Perl, and Object Pascal API as it is platform independent.  Java API is also built on a class hierarchy used specifically by Convergent Billing.  The Java TRE API is also known as the Enterprise Java Interface (EJI).  The term Java TRE API is used in the online help.  The TRE is used both by client and server processes.  The TRE can also be used by external applications by means of the API, for the following purposes:  Calling TRE functions.  Grouping function calls into transactions, with the option to commit or roll back the transaction.  Queuing transactions.  Subscribing to events, defining an event handler, and checking for events.  Posting TRE events.  The Java TRE API provides two mechanisms for accessing remote TRE functions: static or dynamic invocation.  The BuildStaticInterface tool can be used to generate Java classes with selected remote TRE functions available as static methods or the functions can be called by name dynamically at runtime.   By default, the Java TRE API uses configuration information from a file called EJIENVFILE.  At runtime, the API searches the Java CLASSPATH for the EJIENVFILE when a TreConnection class instance is constructed.  The alternative constructor TreConnection(java.util.Properties) can be used to programmatically set the properties of a connection, rather than using the properties specified in the EJIENVFILE file.

pages.title: Java TRE Server
pages.text: The Java TRE Server enables the generation of notifications and outgoing calls to other third party systems and software, and is built using the classes in the Java Bridge.  The Java Server can be connected to the Remote Service server, which uses a TCP connection to communicate.  To create and start a Java server:  Create a new HandlerFactory whose only parameter is the class whose functions are to be used.  The (useInteger TRUE | FALSE) parameter may also be passed to the constructor.  When true, useInteger causes the Java bridge to use int, Integer, and TreVarInteger types for EPM integers.  When false, or not specified, useInteger causes the Java bridge to use long, Long, and TreVarLong types for EPM integers.  Example: HandlerFactory factory = new ReflectHandlerFactory(functionClass.class);  Create a new Listener.  Example: Listener listener = new Listener(port, factory, block);  To create a new function:  Create the EPM function.    The function must be defined under the Function Definition tab; however, the definition's body is not used when the function is invoked.  The definition must include appropriate parameter declarations and the return type that will be used by the replacement Java function.  The function body must return a dummy value of the appropriate type.  Select the following:  Use Remote Function Call? check box.  Asynchronous, Queued, or Synchronous in the Call Type field.  biRService in the Service Name field.  Execute as separate transaction? check box.  Create the Java function, and ensure that it exists as a method in the class that was passed as a parameter when creating a new Java server.  The method must have the same name and case as the EPM function and must be declared 'public static'.  EPM parameters do not map directly to Java parameters.  The Java parameters occur in the same order, but have different types.  The mapping also depends on whether parameters are available; this is indicated by the var keyword before the parameter name.  The return type is mapped as a non-variable parameter.  EPM functions, whose parameters are of type Unknown, must have appropriate overloaded Java functions for all basic types (Blob, Date, Integer, Real, and String).  If the EPM function has several parameters of type Unknown, then Java functions for all permutations of the five basic types for those parameters of type Unknown must be written.  The Java TRE server uses EPM to Java Type Mapping.

pages.title: Licence Checks when Logging In
pages.text: Whenever a user attempts to log in to Convergent Billing from a client workstation, the Authentication server checks the number of active users against the licensed maximum.  When the number of active users is:  Below the warning level, access is accepted if login is successful.  Between the warning level and the maximum licensed number, a warning message is displayed and login is accepted.  Between the licensed number and the maximum level, a more strongly worded warning message is displayed and login is accepted.  Above the maximum level, access is denied.  A user who cannot log in because of licence restrictions can log in again when the number of active users falls below the maximum level.  If a client logs in and an invalid licence signature is detected or licence recalculation is overdue, the Authentication server automatically initiates a one-off task to perform a licence recalculation.    Users are unable to log in until the licence recalculation task is successful.  No further licence recalculation tasks are issued by the Authentication server for 30 minutes.

pages.title: Licensing
pages.text: Convergent Billing is subject to licensing restrictions; the conditions of a licence are negotiated between the Convergent Billing user and CSG International.    Each licence is based on three factors:  A period of validity, from the granting of the licence to an expiry date.  A specified machine and, optionally, a specific database on that machine.    A maximum permitted workload, defined in terms of the number of concurrent users, active customers, active customer nodes, and active service instances.  A licence key can be affected by changes to the specified machine, causing a new key to be required.  Changes to hardware such as RAM, CPUs, or disks do not affect the licence key.  Changes that may require a new licence key are:  Changes to the motherboard  Firmware updates  New system software installed (AIX)  Change to the IP address.  The licence is supplied in the form of a software key, from which a configuration item is constructed in the Convergent Billing database.  A Tuxedo server, known as the Authentication server, is responsible for checking the validity and usage level of the licence.  Detection of an invalid licence (one that has expired or been tampered with) can have two outcomes:  On startup, the Authentication server does not start, and does not permit the other server processes to start.  Clients are not able to log in under these circumstances.  In normal operation, the Authentication server continues to run.  If the key has been tampered with, the previous licence information is retained.  However, if either the Event Rating Process (BKR) or the Bill Generation Process (BGP) detect that the licence has expired (or that the licence limits have been exceeded), these processes do not start.  Each machine in a Convergent Billing cluster must have its own Authentication Server and, therefore, its own LICENCE configuration item.  The Authentication Server also monitors the workload, issuing warnings as the maximum permitted level for each entity (user, customer, customer node, or service instance) is approached.  The following action is taken when the workload reaches its maximum permitted levels:  If the number of concurrent users is exceeded, additional users are not permitted to log in.  If the number of active services is exceeded, rating and billing are disabled.  If the number of active customers or customer nodes is exceeded, billing is disabled.  However, Convergent Billing will remain available for work on entities created within the workload limit.  The licence does not distinguish between temporary and permanent services.  For example, GSM roamers and open access services (IGF) are treated in the same way as permanent services when the Authentication Server assesses workload.  The Authentication server also checks the currency of the licence each time a user logs in.  If an invalid licence signature is detected or licence recalculation is overdue, the Authentication Server automatically initiates a task to perform a licence recalculation.  Users are unable to log in until the licence recalculation task is successful.  No further licence recalculations are issued by the Authentication server for 30 minutes.  The Convergent Billing Invoice Design Tool is a separately licensed item.

pages.title: Licence Enforcement
pages.text: The Authentication server checks the Convergent Billing licence at three levels:  When starting the rating engine or the billing engine.  When users log in.  When users attempt to save new entities subject to licensing.  If the licensed levels are inadequate for the volume of work, a new licence must be negotiated with CSG International.  Related Topics  Server Licence Checks  Login Licence Checks  Entity Saving Licence Checks

pages.title: Functions Defined on the biLicence Service
pages.text: The Authentication server and the client workstations enforce the licence conditions by making calls on functions defined in the biLicence Tuxedo service.  Functions defined on the biLicence service are:  biLicenceReload&  Reloads the licence restrictions from the database.  biLicenceExpiry~  Returns the expiry date of the licence.  biLicenceStatus&  Returns the current status of the entity.  Example 1 describes how to determine the expiry date of the licence.

pages.title: Example
pages.text: To determine the expiry date of the licence, execute the following expression block:  {var Unused$ := '' ;  biLicenceExpiry~ (Unused$)}

pages.title: Lists
pages.text: A list is a defined set of values with a common purpose.  For example, a list can contain the numbers frequently called by a specific customer, a list of areas serviced by a specific substation, or a list of the area codes that form the central business district of a specific city.  As in the case of service types, it is inefficient and often impractical to hard-code information into Convergent Billing.  For this reason, a derived attribute can be defined, with the type of information held in the associated list.  Like equipment types, the values in the derived attribute are not defined during product definition but entered in response to information supplied by the customer.  When a derived attribute, with an evaluation type of List, is evaluated, the value of a conditional expression is compared to each of the values defined in the derived attribute.  The derived attribute returns TRUE (a non-zero value) if the given value is defined in the derived attribute, or returns FALSE (zero) if the given value is not defined in the list.  The most common use for a derived attribute, with an evaluation type of List, is used to group frequently called numbers so that special tariffs can be applied, and customers can nominate up to five B party phone numbers that they call frequently.  The specified numbers (entered by a user on the Lists tab on Customer Detail form) are stored in a derived attribute and whenever that customer makes a call, the B party phone number is compared to the numbers in the derived attribute.  If a match is found, the special tariff is applied; if no match is found, the normal call tariff for that customer is applied.  The application environment determines the options available for derived attribute storage and use.  Derived attributes processed in the Billing application environment, can be used in Customer, Customer Node, Normalised Event, and Service contexts, and stored in Customer, Customer Node, Facility Group, and Service contexts.  Derived attributes processed in the Rating application environment, can be used in the Service context, and stored in Facility Group and Service contexts. Derived attributes can be either master or slaves.  Master and slave derived attributes share the same data, but the slave derived attribute may redefine how the common data is accessed.  A derived attribute can also be used to define a list to look up facilities in a facility group and then specify tariff eligibility criteria.  The list indicates whether a specific facility is in a facility group and therefore whether tariffs associated with that facility should be applied.

pages.title: Local Constants
pages.text: Local constants can be defined by preceding a variable name with the const keyword (for example, const myVar& := 1;).  A local constant is only valid from where it is defined until the end of the current expression block or function definition.  Local constants have the same precedence as local variables.  Local constants must be assigned a value as part of their definition.  The value that they are assigned must either be an expression that can be evaluated to a constant at parse time (that is, a constant value) or an expression which is considered to return a constant value (that is, an expression involving a constant function parameter).  Local constants cannot be modified after they are defined.  Therefore, they cannot:  Appear on the left-hand side of an assignment.  Be passed by reference to a function.  Appear on the right-hand side of an equivalence (::=).  Local constants can improve code efficiency and readability, particularly when compared to local variables.  Expressions involving local constants whose values are a constant can be evaluated at parse time if all other elements of the expression are also known at parse time.  Nested local constant definitions are not supported.  Redefining the same local constant within separate blocks in the same expression is not permitted.

pages.title: Logical Operators
pages.text: Operator  Integer  <> 0 is TRUE, 0 is False  Real  <> 0.0 is TRUE, 0.0 is FALSE  String  Date  NOT or !  Not  Not  AND  And  And  OR  Or  Or

pages.title: Maximum Concurrent Logins
pages.text: The Maximum Concurrent Logins field is an optional field on the Profile Definition form.  This field specifies the maximum number of concurrent logins, between 1 - 999, available to each user with this profile.  If not specified, there is no limit.

pages.title: Negative Acknowledgement Message
pages.text: Format  <length>|NACK|<seq nr>|0|0|  where:  <length> is total number of bytes in the message.  <seq nr> is the sequence number of the message not correctly received.  Example  00000023|NACK|7254|0|0|  Remarks  The rating engine waits for a user definable length of time to receive a response after transmitting a charge message. If no response is received during this period, the rating engine closes the named pipe or TCP/IP socket connection.  Reading events from a TCP/IP socket is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  The value of the <seq nr> field should be identical to the value of the <seq nr> field in the charge message, which was transmitted.  If these values are not identical, the rating engine ignores this negative acknowledgment.  If the values of the <seq nr> fields are identical, the rating engine re-transmits its most recent message.  If another negative acknowledgment is then received, the rating engine again re-transmits the message.  The rating engine continues in this manner until:  An acknowledgment is received.  The number of transmission attempts reaches a user-definable limit (in which case the rating engine closes the named pipe or TCP/IP socket connection).  The named pipe or TCP/IP socket connection is closed by the network or by the remote host.

pages.title: Normalised Event File Type
pages.text: The normalised event file type defines the decoding methods used to convert raw events into normalised events.  The normalised event file type used for each type of incoming raw event is recorded as an attribute for the Event Normalisation (ENM) process.    Each ENM has a FILE_TYPE configuration attribute which specifies the default normalised event file type supported by the ENM, but this file type can be overridden by any other file type for each normalised event file to be processed.  Decoding of incoming events uses:  Built-in decoding methods  Data Interface Language (DIL)  Additional processing, which can be carried out on decoded records before the values are committed to the database.  After decoding by built-in decoding or DIL decoding, the direct variables can be further modified using the Expression Parser Module (EPM).  Further modification may be required, for example, to translate a value supplied by the switch in its own format into the format required by Convergent Billing.  Parses and executes expressions.  Used to make comparisons, validate input, and calculate values.  The EPM provides built-in functions, including mathematical, type conversion, string processing, date functions, subtotal history, invoice data, and form automation.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Built-in Function, Expression, and Form Automation.  Additional processing is usually required after using the built-in decoding methods.  With DIL decoding it is generally more convenient to define additional processing as part of the DIL specification, rather than applying additional expressions after the decoding is complete.

pages.title: Normalised Event Type
pages.text: The normalised event type is used to associate reference types and attribute types with many of the fields in a specific type of normalised event record.  The association is a way of controlling how normalised events are displayed on the Normalised Event Detail form.  The selections that make up a normalised event type do not affect the decoding or storage of the normalised event, they affect how the type of normalised event is displayed on the Convergent Billing workstation.

pages.title: Outgoing Messages
pages.text: Following are the messages that may be sent by the rating engine to a remote destination:  Charge Message  Diagnostic Message

pages.title: Outgoing Responses
pages.text: Following are responses that the rating engine may transmit to the remote source in response to an incoming message:  Acknowledgement Message  Event Error Message

pages.title: Output Device Definition Form
pages.text: The Output Device Definition form defines the UNIX command used to send the output to the required device.  Therefore knowledge of UNIX, the Convergent Billing environment, and device configuration to work with output devices is required.  The form includes the following information:  Output Image Type, which defines the format of the image stored in the database.  Run Command, which is processed in conjunction with the Pipe images to run command? and Concatenate Images? options.  Start Command, which is an optional UNIX command executed before a batch of images is output.  For example, the start command can be used to instruct the printer to select the correct stationery.  Stop Command, which is an optional UNIX command that is executed when each batch is completed.  For example, the stop command can be used to advise a user that the print run has finished.  It can also be used to track the batch number, or where in the entire run a specific batch is.  Options and outcomes of the run command are listed in the following table.  Option  Result  Neither  Run Command (taking $file as an argument) is executed after each image is output.  Concatenate  Run Command is executed after all images in the batch have been concatenated into $file.  The only file type that can be concatenated is .txt.  Pipe  Output image is piped to the Run command.  Both  Same as Pipe, except that the pipe is not closed, and is reopened between images.

pages.title: Output Method
pages.text: Both output method and output method type are used to set up printing configuration to meet the business requirements of an organisation.  An output method is used to select the order in which the output is printed (for example, to have invoices printed by state and by postal code).  Different output devices can be selected for different sets of invoices (for example, a different printer for each state or region).  An output method type defines the location in the database of the query view and the document image.  An output method also specifies any table update required (for example, to flag an invoice as having been printed).  The database views are used to retrieve the data for output, and also define any changes that the output process is to make to the database (for example, to set a 'Printed' indicator on the invoice table).

pages.title: Override a Charge Category at the Customer Node
pages.text: A charge category override at the customer node works differently from the overrides defined in service types or customer types.  If an instance of a charge category exists at a customer node, this instance overrides any default set for the same charge category when a new service is created.  For tariffs with a context of Customer Node, no action is taken because the instance exists; at the customer or service level, a new instance identical with the customer node instance is created.  There are few circumstances when this might apply. However, it may cause unexpected results if some tariffs using the charge category are given the context of Customer Node, and others the context of Service or Customer.  If the customer node instance is modified, this modification affects any subsequent services created at that node with the same charge category.

pages.title: Parameters Passed by a Constant
pages.text: If a function parameter is preceded by the const keyword, it is treated as a constant value.  The function body is not allowed to modify the value of a constant parameter.  Constant parameters cannot be:  Specified on the left-hand side of an assignment.  Passed by reference to other functions.  Specified on the right-hand side of an equivalence assignment (::=) operator.  Declaring function parameters as const improves the efficiency of calling the function, especially for  parameters of string, blob, array, or hash type.

pages.title: Parameters Passed by Reference
pages.text: When a parameter is passed by reference, the function has access to the original variables and can change it.  Only variables are passed by reference.  A parameter is assumed to be passed by value unless the parameter name is preceded by the var keyword in the function definition.  The following example is a function whose parameters are passed by reference:  MyFunction#(var index  &, var somearray#[]) =   {  	FunctionBody  }

pages.title: Parameters Passed by Value
pages.text: When a parameter is passed by value, the function receives a copy of the parameter; any change the function makes to this value does not affect the value of the parameter outside the function.  A parameter is assumed to be passed by value unless the parameter name is preceded by the var keyword in the function definition.

pages.title: Payment Batches
pages.text: Entering payments in batches is simply an alternative method of entering and processing payments of the same payment type.  For example, this method can be used to enter a batch of cheques received in the mail, or a number of cash payments.  Once created, individual payments can be added to and removed from the payment batch.  Each payment added to the payment batch is assigned a receipt number when that payment is saved.  The payment batch is assigned a payment batch number when the first payment within the payment batch is saved.  While the payment batch is being created, the batch status is set to ‘Entered’.  Payments within a payment batch are posted to the relevant customer accounts only when the payment batch is applied.  Once a payment batch is applied, the batch status is set to 'Applied'.  Details of individual payments within a batch can now be viewed, and associated receipts can be previewed and/or printed.  Individual payments within a payment batch can be modified either before or after applying the batch.  If errors are discovered in a payment after it is posted (for example, the payment was posted to the wrong account), the payment batch can be un-applied (restrictions apply).  Un-applying a payment batch results in all payments included in the batch being un-posted.  Individual payments can then be modified and the payment batch re-applied.  Facilities are provided to:  A payment batch can only be un-applied if a payment within that payment batch was not:  Included on (appeared on) an invoice or statement.  Posted to the Sales Journal.  Rejected.  Change the allocation of the payment to an invoice.  Reject the payment.  Delete the payment.

pages.title: Payment Types
pages.text: A payment type is used to define common parameters for payment records.  The following table lists possible payment types.  Payment Type  Description  Cash  Payment by cash.  Cheque  Payment by cheque.  Credit Card  Payment by credit card.  The payment type relies on a number of items being defined and available within Convergent Billing; these include the appropriate currency, GL codes, and account types.  If customising the Individual Payment form for a specific payment type, the appropriate entity validation definition, attribute types, reference types, and context-sensitive help must be defined before the payment type is defined.  For more information about payment types, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Payments
pages.text: Payments received from customers need to be recorded against their accounts.  When recorded, those payments are reflected in that customer’s account details and subsequently on statements and invoices generated for that customer.  Legal document itemising charges (and possibly credits) accrued against that customer's account for services used by, or supplied to, that customer over a specified period.  Accrued charges for a customer node in a customer hierarchy can be 'rolled up' into the invoice for a node higher in the customer hierarchy.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Customer Hierarchy, Customer Node, Reporting Level, and Statement.  Document itemising charges (and possibly credits) accrued against a customer's account for services used by, or supplied to, that customer over a specified period.  Unlike an invoice that itemises charges, a statement provides a record of the charges.   Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Invoice and Reporting Level.  Unique account to which financial transactions are posted.  Each customer has at least one account (known as the primary account) and optionally one or more secondary accounts.  Each account has a unique account number by which it is identified.  See also Account Type.  Each payment is credited to the specified customer’s account.  The payment can be made against an up-front charge or an outstanding invoice.  If the payment is made against an invoice, that payment is allocated to the appropriate invoice.  However, Convergent Billing’s flexibility allows a single payment to be split and allocated to multiple invoices.  Multiple invoices are necessary when, for example, a customer pays four outstanding invoices with a single cheque.  In fact, a payment can be allocated (fully or partially) to any outstanding invoice.  In situations where no invoices are outstanding, the payment can be recorded as a credit.  Customers pay their invoices using a number of payment methods.  For example, payments can be made by cash, cheque, credit card, or direct debit.  Each of these payment methods can be recorded as payment types.  Payments can be entered individually, or in batches of the same payment type.  Convergent Billing assigns a receipt number to every recorded payment irrespective of whether that payment was entered as an individual payment or as part of a payment batch.  Each payment batch is also assigned a payment batch number by which it can be referenced.  The payment type determines the format of each receipt number and payment batch number.  Typically, the format for a receipt number includes a unique prefix so that, when viewing a customer’s account details, payments of a specific type can be more easily identified in the list of transactions.  If errors are discovered in a payment after it was posted (for example, the payment has been posted to the wrong account), facilities are provided to:  Change the allocation of the payment to an invoice.  Reject the payment.  Delete the payment.  Facilities are provided in Convergent Billing to search for and view specific payments and specific payment batches, to view the history of any changes to those payments, and if required, to preview and print the current receipt.

pages.title: Person Types
pages.text: A person type is used to define common parameters for contact (person) detail records.  A person is a customer contact, supplier, employee, or any person or company an organisation needs to contact for business purposes.  The following table lists person type examples.  Person Type  Description  Corporate  Corporate customer contact.  Employee  Person employed by the customer.  Residential  Residential customer who is also the contact.  The person type relies on a number of items being defined and available in Convergent Billing.  Available items include an address format and an icon.  If customising the Person Detail form for a specific person type, the appropriate entity validation definitions, attribute types, reference types, and context-sensitive help must be defined before the customer type is defined.

pages.title: Product Groups
pages.text: Products can be grouped so related products can be located more easily when assigning products to customers.  A product group simply defines the products displayed as a group.  Product groups are displayed on individually named tabs (one tab per product group) on the Customer Hierarchy form.  A tab is labelled with the product group name and displays the icons associated with the products defined in the specified product group.  Products can be grouped as required, but should be grouped so that related products (products that offer similar or complementary services) are available in the same group.  For example, define one product group to include all products relating to digital mobile phones, and another that includes all products relating to standard touchphones.  Once defined, a product group can be modified whenever required.  For example, products can be added to, or removed from, the product group, and a group’s details such as its name and description can be modified.  Any modification made to a product group is reflected in what is displayed.

pages.title: Product Offers
pages.text: A product offer is a collection of products which would typically be offered together for sale to a customer. Most product offers may be included in other product offers.

pages.title: Product Offer Overview
pages.text: A product offer consists of:  A single base product  Companion products  Service restrictions, if required  Customer type restrictions, if required  Derived attribute table rows defined for the combination of companion product and product offer   Child product offers  Offer-based charging and entitlements.  The following diagram displays the product offer model.  Product Offer Model

pages.title: Products
pages.text: When a customer’s details have been recorded in Convergent Billing, the customer can be assigned one or more products.  Convergent Billing supports two categories of product:  Base products, which are combinations of services, tariffs (charges), subtotals (aggregated charges or discounts), facility groups (sets of service options), and derived attributes (types of value lists) required to deliver a product package that is tailored to the specific requirements of a customer. Base products may be associated with a product offer.  Companion products, which add tariffs (charges) and list objects to allow an alternative tariff regime to be applied to a base product.  Each base product has associated with it at least one, and possibly many, services (and any associated equipment).  Provides a specific component of the overall product for which the customer is charged.  Each service has an associated service type, and unique service number against which usage is charged.  One or more facilities (service options) or items of equipment, or both, can be associated with each service.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Equipment, Facility, and Service Type.  At least one service associated with a product must be created, to activate the product instance.  When a base product with an associated product offer is assigned to a customer, companion products and child product offers are made available for selection. A certain number of each may be required to be added to the product offer.  If the base product is not associated with a product offer, one or more facility groups (sets of service options) and one or more companion products can be specified for the product.  Product used to add tariffs, subtotals, and derived attributes to a base product.  Allows an alternative costing regime to be applied to an existing product.  A companion product cannot exist in isolation; it must be associated with an existing base product.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Base Product, Base Product Compatibility, Companion Product Compatibility and Feature.  Collection of one or more service options (known as facilities) defined in a product and associated with a specified service.  A facility group must contain at least one facility, and can also contain details of compatible facility groups.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Configuration Studio  See also Facility and Facility Group Compatibility.  Each product definition has an associated product icon by which that product is identified in a product group.  Icon associated with a specific base product.  The same icon can be used for more than one product.  Product icons are displayed in product groups on the Customer Hierarchy form.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Base Product and Product Group.  During the process of assigning a product to a customer, a copy of the product definition is made and tailored to meet a specific customer’s requirement.  The copy or product instance of the product definition is unique within the Convergent Billing database.  Specific combination of services and the associated tariff structure offered to a customer based on the framework provided by the corresponding product definition.  The original product definition is preserved, with the product instance being tailored to a specific customer's requirements.  Any changes made to the product definition affect only product instances created after the changes are made, not existing product instances.  Referred to as a Purchased Product in Customer Management.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Product Definition and Product Model.  More than one active instance of the same companion product can be assigned to a single base product using one or more product offers or directly, if specified in the definition of the companion product.  Having the same companion product assigned to a single base product is only useful for activation, cancellation, entitlements, and recurring charges generated by the RGP, because multiple companion products of the same name do not influence rating or billing behaviour.  A completed product instance has a status of Active.  A product instance is completed when the following conditions are met:  It has at least one Active service.  All mandatory services and equipment have been created and allocated.  Optional services and equipment that have been added, are created and allocated.  A product instance is automatically completed and its status changed to Active when:  The maximum number of services and equipment have been created.  Optional components have not been specified.  A product instance that is not yet complete (that is, a product having a status of Product Creation) can be deleted.  When a product instance is created for a customer, that instance can be modified whenever required.  For example, initially the customer may only want to use one of the available facility groups, then at a later date request the use of additional facility groups.  A product instance can change to be incomplete while in a status of Active if:   New optional services or equipment are added manually, but not created or allocated.  A product offer changes by:  Adding new mandatory services or equipment.  Reducing the maximum permitted number of services for a specific service type, leaving too many services allocated.  After all new services and equipment have been assigned, the product instance is automatically re-completed.   Cancelling a product instance changes the status of the product instance and each of its constituent services, facility groups, and companion products to Cancelled.  At some later time, the product instance and its associated services can be deleted if all outstanding items for the product and its services have been completed.  Product instances that are not associated with product offers can also be upgraded; this requires a different base product to be assigned to the customer as a replacement for their product.   Upgrading refers to replacing the product on which the product instance is based.  Replacing the base product can therefore result in an upgrade or downgrade of the base product.  A product instance must be replaced if:  The base product does not meet the customer’s new requirements.  Companion products (if any) for the base product do not allow the customer’s new requirements to be met.  A new service number usually needs to be assigned when a base product assigned to a customer needs to be replaced.  For example, if a customer is assigned a GSM phone with voice-only capability and that customer wants to upgrade to a GSM phone with voice and data capability, a new product must be assigned to replace the product, and also a new service number.  A base product can only be replaced with a compatible base product.  If required, product instances can also be moved between customer nodes in the same hierarchy or between nodes in different hierarchies.  A base product instance (and its associated services and companion product instances) can be moved from one customer node to another in a customer hierarchy (some restrictions apply).  A move is achieved by dragging the required product instance from its current customer node (referred to as the source node) and dropping it onto another node (referred to as the target node).  The source node and target node can be in the same customer hierarchy or different hierarchies.  The following restrictions apply when moving a product instance:  A product cannot be upgraded or moved if the product instance was created as part of a product offer.  A product cannot be moved if its owning customer or target customer is blacklisted at any time during the move period and the user does not have access to view blacklisted customers on the Customer Form.  A product cannot be upgraded or moved if the product instance is cancelled, moved, or upgraded at the effective start date or any later date.   A product must be assigned to a customer node.  A product dragged over a root node or blank space of the hierarchy panel cannot be dropped.   Some information regarding the lists and charge categories may need to be entered (when prompted) before the product instance move can be completed.  If a product instance is moved, any changes made to it before or after the move start date are not carried over in the move.  For example, if the product instance is moved at an effective date before an equipment allocation change, following the move the variation of equipment allocation is not reflected.  A warning is displayed so the user can cancel the move.   When dropped onto the target node, customer node lists, customer lists, customer node charge categories, customer charge categories, and start date are generated for the target node as though a new product instance was being created for that node.  Some information regarding charge categories may therefore need to be entered (when prompted) before the product instance move can be completed successfully.  If a product instance is moved on the same day it is created, any activation charges are carried over to the new customer node.  Because of the move, the service accounts are mapped from the source customer node to equivalent accounts on the target customer node.  Any non-invoiced usage charges posted on or after the date the product instance is moved, are moved across to the new accounts.  Recurring charges, such as rentals, are posted to the new accounts the next time the Rental Generation Process (RGP) is run as part of the normal billing cycle.

pages.title: Profiles
pages.text: Profiles are used to set up security and other information for Convergent Billing users in the same work group.  Every user must be assigned a profile.  The information recorded in a profile includes the following:  Currency and maximum amount of adjustments that can be made to customer accounts by users assigned the profile.  Password validation function for users assigned the profile.  Maximum number of concurrent logins available to the user.  If not specified, there is no limit.  Security groups control data created or modified by users assigned the profile, and the security groups accessible to the profile.  Access levels, which control access to data belonging to a specified security group, are set individually for each security group.  Form roles accessible to the profile.  Function roles accessible to the profile.  Work groups, and associated access levels, accessible to the profile.  Oracle password management and resource usage attributes assigned to the profile.  A General tab containing any additional fields set up with entity validation.

pages.title: Queries
pages.text: Any customer enquiry recorded and subsequently processed is referred to as a query.  [[FigureXref:53615-1]] displays the query process.  [[Figure:53615-1]]  Query Process  A query can be recorded against a customer (existing or potential) or, more rarely, against a contact.  Recording a query against a contact is used to accurately record information reported by customers, and for an organisation to obtain statistical information on the types of inquiry being handled and the frequency of each type.  A query must first be recorded (usually by the person who deals directly with the customer making the enquiry) and then either resolved immediately or forwarded electronically to a work group to be resolved.  The act of forwarding the query to a work group is referred to as progressing the query.  If the designated work group cannot resolve the query, or can only provide a partial answer, that work group progresses (forwards) the query to another work group.  Progression continues until the initial query is resolved and a response is made to the customer.  The progression of a query from creation to resolution, using one or more work groups, is referred to as the query workflow.  [[FigureXref:53615-2]] displays the query progression.  [[Figure:53615-2]]  Query Progression  Query workflow ensures that each query is resolved in the fastest possible time and in the most efficient manner, regardless of the query type.  While a query remains unresolved, it is regarded as being open.  Until it is resolved, it is regarded as being closed.  When a query is forwarded to a work group, that work group actually receives a copy of the query and uses the copy as their ‘working’ document.  The ‘working’ document is referred to as a progression and is used to record any actions taken by the work group and, where possible, the solution to the original query.  Document used to record the actions taken by a work group to resolve a query.  If the query cannot be resolved by the current work group, that work group adds resolution text to the progression before forwarding the query to another work group.    Each progression therefore contains progress text (detailing the actions taken by a previous work group) and resolution text (detailing the actions performed by the current work group to resolve the query).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Progress, Progress Text, Query Text, and Resolution Text.  To progress a query:  View the appropriate customer query.  Click the Progress button.  A message is displayed, prompting confirmation that the query is to be progressed to the specified work force.  By default, the work force displayed is that associated with the query type selected.  If required, select an alternative work force.  Click Yes to progress the query to the nominated work force.  Need more information on queries?  If the query cannot be resolved by the nominated work group, that work group adds text to the progression (known as resolution text) stating what actions were taken and what progress was made, and forwards a copy of the progression to the next work group.  The resolution text copied from the previous progression becomes the progress text on which the new work group bases its actions.  The process of forwarding a copy of a progression to the next work group continues until a work group can resolve the query.  At this point, a copy of the text stating how the query can be resolved is recorded against the original query and the query is deemed to be closed.  The query workflow mechanism ensures that each progression and the original query are retained and can be viewed.  Text on which a work group bases its actions.  The progress text is created as resolution text by the previous work group before progressing the query to the current work group.  For the initial progression, the progress text is a copy of the query text.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Progress, Progression, Query Text, and Resolution Text.  Text added to a progression by a work group.  If this work group has not resolved the query, the resolution text becomes the progress text for the next work group.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Progress Text, Progression, and Query Text.

pages.title: Rating and Billing Process
pages.text: Many billing systems restrict data input to call data records, and in some cases, to specific types of call data record.  In Convergent Billing, any event that results in a charge or benefit being passed on to a customer can be input to, or generated within, the system.    Events can originate from any source of charge information, including network elements, other service providers, other mediation systems, customer contacts such as one-off rebates, service enquiries, and faults).  All such events can be input to Convergent Billing if the format of the data is known and is consistent for each type of input.  Because Convergent Billing does not restrict data input to call data records, the term event record refers to a record that contains information that may result in a charge or benefit being passed on to a customer.  [[FigureXref:60348-1]] displays the rating and billing process.  [[Figure:60348-1]]  Rating and Billing Process  The full rating and billing process is divided into the following logical operations:  Balance Management, which provides service authorisation, advice of charge information, and customer credit reservations.  Event Normalisation, in which input data is converted into a standard record format.  The output from this stage is a set of normalised event records.  Event Rating, in which the normalised event records are rated (costed) by applying the appropriate tariffs.  The output from this stage is a set of costed event charges.  Event output, in which the costed event records are stored in the Convergent Billing database.  Billing, in which the costed event records are aggregated and any applicable discounts are applied, using Convergent Billing server processes.  The output from this stage is a set of billing data records.  Invoicing, in which billing data is combined with customer detail records and incorporated into an invoice or statement.  Invoice distribution or output, in which invoices and statements are printed or converted for electronic distribution.

pages.title: Event Normalisation
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides facilities to input events from an almost unlimited number of source types to support the production of a single, consolidated bill.  The sources can include call data records, switch data records, and pre-billed records of services from other service providers for re-billing.  In addition to handling 'external' events, Convergent Billing also generates internal events (using a process known as the Rental Generation Process), which are used as the basis for obtaining recurring charges (for example, line and appliance rentals).  Whatever its source, the event data is converted into a standard record format in a process referred to as event normalisation.  The records resulting from this process are referred to as normalised events.  Each data field in a normalised event is stored as a direct variable and is therefore available for use in tariff calculations during event rating.  Related Topics  Normalised Event Type  Normalised Event File Type

pages.title: Event Rating
pages.text: Event rating is the process in which normalised event records are rated (costed) to produce charges.  The rating engine performs all rating, which allows the construction of charges based on service data and event records.  Flexible Tariffs  The key to the rating engine is its power and flexibility which allows complex tariff regimes to be handled easily, and new products and tariffs to be introduced quickly and efficiently.  The rating engine has the ability to accept configuration changes to tariffs, derived attributes, and product definitions while maintaining availability.  Another equally important aspect of the rating engine is its ability to apply different tariff types to the same normalised event record.  Known as parallel tariffing, it is possible to apply separate tariffs that calculate charges to customers, commissions, taxes (such as VAT or GST), general levies, competitor's tariffs (for bill comparisons), and loyalty points.  Parallel tariffing greatly simplifies event record processing as each event record requires only a single pass through the rating.  In addition, it provides simpler, more effective auditing.  Recurring Charges  The rating engine is also used to calculate recurring charges such as line and appliance rentals.  The Rental Generation Process (RGP) generates the events used for these calculations.  The RGP, for each event, identifies the service, product, or facility group used, and the proportion of the full recurring charge to be applied (if the service was not active for the full charge period and prorating is applicable).
