Like 'external' events, the events generated by the RGP are normalised and then forwarded to the rating engine to generate the appropriate charges.  Real-time recurring tariffs (for example, to charge for weekly access to video content) are not evaluated by the RGP.  They are evaluated when generating allocations for entitlements that are associated with real-time tariffs.  Tracking Revenue  Normalised event file transactions are generated during rating, when usage normalised events are rated and rating charges are generated, to track revenue.  The rating engine uses the rating subtotal cache to track accrued revenue generated from rated events.  The rating subtotal cache aggregates usage charges per normalised event file within an accounting period, guided to a specific GL guidance entity.  Rating Processes  While event normalisation and rating are displayed in the graphic as separate processes, both processes are combined by the rating engine, converting events supplied as input to Convergent Billing for normalisation into rated events by using the tariffs defined for each service and customer.  For more information about the structure of the underlying processes, refer to the System Operations Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Billing
pages.text: During this stage, the normalised events and charges output by the rating engine are processed by the billing engine to generate billing data records.  Essentially, the billing engine is identical to the rating engine in that it applies tariffs to the input data to generate the output data and supports parallel tariffing, but there are two major differences.  Firstly, unlike the rating engine (which applies tariffs to individual data records), the billing engine applies tariffs to aggregated data records.  Aggregation means that the individual charges are aggregated (grouped) into one or more predefined groups for the purpose of obtaining a total value or charge for that grouping.  In general, charges are aggregated according to the predefined customer hierarchy so that totals can be obtained for normalised events, services, individual and child customer nodes, and customers.  Secondly, the tariffs applied to the aggregated records are generally discount tariffs (benefits) rather than charge tariffs.  For example, if a customer's usage is higher than a pre-set limit for the specified billing cycle then a volume discount could be applied to the total cost of the calls.  In addition, it is possible to generate:  Invoices, which are sent out to the customer for payment.  Temporary statements, which can be used for quality assurance purposes or for customer information.  Financial Reporting  During billing, the BGP creates GL guidance records to:  Map the correct GL codes to invoice transactions for rental and rental adjustment events.  Record the state changes for rating charges.  The BGP tracks the financial state change of a charge when an invoice is applied to a customer account.    Invoice receivable type history records are created based on the amounts aggregated to each accounts receivable GL code for Billed and Earned (BE) charges for each invoice.  For more information about GL guidance records and invoice receivable types, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Invoicing
pages.text: The final stages of the Convergent Billing rating and billing process involve the production and distribution of invoices.  During invoicing, the billed data records (both individual and aggregated) are combined with customer detail records and incorporated into an invoice template to generate a set of invoices.  Invoices can be produced according to scheduled invoice cycles in response to a customer or management enquiry.  Such cycles can be defined on any periodic basis required.

pages.title: Invoice Distribution
pages.text: When generated, invoices can be sorted into groups using multiple keys (for example, in a single pass, they can be sorted into states, then regions within states, and finally, postcodes within regions) and subsequently distributed in either hardcopy or softcopy formats using a number of different media.  Invoices consist of a number of sections, each section providing details about specific charges (or benefits) that have been applied.  The charges displayed can be for individual event records or for aggregated records.  For example, a standard invoice for a new retail customer would include three separate sections detailing the once-off charge for installation, recurring charges for line rental and appliance rental, and lastly details of charges for usage.    Typically usage charges for local calls are displayed as an aggregated total, whereas usage charges for STD and IDD calls are displayed as itemised and as an aggregated total.  The invoice templates use macros to 'pull in' the appropriate invoice sections.  For example, if a customer subscribes to a frequently-called number plan, an invoice section that details the monthly subscription and the calls to which the appropriate discount was applied, is pulled into the customer's standard invoice.  During product design, consider whether the values of tariffs and subtotals being defined need to be included in an invoice section.  Using an existing invoice section is possible, but it is more likely that a new invoice section will need to be defined.  In more complicated cases, a new invoice template may need to be defined.

pages.title: Rating Subtotal Options
pages.text: Rating subtotals are set for either a certain date range or for the customer's bill cycle.  If the subtotal is set for the customer's bill cycle, it obtains its aggregation date range from that customer node and uses this range when accessing the rating subtotal cache.  Rating subtotals do not generate charge records; that is, many of the billing subtotal attributes (applicable to charge record generation) do not apply to rating subtotals (for example, currency or receivable types).  A rating subtotal can be set up to use another subtotal as its aggregate base.  If a subtotal uses another subtotal's aggregation, it is a 'slave' to that 'master'.  There is a many-to-one relationship between slave and master subtotals (that is, a master can have many slaves, but a slave only one master).  Slaves cannot perform their own direct aggregation and are only able to retrieve the aggregated amount from their master.  When evaluated, slave subtotals calculate their aggregation period and then use their master subtotal's ID to retrieve from the Rating Subtotal cache the sum of the master's aggregation periods equivalent to the slave's aggregation period.  Master and slave subtotal relationships have the following restrictions:  A master subtotal and its slave must share the same context.  A master subtotal and its slave must be of the same data type.  A slave subtotal may not have any terms and therefore may not perform any aggregation in its own right.  A slave subtotal's aggregation period must be a whole number multiple of the aggregation period of its master.  A master subtotal and its slave must have the same effective start and effective end dates.  If a slave subtotal is dependent on a bill cycle for its aggregation date range, either its master must also be dependent on a bill cycle or its master's aggregation date range must be a single day.

pages.title: Real-time Monitor (RTM)
pages.text: The Real-time Monitor (RTM) allows the real-time collection of data and the execution of alarms in a Convergent Billing environment.  Convergent Billing is deployed in environments where rapid detection and response to variation in critical metrics is required.  For example, a Commerce Engine deployment, where Singleview interfaces directly with the network, might require real-time statistics analysis.  If enabled, the RTM polls at a configurable frequency (for example, every ten seconds) for event data.  Event data can be selected from a number of sources (for example, UNIX machine statistics, Tuxedo performance statistics, Commerce Engine metrics).  The event data is passed through a set of alarm conditions, which can be defined to trigger an action such as a UNIX script or EPM function (for example, to forward an email message).  Event data is then written back to the tremon.  RTM event data held in the TRE monitor can be retrieved using GetStats.  RTM capability can be extended to provide a real-time graphical view of the statistics monitored by the RTM using a web browser.  For more information, contact the CSG International Contact Centre.  Related Topics  Statistics  System Monitoring and Tracing

pages.title: Real-time Rating (RTR)
pages.text: Real-time Rating (RTR) is an operating mode of the rating engine that allows a process or application on another system to send events to Convergent Billing, either singly or in a stream.  The rating engine processes these events as soon as possible then transmits each normalised event and its associated charges to a specified remote system.  RTR events can be written to the Convergent Billing database after rating.  Real-time Rating can operate:  As a pipeline, receiving events from one remote system and sending events and charge records to another.  When RTR is operating as a pipeline, records can also be input into the database.  As a circuit, where results are returned to the calling system.

pages.title: Rating Circuit
pages.text: Using the rating server (trerate) interface, events can be rated and their resultant charges returned to the caller.  An event that is associated with a reservation of customer credit is assigned a unique reservation ID.  The use of the Event Socket Interface (ESI) for a rating circuit is deprecated.

pages.title: Rating Pipeline
pages.text: A rating pipeline requires a specially configured Event Normalisation (ENM) process, listening on a named pipe or a TCP/IP socket connection for an incoming event.  When the ENM receives an event, the ENM normalises it and passes it to an Event Rating (ERT) process for rating in the normal way.  The resulting event and the charge records are passed to an Event Rating Output (ERO) process, which transmits the data to its configured destination.  The destination can be directly to the database, a remote host using a TCP/IP socket, or SQL*Loader files for later upload to the database.  If normalisation fails, or if the ERT fails to rate an event, an error event is passed to the ERO and no charges are output.  For the:  ENM, reading events from a TCP/IP socket is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  ERO, outputting normalised events and charges to a remote host using a TCP/IP socket, or to SQL*Loader files is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  SQL*Loader is not supported for rating events that perform real-time account updates or use rating subtotals.

pages.title: Real-time Rating (RTR) Message Exchange
pages.text: Communication between the RTR and a remote host consists of exchanges of data messages and acknowledgments.  The maximum size of each of these messages is 65536 bytes.  The originating system writes the event to be rated in an event message and sends it to the Convergent Billing process configured for RTR.  For each event received by the rating engine, either an acknowledgment message or an event error message is returned to the originator.  An acknowledgment is sent if the event was successfully decoded; otherwise, an event error message is sent which both locates the problem in the event record and indicates the reason for the error.  After normalisation and rating, the rating engine transmits each event, with its resultant charges, in a charge message.  The maximum number of charges that can be transmitted in a single charge message is 64.  In addition, the size of the resultant charge message cannot exceed 65536 bytes.  Of these 65536 bytes, 20480 bytes are reserved for encoded event details and an additional 228 bytes are reserved for Event Rating Protocol (ERP) overhead; therefore, the total number of bytes in all encoded charges in a single charge message cannot exceed 44828 bytes.  If an event generates too many charges to be output in a single charge message (that is, the size of the resultant charge message would exceed 65536 bytes), the rating engine outputs as many charges as possible in a single charge message.  Once an acknowledgment is received for this message, the rating engine transmits the remaining charges in additional charge messages until all the charges associated with the event have been sent.  For each charge message transmitted, the rating engine expects to receive an acknowledgment message before the next charge message is sent.  If a negative acknowledgment message is received, the rating engine re-transmits the charge message.  If an excessive number of negative acknowledgments are received for a charge message, or if no response is received, the rating engine transmits a diagnostic message and then closes the named pipe or TCP/IP socket connection.  If a message other than an acknowledgment or negative acknowledgment is received, the rating engine transmits a diagnostic message and then closes the connection.  Immediately before closing a connection, the rating engine transmits a diagnostic message using the connection to notify the remote host of the reason for the disconnection.  The rating engine transmits a diagnostic message and then closes the connection if:  An excessive number of negative acknowledgments are received for a charge message.  No response is received.  A message other than an acknowledgment or negative acknowledgment is received.  Reading events from a TCP/IP socket is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.

pages.title: Real-time Rating (RTR) Message Formats
pages.text: The protocol used for RTR messages is known as the Event Rating Protocol (ERP), and is designed for compatibility with other Convergent Billing message protocols.  Messages consist of ASCII characters and two reserved control characters in a byte stream with no parity.  ERP messages are generally comprised of variable-length fields with each field terminated by a field delimiter, which is an ASCII 0 (null) character.  Each field delimiter is denoted by a | character.  The first field in each message is called the length field.  The length field is always eight bytes in length, and contains a text representation of the total (decimal) number of bytes in the message (including the length field itself and all field delimiters).  The maximum length of each message is therefore 65536 bytes.  The length field contains leading zeros.  Charge messages output by the rating engine include event records and charge records encoded in embedded format.  Each event record and charge record is prefixed with an ASCII 254 (decimal) character when encoded into a charge message.  Each record start byte is represented by a @ character.  Related Topics  Incoming Messages  Outgoing Responses  Outgoing Messages  Incoming Responses

pages.title: Real-time Rating (RTR) Network Interface
pages.text: The RTR interface to the rating engine is implemented using named pipes or Berkeley stream sockets over the internet domain.  The RTR interface uses the TCP component of TCP/IP.  Reading events from a TCP/IP socket is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  Related Topics  Connection Procedures  Disconnection Procedures

pages.title: Real-time Rating (RTR) Process Configuration
pages.text: The following processes need to be configured for RTR, in the order in which they should be configured.  The following processes are only applicable to rating pipelines.  For rating circuits, the rating server (trerate) should be used.  Related Topics  Event Rating (ERT) Process  Event Rating Output (ERO)  Event Normalisation (ENM) Process

pages.title: Real-time Tariffs
pages.text: To specify a real-time tariff, select one of the classes in the settings form and a new tab displays for the type of class selected.  In the new tab, select the Real-time Tariff? checkbox (the checkbox is unchecked by default).  Once selected, only fields appropriate to real-time tariffs become available.  When the Real-time Tariff? checkbox is selected on these tabs, Entity Type may be set to Product or Entitlement.

pages.title: Receivable Types
pages.text: Receivable types are accounting entities used to separate the amount owing on an invoice into individual charges such as rental charges, usage charges, and tax.  Receivable types are sub-divisions of the Accounts Receivable GL account.  In Convergent Billing, receivable type definitions are used to:  Separate the amount owing on an invoice into different components.  When payments and adjustments are applied to an invoice, the payment or adjustment amount is allocated to the receivable type components using an allocation algorithm (for example, based on the priority of the receivable type).  Generate invoice receivable type history records that represent the accounts receivable sub-ledger.  The invoice receivable type history can be reconciled against the balances of the accounts receivable amounts uploaded to an external GL system.  The invoice receivable type history records are viewed using the Receivable Type tab on the Invoice Detail form.  If the GL subsystem is enabled, at least one receivable type must be defined in Convergent Billing.   The use of receivable types without the GL subsystem enabled is deprecated and provided for backward compatibility only.  For more information, refer to Finance Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Reference Types
pages.text: A reference type is a defined list of items, known as reference items, which can be referenced throughout Convergent Billing.  Convergent Billing uses reference types extensively to present predefined options to users in the form of drop-down lists.  Reference types:  Allow specific values to be predefined.  Provide effective control over what is entered into a field.  Reduce the amount and level of field validation required.  Can be referenced from multiple forms.  Can be accessed throughout Convergent Billing and used in all aspects of product definition and use.  Reference types should be defined only when the reference items are constants.  If not constants, list types should be used in place of reference types.  To speed up definition of similar reference types, reference items can be copied from one reference type to another and modified as required.  For more information, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Reporting Entity
pages.text: Convergent Billing records the historical and current information about financial reporting entities for which sales journals are maintained and general ledger (GL) uploads are performed.  Each GL code in Convergent Billing is associated with a reporting entity.  The relationship between GL codes and reporting entities allows separate sales journals to be maintained for each reporting entity.  A reporting entity acts as a set of books. For example, a multi-national company might maintain one set of books for its US operations, and another for those based in the UK.

pages.title: Reports
pages.text: A report can be generated either periodically (for example, once per month) or immediately.  For periodic reports, a schedule is used to create tasks that run when the report is due.  Immediate reports are created by running one-off tasks.  Resulting reports can be printed or viewed on a client workstation in Microsoft Excel XML (default) or HTML.    Singleview-supplied reports are described in the Reports Guide for Singleview.    User-defined reports can be created and included in schedules run from the scheduler.

pages.title: Resource Management
pages.text: The Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) can control the execution of scheduled tasks based on the resource usage of running tasks.  A task can consume one or more system or Convergent Billing resources.  Resources can be physical (for example, system memory or hard disk read/write) or logical (for example, a report resource that limits the number of concurrently generated reports on an instance).  Resources are assigned to a task in the task’s schedule type definition.  Execution of a task is affected by:  Task incompatibility  A task is delayed because it requires access to a resource in use by another task.  Resource profiles  A task is delayed because it would increase the consumption of a resource above the defined level for a time period.  Task resource management is defined on the Resources tab of the Schedule Type Definition form.    A graphical task viewer is available to assist in monitoring current and expected resource usage.  The viewer is generated by the Graphical Task View Search form.

pages.title: Sales and Cash Receipts Journal
pages.text: A Sales and Cash Receipts Journal (in Singleview, referred to as a Sales Journal) tracks financial transactions related to sales to customers, including payments, adjustments, and credit.  Transactions are associated with GL codes (for sales, indirectly using a GL guidance entity).    GL codes are usually defined in a hierarchical manner to group similar transactions for summarisation at varying levels. In the Convergent Billing database, GL codes are associated with a reporting entity, providing a separate sales journal for each reporting entity.  Convergent Billing internally groups and records sales journal transactions, and associates the transactions with an accounting period.  At the end of each accounting period, sales journal entries can be extracted and posted to an external general ledger system.  The Sales Journal records the following types of transactions:   Revenue for all sales made against a Convergent Billing account, which are rated or billed by Convergent Billing.  Payments made to customer accounts, including payments against postpaid and prepaid accounts.   Adjustments made against customer accounts.  The Sales Journal also reflects the change of state of a transaction; for example, the change of state from deferred (Billed but Unearned (BUE)) to recognised (Billed and Earned (BE)) revenue.

pages.title: Schedule Types
pages.text: Each schedule is assigned a schedule type.  The schedule type defines the type of task to create, the program that the schedule task will run, and the parameters required.  Defines when an activity (or task) will be executed and the frequency at which that task will be executed.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Pre-schedule Count and Task.  To define a schedule type, the following information is necessary:  Format of the command to be executed when a task based on this schedule type is run.  Details of any parameters the user may need to pass to the command at run time (for example, parameter type, order in which the parameters are expected, and which parameters are mandatory).

pages.title: Scheduled Functions
pages.text: Scheduled functions perform the scheduling of actions with time-based triggers and allow for re-evaluation if the function fails. A group of scheduled functions can be run in sequence. All scheduled functions can be rescheduled.    Scheduled functions are processed by the Scheduled Function Monitor (SFM) process.   When statistics are enabled, function scheduling details are reported to the tremon.    A scheduled function specifies:  Function to evaluate, and the function parameters.  When the function is to be run.  Effective date of evaluation.  Number of times that a scheduled function can be retried.  How often the scheduled function can be retried.   Convergent Billing instance the schedule is run on.

pages.title: Scheduled Functions Monitor (SFM) Process
pages.text: The Scheduled Function Monitor (SFM) process is responsible for executing EPM functions in accordance with their schedule and sequence, if applicable.  The SFM updates the database to track the progress of a scheduled function evaluation and re-schedules any failed functions configured to be retried.    The SFM uses a thread pool for concurrent evaluation of scheduled functions.  The number of evaluation threads in the pool is configured using an interface definition.  Each thread has a database connection, TRE connection, and an EPM parser.

pages.title: Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) Process
pages.text: The Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) process is responsible for generating and queuing tasks in accordance with their schedule.  The tasks are launched by the Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) process.  When a client defines or modifies a schedule, its details are stored in the database.  At the same time, the client calls a TRE function, notifying the STD of the change.  The STD retrieves the schedule definition from the database and creates any new tasks required.  At the same time, if the Regenerate Tasks option is selected, the STD deletes any remaining tasks for the old schedule.  If the client modifies a task (for example, by resubmitting it), the STD is informed and adjusts its internal queue accordingly.  Acting as a UNIX daemon, the STD monitors all pending tasks, and instructs the TLM to launch each one at the appropriate time.  When the TLM notifies the STD that the task is complete, the STD notifies the originating client, either by posting a TRE event if the user is logged in, or by email.  If the schedule's end date is not reached, the STD generates a new task to maintain the pre-schedule count specified in the schedule definition.  In a multi-instance configuration, only one STD can be active.  One STD is used to support one TLM server per active server instance.

pages.title: Schedules
pages.text: Schedules are required to run tasks at specific times and frequencies in Convergent Billing.  Schedules are used to manage all billing tasks such as the rating of events, and the preparation and printing of invoices.  Schedules are also used to generate reports.  Tasks can be set up to run automatically at predefined intervals or at a specified time and date.  The schedule definition is determined in part by the associated schedule type.  When setting up a schedule, an instance on Convergent Billing can be specified to run the schedule.  If an instance is not specified, the schedule is run on the default instance defined for the scheduler.  (The default instance is defined in the STD configuration item.)  Preconfigured functions can be automatically executed on commencement or completion of a scheduled task, and notification messages provided to assist with system operations.  A schedule specifies:  When a task is to be run for the first time.  The Convergent Billing instance the schedule is run on.  The effective date (used as a base to compute the effective date for tasks that are created).  How often the task should be repeated.  What program the task needs to perform its function, and what parameters should be passed to it.  Selection parameters such as whether a report should include data on all customer nodes or only include data on a specific customer node.  Display parameters, such as whether the data included in a report is to be sorted, the sort order, and the sort sequence.

pages.title: Search Functions
pages.text: Functions to search the database make use of a WHERE clause and an optional ORDER BY clause that refer to the columns in the appropriate view.    The function returns an array of IDs of items that meet the requirements of the WHERE clause.

pages.title: Security
pages.text: Convergent Billing security defines which users have access to information and the type of access they have.  Client security is based on profiles that define security privileges for types of user.  Each user in Convergent Billing is associated with a single profile.    The profile defines whether a user is authenticated using an internal or external method.  User profiles also control login access for internal authentication.    A user can be associated with a person stored in the database, providing additional information about the user.  For more information about user, refer to the Security and Auditing Configuration Guide for Singleview.  Profiles are designed to provide access to the data and Convergent Billing forms required to carry out a user's function.  A profile is made up of one or more of the following four elements:  Security groups, which define the database entities that a user can access.  Security form roles, which define the menu items and forms available to a user.  Security function roles, which define the database remote functions that a user can access.  Work groups, which provide a mechanism for the management of customer queries.  Access levels define the level of security for the following profile entities:  Security Groups, restricting the operations a user can perform on data; for example, updating, inserting, and deleting records, or updating and deleting historical records.  Form roles, restricting the kind of operations a user can perform using a specific form; for example, viewing, inserting, updating, and deleting records.  Some forms have form-specific operations; for example, restricting the ability to insert future-dated payments using the Payment Details form.  Work groups, restricting a user's ability to view, insert, or update queries for a work group.  A user definition cannot be defined until the appropriate security profile is defined.  The security profile cannot be defined until the appropriate form roles, security groups, and work groups have been defined.  If a person record needs to be associated to a user definition, the person record must be defined before the user definition is defined.

pages.title: Users
pages.text: Convergent Billing users are assigned a security profile, which provides the security privileges needed to perform specific tasks.  The information recorded for each user includes:  A user name and password, used for logging in to Convergent Billing.  Passwords are recorded and maintained by Convergent Billing only if internal authentication is enabled for the user.  A security profile, which defines the user's access to Convergent Billing and the database, and access privileges to data, menu items, and forms.  Personal information such as the full name of the user, email address, and contact telephone numbers.  A user record can also be assigned to a person record (of person type 'Employee'), where additional personal information can be recorded.  Additional company-specific information, defined using entity validation.

pages.title: Security Groups
pages.text: Security groups are used to control access to the data within the Singleview database.  Data belonging to a specific security group can only be seen by users who belong to the same security group.  The ability to modify or delete this data is further controlled by access level settings.  The primary security group is associated with operational data created associated with a profile. The configuration security group is associated with configuration data created and modified by users associated with this profile.  It defaults to the Primary Security Group.    Data attached to the either security group can only be seen by users who belong to the same security group, if the role defined in their profile allows access to the appropriate menu items and forms.  Users can belong to more than one security group.  The access privileges for a user belonging to the correct security group is determined by the access levels set in the security profile.  Users with sufficient access privileges can change the security group to which data is attached.  When the security group of data is changed, any encrypted data is automatically re-encrypted to ensure that all data within the security group is encrypted with the correct encryption key.   When the security group of an entity with child dependencies is changed, the data associated with the dependent child entities must be re-encrypted manually.  To re-encrypt data manually, use the biCustomerNodeReencrypt&() and biDerivedAttributeArrayReencrypt&() functions (see the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1)).

pages.title: Form Roles
pages.text: Form roles provide users with access to specific forms and menu items, and control the updating privileges required when working with each form.    A form role determines which forms can be accessed by a user, access level settings for each form, and whether the menu item for a form is greyed-out.

pages.title: Function Roles
pages.text: Function roles specify which functions a user, with the appropriate security settings, can execute using the TRE.    Function roles also define function aliasing; for example, if a user calls one function, the TRE executes the function that is defined as the alias in the function role for that user.  TRE function aliasing reduces the configuration costs by making it easier to implement the customer's business rules.

pages.title: Work Groups
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, a user or group of users responsible for progressing and resolving queries is called a work group.  A work group is similar to a security group in that queries are attached to a work group in the same way that data is attached to a security group.  To work with a query, the user profile must assign the user to the work group that created and progressed the query.  Work groups can often be based on workflow.  When planning work groups, map the workflow of the various groups.  The map provides the information required for determining the work groups that need to be defined and to whom they need to be assigned.

pages.title: Protected Data
pages.text: Data in Convergent Billing can be protected in the following ways:   Encryption  Data is encrypted in the database using a configurable algorithm.  Masking  Data is fully or partially hidden using a configurable mask when viewed by a user.  Protected data is hidden in all outputs, including debug, print, and trace files, and appears as a default mask of six asterisks ('******').  Access to protected data is controlled by user security group privileges.  Data protection is applied to a field on a form by configuring attribute type settings that are implemented using entity validation.    When configuring an attribute type for encryption or masking, the following restrictions apply:  Data protection can only be implemented on string-based fields, and therefore can only be implemented on attribute types based on:  Data type  Original field.  If encryption is configured on an attribute type with a data type of string, the Max Characters field must be set.  When implementing an attribute type configured for encryption or masking using entity validation, the following restrictions apply:  The attribute type can only be implemented on string fields.  In a derived attribute table, only results columns should be associated with an encryption attribute type.  Index columns are not supported for encryption.  If encryption is configured, the length of the encrypted value must not be greater than the size of the field.  For more information about data protection, refer to the Security and Auditing Configuration Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Server Licence Checks
pages.text: The Authentication server checks the licence when the BKR or BGP are started.    The Encryption Services Server (tresec) checks the licence when the server starts, to determine if encryption is enabled.    The licence status is checked at the start of every bill run by a call to biLicenceStatus&().  There is a minimum of 24 hours between licence entity checks by the BGP.  If a bill run is started within 24 hours of the last licence entity check, the licence entity is not checked.  If a bill run is started more than 24 hours after the last licence entity check, the licence entity is checked again.  If the licence entity check fails for any reason, biInvoiceGenerate&() does not run.  The BKR requests a licence check every 24 hours from its first successful start.  If the licence has expired, or if interference is detected by the Authentication server, an error is logged but the BKR does not shut down.  It is also recommended that the licence recalculation task be run every 24 hours.  If licence violation errors occur, perform the following steps:  Check that the LICENCE configuration item attributes are correct; if necessary, restore them to the correct values.  If the BKR still does not start, escalate the problem as required by company procedures.  Intervention by CSG International may be required to generate a new licence.

pages.title: Server Processes
pages.text: Convergent Billing uses a three-tier architecture, in which clients connect to the server by means of the Transaction Engine (TRE), an implementation of Tuxedo middleware.  The Tuxedo processes together make up the TRE, used for communication and inter-process control.  Server operations specific to Convergent Billing are controlled by a series of processes, all under the control of the Backend Monitor (BMP) process.  A control program, the Expression Control Program (ECP), is available for process control from the UNIX command line and in scripts.  All Convergent Billing processes and Tuxedo need to be running for Convergent Billing server operations.  The server processes are:  Billing  Rating  Other Server Processes.  Convergent Billing provides other processes used in bill generation and printing.  Bill generation and printing processes are run as required, rather than continuously.  Most server functions such as rating, invoice generation, database validation, and archiving, are run as independent tasks.  These tasks are usually scheduled from a client workstation, using the STD process, and run by the TLM process at the correct time.  The UNIX command line is not required for day-to-day operations.

pages.title: Tuxedo Processes
pages.text: The TRE requires these Tuxedo processes to be running:  BBL  ORATMS (2 instances)  TMUSREVT  trebgp  treigp  trerate  trergp  trerwdb  authsvr  trerodb  WSL  WSH  The above processes are started and stopped with Tuxedo commands tmboot -y and tmshutdown -y, normally executed within the sv_start and sv_stop server utilities.

pages.title: Backend Monitor Process (BMP)
pages.text: The Backend Monitor Process (BMP) is the monitor of all Convergent Billing processes.    The BMP can be started by the biBmpStart&(), biBmpStartAll&(), biBmpStart&(ProcessNum&), biBmpStart&(InstanceName$), or biBmpStartAlone&() ecp command, normally from within the sv_start utility.     It starts up and monitors the Event Rating Broker (BKR), Task Launch and Monitor (TLM), and Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) processes (if their Enabled flags are set to True).  Only one BMP process can exist for each Convergent Billing installation.

pages.title: Billing Processes
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a number of TRE servers, processes, and schedule types used for bill generation and output.  The GOP process runs when required, generally under the control of a schedule.  The TRE servers are started with the Convergent Billing server.  The billing servers and processes are:  Bill Generation Process (BGP), implemented as the TRE server trebgp.  Invoice Generation Process (IGP), implemented as the TRE server treigp.  Rental Generation Process (RGP), implemented as the TRE server trergp.  General Output Process (GOP).  The schedule types are:  Schedule types for bill runs  Schedule types for individual customers  Related schedule types.

pages.title: Rating Processes
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a number of processes and a TRE server used to generate rating information.  The processes are run when required, generally under the control of a schedule.  The TRE server is started with the Convergent Billing server.  The rating processes are:  Event Normalisation (ENM)  Event Rating (ERT)  Event Rating Output (ERO)  Event Rating Broker (BKR)  Rating Server (trerate)  Transactional Rating Server (trerate_tran).

pages.title: Other Server Processes
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a number of server processes other than rating and billing.  Some of the functions of these processes are to monitor and control other processes, generate tasks, interact with the TRE, and evaluate expressions and functions in Convergent Billing.  Other server processes are generally called from within another process.  The server processes (other than rating and billing) are:  Authentication Server  Backend Monitor Process (BMP)  Expression Control Program (ECP)  Scheduled Function Monitor (SFM)  Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD)  Task Launch and Monitor (TLM)  Tuxedo Handler Process (THP)  Tuxedo Queue Forwarder (TQF)  Variable Information Viewer (VIV).

pages.title: Service Types
pages.text: When creating a product offering for a customer, one or more services must be specified as part of a product offering.  As the services available at any one time vary depending on locality and availability, it is impractical for a product administrator to define a product using specific services.  For this reason, it is necessary to define the service components of a product more generically in terms of service types.  Defining the type (or category) of service has the following advantages over hardcoding a service into a product offering:  Flexibility  The user can offer one of several equivalent services, rather than being restricted to a single service offering.  Maintainability  The list of available services (having the specified service type) can be modified whenever required without affecting the product offering.  Easy introduction of new services  New services can be introduced whenever they are required, without affecting the costing of the product offering.  Up-to-date  The user is always able to select the current services associated with a specific service type.  Customisation  The list of available services can be customised to reflect local conditions and current market trends.  Service types can also define generic and default values for the services associated with that type and to define any service attributes for a specific service.  For example, default values for the types and quantities of equipment required by services of the specified service type can be defined.  Defining service types to be used in a product is a two step process:  Determine whether the service type exists.  Define a new service type (if required).  For inclusion in a product definition, it is only necessary to define the service type to be used; it is not necessary to define the services to be used as these have no bearing on how the product is defined or rated.  The services associated with a service type are defined by a user when they create a service instance for each service type specified in the product instance.  When a companion product is created, the service type of the base product must also be included in the companion product's list of service types; otherwise, the companion products tariff is not applied.  Other service types can be listed in the companion product definition, but the base product's service type is mandatory.

pages.title: Services
pages.text: A service is a specific component of a product for which the customer is charged.  Each service has an associated service type, and unique service number against which usage is charged.  One or more facilities (service options) and/or items of equipment may be associated with each service.  Physical components required to provide a service; for example, modem, leased line, or mobile phone.  Equipment information is stored for information purposes only, but can also be used to allocate service numbers.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Service.  Service option (for example, Call Waiting).  A facility can be regarded as a logical attribute of a service.  Facilities cannot be included in a product directly; they must be defined as part of a facility group.  Usage of a facility is billed against the corresponding service.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Configuration Studio  See also Facility Group, Facility Group Compatibility, and Service.  Specifies any defaults or entity validation for services specified with that type.  If required, an icon can be specified to identify each service type.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Icon and Service.  Refer to Base Product and Companion Product.  A service can be created while assigning a product instance to a customer, or at some later time.  Until each of the services associated with a product is created, that product cannot be made active.  Specific combination of services and the associated tariff structure offered to a customer based on the framework provided by the corresponding product definition.  The original product definition is preserved, with the product instance being tailored to a specific customer's requirements.  Any changes made to the product definition affect only product instances created after the changes are made, not existing product instances.  Referred to as a Purchased Product in Customer Management.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Product Definition and Product Model.  Services can be added to product instances cancelled at a future date.  However, services cannot be added to product instances that have a future status of Moved or Upgraded.  A service cannot be updated to a status of Product Creation, and cannot be updated when it has a status of Product Creation or Cancelled.  A service cannot be cancelled if it leaves the product instance incomplete as of the cancellation date or in the future.  Services are automatically cancelled if the product instance is cancelled.  A service can only be cancelled if it:   Is in View Only mode.  Has no future service records.  Is not in a status of Product Creation, Cancelled, Moved, or Upgraded.  Has no unallocated service or equipment items associated with the base product instance (that is, the base product instance is Active).  A service can be deleted only if it:  Does not have future service records.  Is in a status of Product Creation.  Is in View Only mode.

pages.title: Single Sign-on
pages.text: Single sign-on provides the ability to connect to Singleview without the need to re-authenticate, based on the authentication provided by an external application (for example, Microsoft Windows).  Single sign-on uses external authentication to share authentication data from other systems.

pages.title: Singleview Workflow Engine
pages.text: Singleview Business Process includes the Singleview Workflow Engine, which integrates Red Hat's JBoss Business Process Management (jBPM) workflow engine as an embedded process to provide all workflow capability.  jBPM is part of the JBoss Business Rules Management System (BRMS).  jBPM and Singleview can execute business processes described using Business Process Model and Notation (BPMN).  BPMN graphically represents business processes to aid communication between non-technical users and Singleview configurers.   Configuration Studio is integrated with an Eclipse-based graphical BPMN editor, which is available as an optional Configuration Studio plug-in.  For more information, refer to the Business Process Management for Singleview.

pages.title: SQL Search Examples
pages.text: Simple Examples  The following table lists simple examples of the SQL searches (assuming performing a product definition search on the product name).  Expression  Retrieves  = 'aa' or product_name = 'bb'  Products with names 'aa' and 'bb'.  in ('aa', 'bb')  Products with names 'aa' and 'bb'.  like 'B%' or product_name like 'C%'  All products with names that begin with 'B' or 'C'.  Complex Examples  More complex searches can be performed by using other database table fields for the entity as part of the search criteria.  The following table lists more complex examples.
