pages.title: Statements
pages.text: Statements provide a record of the charges billed to a customer and are provided only for the customer’s information.  The following can be viewed:  Details of each statement generated for a customer, including statement number, account number, total amount, and details of each transaction.  Electronic copy (image) of the printed statement sent to the customer.  Image of the statement immediately after it is generated.  Statements are generated only if the report level of the customer node is set to Statement.  Any charges resulting from the use of services at a customer node where the report level is Statement must be billed to an account on a customer node where the report level is set to Invoice.  The flexibility of Convergent Billing allows this invoice account to be an account on a node in the same customer hierarchy or on a node in a different hierarchy.  The appearance of a statement, level of detail it contains, and frequency at which it is generated are specified for a customer when that customer’s details are recorded in Convergent Billing.  The frequency at which a customer is sent a statement is determined by the required invoice cycle.  The level of detail displayed on the statement and its layout are determined by the required invoice format.  When generated, each statement is assigned a statement number by which it can be referenced.

pages.title: Statistics
pages.text: Convergent Billing offers a comprehensive package of schedule types and utilities that enable statistics gathering.  Some of the statistics functions and schedule types return information directly back to the caller, and others send information to the TRE Monitor event cache.  All statistics are produced by individual servers (or processes) and sent to the TRE Monitor server (tremon), which is the Convergent Billing server that controls all gathered statistics data.  The GetStats tool manages the process of logging, gathering, and printing statistics.  GetStats can display all statistics collected and sent by schedule types, scripts, methods, or functions to the tremon.  GetStats can also collect and display statistics for all Convergent Billing servers and caches.    For more information about GetStats, refer to the Performance Guide for Singleview.  Related Topic  Real Time Monitor (RTM)

pages.title: Subtotal Definition
pages.text: Subtotals can have an application environment of either Rating or Billing and a context must be specified.  Customer contexts can also be created using keyed subtotals.  Terms for rating subtotals can only have an evaluation context of Normalised Event or Charge.  Subtotal with a data type of array or hash.  A value is calculated for each value of the key in the aggregation set, so that multiple values are returned for a single subtotal.  Keyed subtotals are often used in conjunction with keyed tariffs and keyed derived attributes, to provide tiered discounts, or aggregation for related products.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Aggregation, Subtotal, Keyed Tariff, and Subtotal Term.  When defining a subtotal, its status, which can be set to Active (the subtotal is in use), or Trial (the subtotal is being tested or undergoing trials) can be specified.  Subtotals are available to the billing engine for a billing run, regardless of the status.  By default, the value of a persistent subtotal is stored and used in the future (for example, in conjunction with user-defined functions).  For example, permanent (or persistent) storage of subtotal values allows the charges for the current billing period to be compared with the last billing period or with the same billing period for the previous year.  A subtotal is defined by one or more subtotal terms.  For more information about subtotal terms, refer to the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  The subtotal name must be unique for the date range of the subtotal when compared to all other variables (for example, functions, derived attributes, subtotals, tariffs, and direct variables).  The rules for naming are:  For a scalar data type, the name and data type combination must be unique when compared to other variables.  For a hash type, the name must be unique when compared to other hash type variables.  For an array type, the name must be unique when compared to other array type variables.

pages.title: Subtotals
pages.text: Individual costed data records (billing data) often need to be aggregated so that totals for a service, customer node, or customer can be displayed on the customer’s invoice.  In large organisations, several levels of aggregation may be required for full breakdown of the total charges into charges for specific departments or types of service.  Event and charge details also need to be aggregated so that accurate calculations can be made for real-time services.  Credit monitoring of postpaid customers requires real-time access to the customer account information (including account balance, current outstanding usage amounts, and the customer's credit limit).  To provide these services, Convergent Billing allows individual costed data records to be aggregated (or subtotalled) in the billing engine at each level of the customer hierarchy.  Rating aggregations are supported for individual customers and services.   To facilitate the storage of aggregations, Convergent Billing supports a special type of variable known as a subtotal.  A subtotal specifies one or more subtotal terms that define the aggregation to be performed using the method specified by one of the following aggregation functions:  Summation, in which the value of the subtotal is calculated by summing the values of a subtotal term for each match to a costed data record.  Minimum, in which the value of the subtotal is taken as the minimum calculated value of each eligible subtotal term.  Maximum, in which the value of the subtotal is taken as the maximum calculated value of each eligible subtotal term.  The only aggregation function supported for rating subtotals is summation (minimum and maximum aggregation is not supported).  For date type subtotals, only maximum and minimum aggregation is allowed.  The data type returned by each subtotal term must be the same as the data type defined for the subtotal.  Subtotals can have a data type of real, integer, real hash, or integer hash.  Billing subtotals can also have the data types of date, date hash, date array, real array, and integer array.    Subtotal terms are selected for aggregation in four stages. In the:  First stage, the costed data records to be aggregated are identified by application, context, and eligibility.  Second stage, subtotal eligibility criteria are evaluated to determine which subtotal definitions are applicable.  Third stage, the subtotal term is evaluated to calculate the value to be passed to the aggregation function.  Fourth stage, the specified aggregation function is applied to obtain the required subtotal.  A subtotal is defined as a variable so that the aggregated data value it contains is available for use in other expressions in the billing process.  Billing subtotals can be accessed using their variable name.  For example, one common use of a subtotal in the billing process is in discount tariff expressions, which are generally applied to aggregated billing data.  In these cases, the subtotal variable (containing the summed value of a set of costed data records) is used in the discount tariff expression to calculate the applicable discount.  Rating subtotals can be accessed during rating using their variable name in the same way that they are used in billing.  Rating subtotals can also be accessed and manually aggregated using available built-in EPM functions.  Some of these functions are only available during rating; it is only possible to aggregate the value of a rating subtotal by rating an event.  For more information about subtotals, refer to the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Summary of Change View
pages.text: A Summary of Change View form is used to define the parameters displayed on the Summary of Change form.  The Summary of Change form displays details of any changes made between two consecutive data records.  The parameters available for configuration on the Summary of Change form are column name, table name, date type, default column label, default group label, column entity validation, group control entity validation, and message fields.

pages.title: Summary of Changes
pages.text: The Summary of Change form is used to display details of specific changes made between two consecutive data records.  The information recorded on the form displays the name of the user who made the last change, date changes were made, and a detailed description of each change made between the current and previous data record.  Each form in Convergent Billing displays and maintains a Summary of Change form that is unique to that form.  For example, the History form and Customer Detail form display two different Summary of Change forms for the same customer details.

pages.title: Syntax for SQL Searches
pages.text: Date Functions  SYSDATE  TO_DATE(char[,fmt]) where fmt = 'DD/MM/YYYY HH24:MI:SS'  TO_CHAR(expr[,fmt]) where fmt = 'DD/MM/YYYY HH24:MI:SS'  Expressions and Conditions  Syntax for Expressions and Expression Lists  Syntax for Conditions  Operators  The following type of operators is supported:  Comparison (SQL) Operators

pages.title: System Monitoring and Tracing
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a number tools useful to an administrator.  Statistical information, and traces, can be used to optimise Convergent Billing processes.  For example, event rating can be used to produce more versatile rating plans.  Statistical and monitoring tools provide support for:  Process tracing  Event rating evaluation  Process statistics  UNIX statistics  Oracle statistics  Tuxedo statistics  Java TRE API statistics  C TRE API statistics.  Interfaces  Processes and components can be evaluated and monitored using schedule types, Convergent Billing client forms, scripts, and functions.  Log files  All trace and debugging information is sent to central server or client log files, which can then be easily viewed using log viewing tools.  TRE Monitor (tremon)  Statistical schedule types, scripts, and functions either return information directly to the caller or store it with the TRE Monitor (tremon).  Information stored in the tremon's event cache can later be retrieved using the process name.    Statistical information can be sent to the tremon's log file.  The log file uses the XML syntax, enabling later translation into other formats. The GetStats tool is designed to make the collecting and output of statistics information easier.  Related Topic  Real Time Monitor (RTM)

pages.title: Table Partitioning and Scalability
pages.text: Partitioning handles the problem of supporting very large tables and indexes by allowing them to be split up.  Partitions increase efficiency by splitting up large tables or indexes into smaller and more manageable sections.  Table partitions are defined during implementation as part of the database build process.  When planning table partitions, future growth should be considered.  Ideally, the process of creating table partitions should be a one-off build process.   Partitioning is used by the following two types of scalability to improve performance:  Vertical  Used for a single instance, and involves partitioning a specified subset of tables by date.    Horizontal  Used for multiple instances, and partitions all tables containing customer instance data on the primary identifier for the table.  For information about the architecture of Convergent Billing for vertical and horizontal scalability, refer to the Architecture Overview for Singleview.  Convergent Billing supports the use of the Oracle partitioning option for the management of data in the Convergent Billing database.  The tables that can be partitioned are defined in the TablePartition derived attribute table.  CHARGE  DOWNLOAD_AUDIT  ENTITLEMENT  ENTITLEMENT_ALLOC_DELTA  ENTITLEMENT_ALLOCATION  ENTITLEMENT_HISTORY  EXTERNAL_DEFN_AUDIT  FILE_REGISTER  FILE_REGISTER_RECORD  NEF_GL_GUIDANCE_DELTA   NORMALISED_EVENT  NORMALISED_EVENT_ERROR  SCHEDULED_FUNC_WORKITEM  SCHEDULED_FUNCTION  SUBTOTAL_RATING_DELTA  SUBTOTAL_RATING_VALUE  UPLOAD_AUDIT.   Partitioning is recommended to:  Improve rating performance.  Improve billing performance.  Simplify archiving of old event, charge, and subtotal data.  Simplify database administration tasks associated with tables.  Convergent Billing provides the capability to define and manage table partitions using the Table Partition Definition form.  Local partitioning indexes are used for each table.  Schedule types are supplied to automate most activities associated with the creation and maintenance of partitions on the tables.  For more information about:  Table partitioning, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Oracle partitioning features, refer to Oracle documentation (for example, the Oracle Concepts Guide).

pages.title: Tariffs
pages.text: Tariffs specify the charges and benefits to be applied to events, and the rules for applying them, to calculate cost information.  Because tariffs can result in both positive and negative values being billed to a customer, the following terms are used to differentiate between the different types of tariffs:  Usage tariff  Calculates the charges owed by a customer for use of services, equipment, and facilities.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Equipment, Facility, Service, and Tariff.  Discount tariff  Tariff that reduces the amount owed by a customer.  Discount tariffs are usually aimed at fostering customer loyalty.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Tariff.  Tax tariff   Tariff that calculates the amount of tax to be paid to the Taxation Department.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Tariff.  Recurring tariff  Comparative tariff.  Tariff that calculates the amount that a customer would have been charged if they used an alternative rating program such as a special volume usage program or a competitor's product.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Tariff.  Tariffs can also be used with entitlements to consume allocations in real time.  Real-time tariffs can be used to generate activation, cancellation, or recurring charges (see the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing).  A tariff is a variable, the value of which is defined by a charge expression.  Like other expressions defined in Convergent Billing, the charge expression consists of operators and variables (known as charge values) that, when evaluated, returns a single value.  Usually the relevant charge values for inclusion in the charge expression are obtained from a table of values, known as a tariff table.  The tariff table associates each set of charge values with a set of conditions (also contained in the tariff table).  The conditional expressions defined for each condition determine which set of charge values are to be used in the charge expression.  To calculate a specific tariff, a set of input values from an event record is compared to each set of conditions defined in the tariff table.  When the first set of conditions is reached that matches the set of input values, the charge values associated with that set of conditions are substituted into the charge expression.  The expression is then evaluated and a value for the tariff returned.  Every condition in a set of conditions must be satisfied by the input values for a match to be found.  If no match is found, a default charge expression is used to return a value for the tariff.  To restrict the number of tariffs applied to an event, the 'pool' of available tariffs must be reduced by selectively reducing the number of tariffs applicable to that event.  For example, when the rating engine is used to rate a normalised event, the rating engine selects from the full list of valid tariffs:  All global tariffs (those in which the Global Event? check box is selected) and any tariffs where the application environment is set to Rating and the context is set to Normalised Event.  Product-specific tariffs (defined during product definition and selected when the product instance is created for a customer).  Product specific tariffs form the set of tariffs associated with each service defined in the product and are therefore the only set of tariffs that can be applied to this customer using this service.  Tariffs with the highest priority that have the same type, application environment, and context.  Context:  Convergent Billing  Attribute of a tariff that determines which tariff is applied in a product definition.  A tariff with a higher priority (lower numerical value) overrides a tariff with a lower priority (higher numerical value) only if they have the same type, application environment, and context.  A tariff with no priority cannot be overridden.  Context:  Process Engine  Used for cases and actions to be assigned a priority.  See also Tariff and Product Definition.  Tariffs whose eligibility criteria validate them for the event.  An invalid tariff is one that has a non-scalar data type and all its key expressions evaluate to undefined values.  All remaining tariffs are applied to the specified event.  Tariffs are used in both the rating and billing engines.  A specific tariff, however, can only be used in one or the other, depending on which application environment is specified in its definition.  Typically, usage and recurring tariffs are used in the rating engine, and discount, recurring, and tax tariffs are used in the billing engine:  In the rating engine, a tariff is applied to a normalised event record to generate a charge record.  In fact, multiple tariffs can be applied to the normalised event record, thereby generating multiple charge records from a single normalised event.  For example, both a usage tariff and a comparative tariff can be applied to a normalised event record to calculate the standard cost of that event, and the cost if the comparative rating plan is used.  In the billing engine, tariffs can be applied to charge records to generate billed data records.  For example, charge records for a customer can be aggregated to calculate the total amount owed by that customer for a specific service for the current billing period.  A discount tariff can then be applied to the total amount owed.  As in the rating engine, multiple tariffs can be applied to a single charge record in the billing engine.  A tax tariff can be applied to the total amount owed by a customer in addition to the discount tariff.  The billing engine can also apply multiple tariffs to aggregated charge records.  Tariffs generated at billing time (Billing application environment) should only be accessed by referencing the tariff as a variable (that is, by name).  Access to billing tariffs (or subtotals) using the following methods is not reliable and should not be used:  ChgInputBilledCharge#  SQL during the BGP operation to try and access CHARGE records generated by billing tariffs.   These two techniques only work if the internal processing order employed by the BGP is correct.  Because this order is not controlled by the configurer, it is impossible to ensure reliability of access using either method.  For more information about how context is processed, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Usually the cost information generated by a tariff is included on an invoice or a statement, but can be excluded if it is not required.  For example, a tariff can be specified as non-billable, in which case the tariff values are ignored when invoice data record values are passed to the invoice generation program.  Alternatively, a tariff that returns a zero value can either be recorded in the CHARGE table so that it can be included in any subtotals, or handled as a rating or billing error.  Keyed tariffs allow tariffs to be grouped so that multiple values can be applied to a single event.  In this way, a single tariff can replace a number of individual tariffs of the same type or generate multiple charges.  Keyed tariffs have a data type of Real Array or Real Hash and return an array of tariff values or a hash of tariff values, respectively.  To appreciate the power and flexibility of tariffs in Convergent Billing, it is first necessary to have an understanding of the generic components of tariffs including:  Derived Attributes  Direct Variables  Functions  Local Constants  Subtotals  Tariffs are specified in a two stage process:  Tariff definition, in which the basic properties of the tariff are entered, the structure of the tariff table is defined, and the charge expression for the tariff is entered.  Tariff table definition, in which values for the conditions and charges are entered into the tariff table.  The tariff name must be unique for the date range of the tariff when compared to all other variables (for example, functions, derived attributes, subtotals, tariffs, and direct variables).  The rules for naming are:  For a scalar data type, the name and data type combination must be unique when compared to other variables.  For a hash type, the name must be unique when compared to other hash type variables.  For an array type, the name must be unique when compared to other array type variables.  For more information on tariffs, refer to the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.

pages.title: Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) Process
pages.text: The Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) process is responsible for launching tasks created and queued by the Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) process, when the tasks start date arrives.  The TLM listens on a TCP/IP socket for instructions from the STD to launch a specified task.  When the task completes, the TLM adjusts the task status appropriately, writes the task output to the database, and informs the STD through the socket connection.  In a multi-instance configuration, there is one TLM per active server instance.  However, there is only one active STD server for all instances.

pages.title: Task Prerequisites
pages.text: Schedules and one-off tasks can be defined with prerequisites; that is, tasks that must be in a specified state before another task will run.  Prerequisite tasks allow complex operational frameworks to be defined to promote process automation and ensure tasks are run in the correct order.  For example, Tasks A and  B are prerequisites for Task C, and Task C must be completed before Task D can begin.  Prerequisite tasks do not have to be completed successfully to trigger the dependent task.  Tasks can also be defined to start whenever their prerequisite conditions are satisfied, regardless of the specified start date-time.

pages.title: Templates
pages.text: In Convergent Billing, the term 'invoicing' is used to cover the production of invoices (requiring payment) or statements (used only for reporting).  Invoices and statements can contain summarised information, line-by-line details, or a mixture of both.  The Invoice Generation Process (IGP) takes billing data from Convergent Billing (including direct variables and subtotals) and inserts them into an invoice or statement using a set of templates specified using the Invoicing tab and Invoice Format... button on the Customer Detail form.  Dunning letters to customers whose accounts are overdue are generated in the same way as invoices and statements, using templates into which the appropriate data is inserted.  Adjustment images (for example, credit and debit notes) represent adjustments created by a user and assigned to a customer account.  Adjustment images are generated using the Generate Adjustment Images task, and output using the Print Adjustments task.  Invoices, statements, adjustments, or dunning letters consist of a hierarchy of templates, based on predefined template types.  Each template type has a default database view associated with it, and the template can use any direct variable defined in the view, either by inserting its value directly in the document or by using it in expressions and functions.  Data can also be included from database views other than the default view for the specified template type.  The alternative view can be selected when creating a template, if the column names specified in the WHERE clause of the view’s SELECT statement are valid for the specified template type.  A template for an invoice, statement, adjustment image, or dunning letter typically contains the following elements:  Typographical and layout commands in XML, TEX, or IDTTeX page description language.  Substitution macros, to embed Convergent Billing billing data and other elements.  Static text and images, such as the company name, address, and logo.  Comments.

pages.title: Transaction Engine (TRE)
pages.text: Convergent Billing has a three-tier client/server architecture:  The first tier consists of clients, remote hosts, and external applications, using a workstation or remote functions to enter, inspect, modify data, and initiate server processes.  The second tier consists of:  Convergent Billing's expression-driven configuration and the Transaction Engine (TRE).  Configuration is used to reflect the customer's individual business logic.  The second tier manages transactions initiated from the first tier and returns results to the first tier.  Convergent Billing processes and the TRE services that clients can use for core business functions.  In addition, an Application Programming Interface (API) is available to provide other applications with access to TRE functionality.   The third tier is the Oracle database, in which business and administrative data is stored.  The TRE is the second tier of the Convergent Billing architecture and is a configured installation of Tuxedo middleware.  The TRE has the primary function of ensuring data exchange between clients, server processes, and the database.  EPM built-in, callback and user-defined functions supplied with Convergent Billing are called from EPM expressions and functions defined by the user.  The user may also define functions within a Tuxedo service, provided the appropriate service is configured.  The TRE consists of several server processes.  The processes are divided into two categories: Tuxedo processes, and Convergent Billing processes.  The following lists these processes:  Tuxedo processes:  Bulletin Board (BBL)  Transaction Management Server (ORATMS: two instances)  Workstation Listener (WSL) and Handler (WSH)  Convergent Billing processes  TRE named servers

pages.title: Bulletin Board
pages.text: The Bulletin Board is a Tuxedo component that shares information derived from the Tuxedo configuration file.  The bulletin board information base allows Tuxedo to perform dynamic client and server mappings while implementing functions such as load balancing, security, and transaction coordination.

pages.title: Transaction Management Server
pages.text: The Transaction Management Server (TMS), named ORATMS, is a Tuxedo server specifically configured to work with Oracle, using X/Open Distributed Transaction Processing (DTP).  The TMS is responsible for assigning identifiers to transactions, and monitoring and coordinating their progress.  Transactions are subject to a two phase commit process.  The first phase of this process ensures the transaction is committed only after all Resource Managers have guaranteed that each component of the transaction can be committed.  If this phase is not successful, the entire transaction is rolled back.  The second phase ensures the data is successfully written to the database.  The UBBCONFIG Tuxedo configuration file specifies that two ORATMS servers are started for load sharing purposes.

pages.title: Workstation Listeners and Handlers
pages.text: The Workstation Listener (WSL) is a Tuxedo server that enables workstation clients to access services using a network address.  A set of Workstation Handlers (WSH) represent the clients within the TRE.  The WSHs are started and stopped by the WSL as necessary to meet the incoming load from workstations.

pages.title: TRE Named Servers
pages.text: TRE named servers advertise services available to clients.  Each service is made up of one or more remote functions that carry out some operation within the service.  For example, the service designed to work with the person entity in the Convergent Billing database (biPerson) contains functions for locating, adding, updating, and deleting a person record in the database.  The named servers are:  Authentication Server (authsvr)  Bill Generation Server (trebgp)  Database Read-Only Server (trerodb)  Invoice Generation Server (treigp)  Monitor Services Server (tremon)  Rating Server (trerate)  Remote Services Server (treproxy)  Rental Generation Server (trergp)  Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) trap server (tresnmp)  Socket Interface Server (tresok)  Transactional Rating Server (trerate_tran)  Transactional Server (trerwdb)  All of these servers have common services, as follows:  biPurge  Receives events sent out when cached configuration (for example, functions or derived attribute tables) changes.  biTrcInvoice  Receives events that invoke a specified EPM function in the server with a given set of parameters.  biTrcInvoice is used to gather performance statistics from the servers.  biTrcMem  Processes the event that outputs a memory report for the server.  biTrcTre  Processes the event that activates or deactivates TRE message tracing.

pages.title: Transaction Engine (TRE) API
pages.text: The TRE is a configured installation of the Tuxedo transaction processing middleware, and the TRE API is available for C, Perl, Object Pascal, and Java programming languages.  The TRE performs the following functions:  Acts as the middle tier of a three-tier system in a client/server environment.  Provides a mechanism to communicate with external applications.  Enables external applications to access the database.  The TRE is used by client and server processes.  The TRE can also be used by external applications by means of the API, for the following purposes:  Calling TRE functions.  Grouping function calls into transactions, with the option to commit or roll back the transaction.  Queuing transactions.  Subscribing to TRE events, defining an event handler, and checking for events.  Posting TRE events.  For a summary of the TRE API function calls, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).  A detailed description of each TRE API function is included in Transaction Engine API.  Programming Constraints  Programming with the TRE API in all languages is subject to the following constraints:  The first TRE function call must be treConnect.  The last TRE function call must be treDisconnect.  Memory for arrays and pass-by-reference variables must be allocated using treMalloc or re-allocated using treRealloc if the size has changed, before any function call refers to the array or variable.

pages.title: Authentication Server (authsvr)
pages.text: The Authentication server provides a means of validating client entry to the TRE and enforces licensing conditions.  Each machine in a Singleview cluster must have its own Authentication server and, therefore, its own LICENCE configuration item.  If neither a configuration item sequence number nor a configuration item name is provided, the configuration details of LICENCE1 are loaded.  Command-line usage for the Authentication server is:  authsvr    [-- [-c <EnvConnectName>] <ConfigItemName>|<ConfigItemSeqNr>]  Parameters  Parameter  Description  -c <EnvConnectName>  Name of the environment variable holding the database connection string the Authentication server uses to connect to the database.  If not specified, the Authentication server uses the connection string specified in the ATASVRCONNECT environment variable.  <ConfigItemName>  Optional.  Configuration item name of a LICENCE configuration item, and is used for retrieving configuration information.  <ConfigItemSeqNr>  Optional.  Sequence number of a LICENCE configuration item, and is used to retrieve configuration information.  The LICENCE string can optionally be used to prefix the sequence number for readability purposes.

pages.title: trebgp
pages.text: The trebgp billing server runs the Bill Generation Process (BGP) and is used to create the information that is displayed on the customer's invoice or statement, using the costed events in the charge table.  The server provides the following services:  biBGP  Performs processing of events to create information displayed on invoices or statements.  biBGPEvent  Processes events used to communicate with the biBGP service.

pages.title: treigp
pages.text: The treigp billing server runs the Invoice Generation Process (IGP) that takes the invoice information generated by the Bill Generation Process (BGP) and creates invoice images using the names of templates associated with each customer.  The server provides the following services:  biIGP  Contains all of the functions to generate invoices and reports.  biIGPEvent  Processes events used to communicate with the biIGP service.

pages.title: tremon
pages.text: The tremon TRE server provides an interface for processes to log and query performance-related statistics for Convergent Billing and its related processes.  The server has only one service, biTreMon, that provides monitoring functions.

pages.title: trergp
pages.text: The trergp billing server runs the Rental Generation Process (RGP) that generates normalised events for recurring and one-off charges.   The Event Rating (ERT) process rates the normalised events.  When the RGP is run in rental adjustment mode, it is used to adjust recurring charges generated during a previous billing cycle.  The server provides the following services:  biRental  Contains all of the functions to generate rental events.  biRentalEvent  Processes events used to communicate with the biRental service.  Real-time tariffs are not processed by the RGP.

pages.title: treproxy
pages.text: The treproxy TRE server provides an interface service for communication with remote servers.  treproxy has only one service, biRService, which is used to connect to a Java TRE Server.  The Remote Services Server provides an interface to a remote service that is accessible using a TCP connection.

pages.title: trerate
pages.text: trerate is a rating server that provides event rate and return functionality, using EventRateAndReturn&() and related functions, or event rate and store functionality, using EventRateAndStore&() and related functions.    The different types of functionality rate an event and return the event and charges to the caller, or store them in the database.  The server provides the following services:  biTrerate  Contains all of the functions to rate events and return charge information.  biEvent  Contains all of the functions to rate events and store the charges in the database.  biCache  Contains cache access functions.  biEvtReprocess  Contains event reprocessing functions.

pages.title: trerate_tran
pages.text: trerate_tran is a rating server that provides transactional event rate and store functionality, using EventRateAndStoreTran&() and related functions, to rate an event and store it and any generated charges in the database as part of a Tuxedo transaction.   The server provides the biTrerateTran service, which contains all of the functions to rate events and store the charges in the database as part of a Tuxedo transaction.

pages.title: trerodb
pages.text: The trerodb read-only server provides database services that read data from the database.  The read-only server separates services that read database information from services that need to commit data, so that the transaction load is shared across the TRE servers.  Performance is also enhanced because fewer servers are required for data to be committed.  The server provides the following services:  biAccountRO  Remaps biAccount from the Transactional Server.  It can only be used for querying.  biCallDetFetch  Implements functions to perform call detail searches.  biConfig  Implements functions that perform configuration attribute queries against the database.  biConfigEvent  Processes events for the biConfig service.  biCommand  Implements functions that allow the execution of a specified command string on the server.  biEcp  Provides the interface between client commands using the Expression Control Program (ECP) and the server processes.  biEntity  Implements the biEntityNextId function.  biExprParse  Implements functions for parsing and validating EPM expressions.  biFnEvaluateRO  Remaps the biFnEvaluate service from the Transactional Server.  biFnFetchByName  Obtains the details of a function.  biFnFetchDetail  Returns function details such as the complete function definition, effective date range, service name, and flags.  biFnParse  Implements functions for parsing and validating EPM functions.  biHierFetch  Implements functions to perform customer hierarchy searches.  biMemReport  Implements functions for querying and controlling memory report data.  biNEFetch  Implements functions to perform normalised event error and normalised event searches.  biRefCodeEvent  Processes events to the biReferenceCde service.  biReferenceCde  Implements functions to retrieving reference code data.  biSQLQuery  Processes functions that perform SQL retrieval queries against the Convergent Billing database.  Each call is considered a separate transaction.  biSQLQueryEvent  Processes events for the biSQLQuery service.  biStatus  Implements functions for querying the Tuxedo Management Information Base (MIB).  biStd  Implements functions for communicating with the Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) process.  biTrcEpm  Processes the event for setting the EPM debug level.

pages.title: trerwdb
pages.text: The trerwdb Transactional Server is a general purpose server supporting global transactions using the Tuxedo two phase commit.  The Transactional Server advertises services that read and write to the database and ensures the integrity of the transactions.    The server provides the following services:  biAccount  Implements functions for querying and controlling account data.  biAccountEvent  Processes events for the biAccount service.  biAdjBatch  Processes functions that control and query adjustment batch data.  biAdjBatchEvent  Processes events for the biAdjBatch service.  biAdjustEvent  Processes events for the biAdjustment service.  biAdjustment  Implements functions that control and query adjustment data.  biContract  Performs processing for functions that query and control contact details.  biContractEvent  Performs processing for events used to communicate with the biContract service.  biCustNdeEvent  Processes events used to communicate with the biCustomerNode service.  biCustomerNode  Implements functions for querying and controlling customer node data.  biDerivedAttEvt  Processes events that communicate with the biDerivedAttr service.  biDerivedAttr  Implements derived attribute table maintenance functions where the storage context is Global or Global-Shared.  biEquipment  Implements functions for querying and controlling equipment data.  biEquipmentEvt  Processes events for the biEquipment service.  biFacGroup  Implements functions for querying and controlling facility group data.  biFacGroupEvent  Processes events for the biFacGroup service.  biFacGroupInst  Implements functions for querying and controlling facility group instance data.  biFacGrpInstEvt  Processes events for the biFacGroupInst service.  biFnEvaluate  Evaluates user defined EPM functions.  biInvoice  Implements functions for querying and controlling invoice data.  biInvoiceEvent  Processes events for the biInvoice service.  biPayBatchEvent  Processes events for the biPaymentBatch service.  biPayment  Implements functions for querying and controlling payment data.  biPaymentBatch  Implements functions for querying and controlling payment batch data.  biPaymentEvent  Processes events for the biPayment service.  biPerson  Implements functions for querying and controlling person data.  biPersonEvent  Processes events for the biPerson service.  biProdInstEvent  Processes events for the biProductInst service.  biProductInst  Implements functions for querying and controlling product instance data.  biProgress  Implements functions that control and query customer query progress data.  biProgressEvent  Processes events for the biProgress service.  biQuery  Implements functions for querying and controlling customer query data.  biQueryEvent  Processes events for the biQuery service.  biService  Implements functions for querying and controlling service data.  biServiceEvent  Processes events for the biService service.  biSQLExecEvent  Processes events for the biSQLExecute service.  biSQLExecute  Implements functions that perform SQL Data Manipulation Language (DML) queries against the Convergent Billing database.  The service is provided in read-write servers that can participate in global transactions.  biTrcEpm  Processes the event for setting the EPM debug level.

pages.title: tresnmp
pages.text: The tresnmp Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) trap server allows EPM code to send SNMP notifications to management stations.  SNMP offers help for managing networks.  Managed objects are defined in the MIB (Management Information Base), and an SNMP agent is responsible for tracking, and responding to, object information notifications.  Notifications, or traps, are sent asynchronously (using the function biSnmpTrapSend&()) and are not acknowledged by the network management station.  SNMP notification receivers, or trap sinks, are defined in the tresnmp.conf file.    The tresnmp server advertises the biTresnmp mandatory service that performs the correct routing of SNMP trap invocations to the registered EPM callbacks.

pages.title: tresok
pages.text: The tresok Socket Interface Server provides socket interface services for communication with external processes.  The tresok server is activated only where a socket interface is required for a specific Convergent Billing instance.  The services advertised by the tresok server are configurable.    The service name advertised by a tresok server is defined in the TRESOKC configuration item.

pages.title: Unicode Support
pages.text: Unicode is a character encoding system designed to support all languages, regardless of platform, program, and programming language.  It provides a unique number, called a code point, for every character.  Convergent Billing supports Unicode in the following ways:  The Convergent Billing database, server, and TRE support Unicode, allowing data to be entered, viewed, and manipulated in multiple languages.  The Convergent Billing database and server support UTF-8 encoding.  The TRE supports both UTF-8 encoding and UTF-16 encoding, enabling integration with many applications that use UTF-16, including Windows.  The C, Pascal, and Java TRE clients support UTF-8 and UTF-16.  The Perl TRE clients support UTF-8.  A single Convergent Billing instance is capable of supporting multiple Windows clients, each using different character sets (however, only one character set per PC is supported).   Therefore, in an internationalisation context, data can be entered, viewed, and manipulated in the Convergent Billing client in any language supported by the character set of the PC's locale.  The following constraints apply to Convergent Billing's support of Unicode:  The Convergent Billing client is not Unicode enabled, so when Unicode is used, conversions are performed between Unicode and the character set as defined by the PC's locale.  Separate client machines are required for each distinct character set as each Convergent Billing client can only correctly display characters corresponding to the locale for which the PC is configured.  In practice, a user can only work with one character set as configured on the PC they are working on.   ASCII is available in all character sets.  String columns in the Convergent Billing database are of fixed byte size; for example, the customer name column is 80 bytes.  As UTF-8 encoding is a variable length byte encoding between one and four bytes, depending on the characters stored in a column, the effective number of characters stored in a column may be fewer than the column size.  Process Engine and Process Engine business solutions (for example, Customer Management) do not support Unicode.  As Process Engine is not supported for Unicode, Process Engine cannot be used with a Convergent Billing installation.  For more information, refer to the Internationalisation Configuration Guide for Singleview.

pages.title: Variables
pages.text: Convergent Billing supports the following types of variables (see the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing):  Local Variables  Direct Variables  Entity Validation Variables.  Functions, Derived Attributes, Tariffs, and Subtotals are also regarded as variables in Convergent Billing because they return values.  With the exception of local variables whose scope is confined to the current expression block or function, the scope of a Convergent Billing variable is controlled by two attributes, the Application Environment and the Context.    Environment in which a variable or function is used.  Must be one of the following:  Any (for functions only)  Billing  Data Entry  EVS (for Entity Validation Server (EVS) functions)  GL Guidance  IGP Report  Invoicing  PE  Rating  TRE Table (unavailable for functions).  Functions with an application environment of Any can be called from Convergent Billing or Process Engine.  The PE application environment is specific to Process Engine functions and direct variables defined in Process Engine.  Functions with an application environment of PE are read-only and cannot be deleted.  All other application environments are specific to functions and variables defined in Convergent Billing.  Functions with an application environment of EVS are read-only and cannot be deleted.  They cannot be specified or updated in Convergent Billing or Process Engine.    Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Context and Variable.  Excluding all type suffixes, a name can have a length of up to 64 characters.  The first character of a variable name must be an upper or lower case letter or the '_' character.  Subsequent characters can also include numbers and the '.' and ':' characters.  An application environment of Any and a context of Any can only be given to a function that references only the parameters it is passed or other Any/Any functions.  Variables with other application environments or contexts may not be available in all circumstances in which the function could be called.  The PE application environment is reserved for Process Engine functions, and cannot be specified or updated in Convergent Billing.  Variables can be hidden from display using encryption or masking.

pages.title: Local Variables
pages.text: Local variables are those whose scope is limited to the current block of expressions or the current function.  Local variables can be of two kinds:  Local to an expression block or function, which are defined using the reserved keyword 'var'.  Local to an expression, which are prefixed with the '@' symbol.

pages.title: Hidden Variables
pages.text:
Variable values can be hidden in print, debug, and trace outputs by the conceal() function; the data is displayed as a fixed mask of six asterisks. Values remain hidden unless explicitly revealed by the reveal() function, or if the value is transformed by another EPM function. Most mathematical operations on a value result in a value that is not hidden; therefore, it cannot be assumed that an operation will propagate the hidden or revealed status of a value. The hidden status of a value always persists: Across assignments When values are passed to function parameters Across string operations on a value When a value is converted to a string value When two strings are concatenated (if one of the strings is hidden, the resultant concatenated string is also hidden). Hidden data is handled explicitly by the conceal() and reveal() functions, and can be checked using the is_concealed() function (see the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 2)). In the following example, a& and c& are hidden, but d& is not hidden and can be displayed: a& := conceal(b&);
c& := a&;
d& := abs(a&);

pages.title: Variables Declared with the @ Symbol
pages.text:
Local variables with scope only within a single expression are implicitly declared by Convergent Billing using the @ symbol. The variables are declared for use in expression in the client application. Location and description of variables declared with @ are listed in the following table. Form Containing Variable Variable Identifier Description Subtotal Definition @EffectiveDate Contains effective date of evaluation. Available only to From Date Expression and To Date Expression fields. contains type declaration character. Subtotal Definition @FromDate Contains the result of the From Date Expression field. Available only to To Date Expression field. contains type declaration character. Tariff Definition Derived Attribute Definition @
Contains value to evaluate tariff and derived attribute expressions in Variable Name field. is a user-declared variable followed by type declaration character (for example, @myKeyVariable$ or @tier1&). Forms using @value variable are listed below. @value Contains value for encoding and decoding sequence or serial numbers. contains type declaration character. Tariff Definition @charge1 to @charge10 Contains value that refers to charges defined in the Tariff Definition form. Each variable refers to one of the charges defined in the grid on the Charges tab (for more information, refer to the Customer Care and Product Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing). A variable with scope only within a single expression can be declared using the @ symbol. The most common example of this is the @value variable, used in the Convergent Billing client for encoding and decoding sequence or serial numbers. Users can define an expression to format the account number for a customer node by entering an expression such as: 'ACC' + to_string (@value&, '00000000') The expression takes the account ID of the account being declared in the database, converts it to a string of eight numerals, and prefixes it with the letters 'ACC'. The @value variable is used for the purposes listed in the following table. Form containing expression @value refers to Expression returns Account Type Account ID Account number Adjustment Type Adjustment ID Adjustment number Adjustment Type Adjustment Batch ID Adjustment Batch number Attribute Type User-entered value Field validation Customer Type Customer ID Customer number Derived Attribute List Entry Current item in list Equipment Type Equipment ID Serial No. (encode and decode) Equipment Type Equipment ID Network Address (encode and decode) Payment Type Payment ID Payment number Payment Type Receipt ID Receipt number Payment Type Payment Batch ID Batch Payment number

pages.title: Variables Declared with 'var'
pages.text:
Local variables are declared within an expression block or a function by using the var keyword. For example, var temp$ declares a local string variable, temp$. The following conditions apply: The variable must be of the correct type for the data it will contain. The variable has scope from its declaration up to the end of the expression block or function. Each variable must be declared on a separate line. Local variables take precedence over parameters, global variables, and other local variables of the same name. Each array or hash type variable must have a different name (excluding data type). For example, the following expression block returns an error stating that the a variable has been declared with the wrong data type: {
if (TRUE) {
var a&[] := [1];
} else {
var a$[] := ['No'];
}
} This restriction does not apply to scalar variables, or hash or array type variables with the same name and data type.

pages.title: Views
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides a comprehensive logical data model that can be externally accessed using views.  Views provide a universal, stable, and less complex interface than the physical database.  Views provide:  Reduced complexity  The physical data model for Singleview is a meta model and therefore difficult for third parties to access.  The logical data model is designed to minimise the meta model effect.  Data abstraction  Views represent the data in a format that reflects the service provider's conceptual view of the data (for example, customers, contacts, accounts, or products).  Access that can be upgraded  Any direct external access to the physical tables cannot be upgraded by core upgrades.  The logical data model provides an abstraction layer that helps protect investment placed in external development.  Convergent Billing provides the following types of views:  Normal  TRE  Database  TRE views and database views can be customised, allowing implementation-specific views to be preserved during upgrades.  For example, hints can be added to view definitions for performance tuning.  A knowledge of SQL and the purpose and use of each view is required for customising views.  For more information, refer to the Configuration Fundamentals Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  String Columns and Unicode  The string columns in the Convergent Billing database have fixed byte sizes.  Characters encoded using UTF-8 may be single-byte or multi-byte. Therefore, if UTF-8 encoding is being used (that is, Unicode is enabled in Convergent Billing), the effective number of characters that can be stored in a string column may be fewer than the column size, depending on the characters that make up the string.

pages.title: Normal Views
pages.text: Normal views are generally used when configuring the Convergent Billing client.  Direct variables are associated with specific normal database views.  In this way, database table values are available for reading, writing, and updating (where permitted).  All normal views use the naming syntax <table>_v.  For a list of normal views, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).

pages.title: TRE Views
pages.text: Functions that work with the Convergent Billing database operate through TRE views.  Each TRE view is a filtered representation of database tables and contains all the information required for the built-in functions in the corresponding Tuxedo service.  The combination of a TRE view and the accompanying service constitutes an abstraction of the database, providing a well-defined and secure access method.  The TRE views are the most appropriate way of externally accessing data stored in Convergent Billing.  All TRE views use the <table>_TRE_V naming syntax.  For a list of views on the Convergent Billing database provided for use by TRE functions, refer to the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1).

pages.title: Database Views
pages.text: Convergent Billing reports use any views or tables that exist in the database.  A separate set of reporting views is available specifically for user-defined reports to access the Convergent Billing database.  All database views use the <table>_cv naming syntax.  Convergent Billing restricts direct access to underlying data, using database views (see the Configurer's Reference Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing (Vol. 1)).

pages.title: Access Level Settings Form (Profile Definition – Security Groups)
pages.text: The Access Level Settings form is used to specify the security privileges (access levels) to be granted to a specified security group to access the data held in the Convergent Billing database.  Security feature that determines what a user can do and what data they are permitted to access.  Security is based on form roles and groups, which in combination, determine a user's privileges.  Each user is assigned a specific profile that defines the level of access for each role and group.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Group, User, User Profile, and Form Role.  Data belonging to a specific security group can only be viewed by users belonging to the same security group.  The access levels specified using this form can also control the privileges required to modify or delete the displayed data.  A selected check box indicates that the associated access level is granted.  Associated Actions  Viewing a Profile  To view a profile definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Profiles option.  The Profile Definition Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of profile definitions matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate profile definition and click the Detail… button, or double-click the appropriate profile definition. The Profile Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on security?  Defining a Profile  To define a profile definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Profiles option.  The Profile Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The Profile Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the appropriate data entry fields on the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on security?  Updating a Profile  To update a profile definition:  View the appropriate profile definition.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Profile Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the profile definition details as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on security?  Deleting a Profile  To delete a profile definition:  View the appropriate profile definition.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the profile is to be deleted.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Access Level Settings Form (Form Roles)
pages.text: The Access Level Settings form is used to specify security privileges (access levels) to be granted to a user to access specific forms and menu items.  Security feature that determines what a user can do and what data they are permitted to access.  Security is based on form roles and groups, which in combination, determine a user's privileges.  Each user is assigned a specific profile that defines the level of access for each role and group.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Group, User, User Profile, and Form Role. A selected check box indicates that the associated access level is granted.  Associated Actions  Viewing a Form Role  To view a form role:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Form Roles option. pages.title: Account History Form
pages.text: The Account History form is used to view details of a customer account.  General account details are displayed in the upper part of the form (for example, account number, currency, current balance, and date of the last account balance update).  The Aged Classification Totals group displays classification of a group of items or transactions.  The upper part of the form is used to specify whether or not the Current Balance, Unbilled Amount (or Current Amount), or Available Credit fields include, in addition to the amounts for this account, any amounts from relevant statement and reporting nodes by including rolled-up amounts.  Other fields may also be displayed, depending on account type.  The lower part of the form consists of the following tabs, for viewing specific details about the account:  Transactions  The Transactions tab displays each transaction (invoices, statements, payments, and adjustments) associated with the specified account.  Reservations  Whether the Reservations tab is displayed and, if so, which fields are displayed, is dependent on the account type.    The Reservations tab displays details of all current reservations for the account.  General  Whether the General tab is displayed and, if so, which fields are displayed, is dependent on the account type.  Display of the columns on the Transactions tab is configurable.  Associated Actions  Viewing a Customer Account  The method to access and view a customer’s account depends on whether the account number is known.  If the account number is known:  Select the Accounts @ Account History option. The Account History form is displayed.  Enter the account number in the Account Number field.  Press Tab or click the Refresh History button. Transaction details associated with the specified account are displayed including the account balance.  If the account number is not known:  View the Customer Details Form for the customer.  To view the primary account, click the Account History… button.  The Account History form is displayed with details of the primary account including the account balance.  To view a secondary account, click the Other Accounts… button.  The Other Accounts for Customer form is displayed listing the secondary accounts (if any) assigned to the specified customer.  Double-click the account to be viewed or select the account and click the Account History… button.  The Account History form is displayed with details of the specified secondary account.  Need more information on accounts?  Viewing a Specific Transaction  To view an account transaction:  View the account history for the relevant customer.  Display the required transaction entry in the lower part of the form by scrolling through the list of transactions.  Double-click the transaction to be viewed, or select the transaction and click the Details… button.  The appropriate form is displayed in View Only mode with details of the selected transaction.  Transaction Selected  Form Displayed  Invoice  Invoice Detail form  Statement  Statement Detail form  Payment  Individual Payment Detail form  Adjustment  Individual Adjustment Detail form  Need more information on accounts?

pages.title: Account Number Search Form
pages.text: The Account Number Search form is used to search for one or more account numbers using a specific field, criteria, and method.  Unique account to which financial transactions are posted.  Each customer has at least one account (known as the primary account) and optionally one or more secondary accounts.  Each account has a unique account number by which it is identified.  See also Account Type.  The lower part of the form is used to list each of the account numbers returned by the search that matches the specified criteria.  The form is used with the Charge Category form in Update mode. The account number can be selected (by highlighting the Account Number field) and then assigned to the account (using the Assign button on the Charge Category form).  Associated Actions  Viewing a Charge Category  To view a charge category:  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Charge Categories option. The Charge Category Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button. A list of the defined charge categories matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate charge category and click the Detail... button, or double-click the appropriate charge category.  The Charge Category Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on charge categories?  Charge Category Examples  A charge category specifies an account type and, optionally, an account, to which a tariff’s charge or benefit is posted, and is an essential part of tariffing.  Another account type can also be defined and, optionally, an account, to which a balancing (opposite) entry can be posted (known as the ‘from’ account).  The term ‘tariff/charge category pair’ is often used to emphasise that the two objects are independent, but always go together.  Charge categories cannot reference account types that permit multiple accounts of the same type on a customer node.  The account inferred from an account type assigned to a charge category must be unambiguous.  A charge category instance is created for every tariff used by a service whenever a product containing the service is sold, creating a product instance.  The charge category instance is located at the customer node, the customer (root node), or the service level, depending on the context defined for the associated tariff.  A different instance of the charge category can exist at each level, for use by tariffs with different contexts.  A charge category instance is created using values from the default charge category specified in the appropriate tariff configuration.  The values used can be overridden.  Only one instance of the charge category is created at each location, no matter how many services reference the tariff.  Any defaults for services after the first are ignored.  A charge category instance can be re-defined so that proportions of a charge are posted to more than one account.  They can also be edited after creation, to redirect payments to a different account.  When the rating or billing engine processes an event, the process involves looking up details of the service stored at the customer node, identifying the applicable tariffs, and then using the tariffs to calculate the value of each charge or benefit.  The appropriate charge category instance is then used to identify the account.  The combination of the charge and the account information makes up the charge record in the CHARGE table of the database.  A charge category instance can also define a GL code to assign to the charge or benefit, if required.  However, using charge categories to assign GL codes is deprecated and provided for backward compatibility only. GL codes are assigned to charges using GL guidance (for more information, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview).  Defining a Charge Category  To define a default charge category:  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Charge Categories option.  The Charge Category Search form is displayed.  Click the New... button.  The Charge Category Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the appropriate data entry fields on the form.  If required, assign the appropriate account number.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on charge categories?  Updating a Charge Category  To update a default charge category:  View the appropriate charge category.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Charge Category Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the charge category details as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on charge categories?  Deleting a Charge Category  To delete a default charge category:  View the appropriate charge category.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the charge category is to be deleted.  Need more information on charge categories?

pages.title: Account Type Definition Form
pages.text: The Account Type Definition form is used to view, define, and update an account type.  Specifies any defaults or entity validation for accounts specified with that type.  Account types are used in the definition of charge categories, payment types, adjustment types, and customer types to specify the type of account to which charges are applied.   Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Configuration Studio  See also Account and Charge Category. pages.title: Adjustment Batch Form
pages.text: The Adjustment Batch form is used to enter, view, and update adjustments of the same type to be processed as part of an adjustment batch, and to apply the adjustment batch (that is, post the adjustments within that batch to their respective accounts).  Set of individual adjustments of the same type processed at the same time.  Each adjustment within the batch can be viewed or modified until the batch is applied (processed).  An adjustment batch can be created incrementally (one or more adjustments at a time) over a period of time.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Adjustment.  Transaction outside of the normal billing cycle transactions (namely, invoices and payments) that affects the outstanding balance of a customer's account.  An adjustment is recorded against a specific customer's account and optionally against one or more specified invoices.  Debit and credit notes are commonly referred to as adjustments in Convergent Billing.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Singleview  See also Adjustment Batch, Adjustment Type, Payment, Debit Note, and Credit Note.  The form also provides facilities to un-apply an applied adjustment batch.  The upper part of the form displays:  General details about the adjustment batch such as its description, types of adjustment it contains, and the type of batch  Read-only fields with information about the adjustment batch, such as the date it is recorded and its current status.  The lower part of the form lists each of the adjustments processed (or to be processed) as part of the batch.  The Invoices… button is enabled if the View Invoice Allocation access level is selected for the Adjustment Batch form in a user's form role and the Credit Account Number for the selected adjustment is a prime account.    Clicking on the Invoices… button displays the Invoices for Adjustment form to allow viewing of invoice allocations for individual adjustments within a batch.  If the Update Invoice Allocation access level is selected for the Adjustment Batch form in a user's form role, the user can also update individual adjustments within a batch, using the Invoices for Adjustment form.    For information about setting form role access levels, refer to Update a Form Role.  The form can be displayed in one of three form modes; the current mode is indicated in the form’s title.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  An adjustment batch number is assigned automatically by Convergent Billing when the first adjustment in a batch is saved.  Associated Actions  Creating an Adjustment Batch  To create an adjustment batch:  Collate adjustments into batches (groups) of the same adjustment type.  Select the Accounts @ Adjustments @ New Batch Adjustment option.  The Adjustment Batch Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Enter a description of this batch in the Description field.  The description entry is used to identify the batch at a later date.  Select the appropriate adjustment type and batch type.  Enter the account number or invoice number in the appropriate columns associated with the adjustment and press the Tab key. An adjustment number is assigned to the adjustment and displayed in the first column of the current row.  The account number or invoice number is verified against the account details held in the system and, if valid, corresponding account and invoice details are displayed in the relevant columns.  If invalid, a warning message is displayed on the Status bar.  To rectify this, click the Delete button and enter a valid account or invoice number.  Ensure that the customer name is correct.  If not, a valid, but incorrect account or invoice number has probably been entered.  To rectify this, click the Delete button to remove the row, click the Insert button to insert a new row, and re-enter the account or invoice number.  If there is a selected invoice for the account, the invoice number appears in the Invoice column.  Enter the amount of the adjustment in the Amount column, and press the Tab key.  The Invoices for Adjustment form is displayed in Update mode.  If there are a number of invoices against the account, the word 'Split' appears in the Invoice column.  Enter the amount of the adjustment in the Amount column, and press the Tab key.  The Invoices for Adjustment form is displayed in Update mode.  Allocate an amount to one or more of the listed invoices as required.  When an adjustment is being recorded, it (or part thereof) can be allocated to one or more of the outstanding invoices or simply recorded as a credit (or debit if it is a negative adjustment).  Recording an adjustment as a credit or debit (rather than against a specific invoice) may be necessary if, for example, it is not clear which invoice should be allocated the adjustment.  When an adjustment is made, Singleview automatically makes an initial allocation of the funds against any outstanding invoices (if there are any).  The initial allocations can be modified before the adjustment is applied.  Adjustments are allocated differently depending on the allocation function specified for the adjustment type.  After the initial allocation is made, view and update the allocations by selecting the Invoices tab (for an individual adjustment) or by selecting an adjustment and clicking the Invoices button (for a batch adjustment).  The amount allocated to each invoice and receivable type is displayed in This Adjustment field (in the Individual Adjustment Detail form for individual adjustments or in the Invoices for Adjustment form for batch adjustments). Any credit amount not allocated to an invoice is displayed in the Credit field. The Credit field is updated as funds are allocated or de-allocated to an invoice or receivable type.  To adjust the initial allocations made to the adjustment (whichever form is displayed):  Enter zero in the This Adjustment field of the invoices not being allocated any funds.  If the whole amount is being allocated against a single invoice, the full amount is entered in the This Adjustment field of the appropriate invoice.  If the amount is being allocated against one or more receivable types, enter the amount in the This Adjustment column for the appropriate receivable type.   If the adjustment is being split between two or more invoices, the required amount for each invoice is entered in the This Adjustment field.  Each time an amount is entered, an equivalent amount is deducted from the amount in the Credit field.  If the adjustment is more than the combined total of the outstanding invoice balances, the funds remaining are treated as a credit against the specified account.    The amount in the Credit field is displayed in brackets if amounts are entered with a total of more than the adjustment amount.  View and modify how an adjustment is allocated at any stage.  Press the Tab key or close the Invoices for Adjustment form.  Control is returned to the Adjustment Batch Detail form.  If the adjustment has been entered against more than one invoice, the word 'Split' is displayed in the Invoice column.  If the adjustment was not made against an invoice, the word 'Credit' (or 'Debit' if it was a negative adjustment) is displayed in the Invoice column.  If required, overwrite the default text in the Adjustment Text field and enter a description of (or reason for) the adjustment in the Description field.  Any text written in the Adjustment Text field is printed on the customer's next invoice or statement; text written in the Description field is saved with the adjustment details, but not printed.  Complete any other fields defined for this adjustment.  The fields displayed depend on the adjustment type selected for the batch.  As each adjustment is entered, the total value of the adjustments in the batch is displayed in the lower right corner of the form.  Press the Down Arrow key to insert the next adjustment.  A new row is inserted below the current row with a new receipt number.   Repeat steps 5 to 11 until all adjustments have been entered, or until the batch needs to be saved.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Adjustment Batch Detail form is displayed in View Only mode.  To post the adjustments to the respective accounts, apply the batch.  To close the adjustment batch without posting the adjustments, click the Close button on the toolbar.  Need more information on adjustment batches?  Viewing an Adjustment Batch  To view an adjustment not yet applied, view the adjustment batch, and details of all applied and unapplied adjustments for that adjustment batch are listed in the adjustment Detail section.  To search for an adjustment batch and list adjustments in the batch:  Select the Accounts @ Adjustments @ Manage Batch Adjustments option.  The Adjustment Batch Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria. If the batch date is unknown, remove the date from the Batch Date field.  Click the Search… button.  If the search returns:  A single record, the Adjustment Batch form is displayed in View Only mode (if the Always Display List? option was not selected).  If a single adjustment batch record is returned from a search, the details of that record are displayed on the Individual Adjustment Batch form.  If more than one adjustment batch record is returned, the records are listed on the Adjustment Batch List form.  The required record can then be selected and its details displayed on the Adjustment Batch form.  If selected, the Always Display List? option overrides the automatic display of the Adjustment Batch form when only a single record is retrieved; in such cases the Adjustment Batch List form is displayed.  Multiple records, or the Always Display List? option was selected, the Adjustment Batch List form is displayed.  To access the Adjustment Batch form from the Adjustment Batch List form, double-click the appropriate batch in the list, or select the appropriate batch and click the Details… button.  The Adjustment Batch form is displayed listing each of the adjustments included in that batch.  The Details… button is enabled when the batch adjustments have been applied.  Need more information on adjustment batches?  Applying an Adjustment Batch  To apply (or reapply) the adjustments in an adjustment batch to their respective accounts:  Ensure that the adjustment batch is saved.  Click the Apply button.  A message indicating that the adjustments in the adjustment batch have been applied (posted) is displayed on the Status bar.  Need more information on adjustment batches?  Un-applying an Adjustment Batch  Rules for Un-applying an Adjustment Batch  To un-apply an adjustment batch:  View the appropriate adjustment batch.  Click the Un-apply button.  The adjustments within the adjustment batch are un-applied and, if required, can be modified or deleted.  Need more Information about adjustment batches?
