pages.title: Task Details Form
pages.text: The Task Details form is used to enter, view, and update details about a task.    Action or operation scheduled to be performed on behalf of a client by the Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) process.  The STD process generates the required tasks based on the schedule definition.  A task is executed as a server process by the Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) process.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Schedule, Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) Process, and Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) Process.  The upper part of the form displays the task ID, task status, status reason, and the schedule name.  The lower part of the form consists of the following tabs, for viewing more specific details:  Details  The Details tab displays a summary of standard information about the task.  The following fields are displayed: Email Address, Instance Name, Effective Date, Scheduled Start Date, Baseline group with Start Date, End Date, Duration (secs), Maximum Duration, Purge Period (days), Expected/Actual group with Start Date, End Date, and Duration (secs).   From the Details tab, it is possible to resubmit or stop a task and view the details of resubmitted, original, or dependent tasks associated with the task.   Parameters  The Parameters tab displays parameters passed to the server process (if any).  Any parameters specified are derived from the schedule that created the task, but they can be modified before the task is run, or when the task is resubmitted.  Clicking the Bill Run… button displays the Bill Run Detail form with the bill run for this task.  The Bill Run… button is enabled only if:  The form is in view mode.  The task created a bill run, or the task is associated with a schedule whose schedule type has a task type of Bill Run Operation, Bill Run Customer Operation, or Bill Run Operation (Prerequisite).  The task status is Success, Failure, or Running.  Prerequisites  The Prerequisites tab displays any prerequisite tasks assigned to the current task.  From the Prerequisites tab, it is possible to search for and assign tasks as prerequisite to the current task and configure the conditions that must be satisfied on the prerequisite tasks before the current task can progress.   The Start task immediately when all prerequisites satisfied? check box allows the task to start as soon as all prerequisites are true rather than waiting for the Scheduled Start Date.  This can be selected even if no task prerequisites are specified.   Resources  The Resources tab displays the details of resources that have been or will be consumed while the current task is running.  The Dependent Resource group within the Resources tab displays details of the resource that resulted in the current task’s status.  Results  For bill runs, customers suppressed from billing, using either the Customer Detail form or Billing Suppress schedule type, are identified as Skipped in the Results tab.  Customers excluded from the bill run for configuration reasons (for example, invoice due amount does not reach a predetermined limit) are designated as Suppressed in the Results tab.  Clicking the Report… button displays the report generated by the task.  The form can be displayed in one of three form modes, with the current mode indicated in the form’s title.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  If the task’s status is Running, Stopping, or Resubmitted, the task cannot be updated or deleted.   Associated Actions  Viewing a Task  To view a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of schedules matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate schedule and click the Details... button, or double-click the appropriate schedule.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on schedules?  Schedules are required to run tasks at specific times and frequencies in Convergent Billing.  Schedules are used to manage all billing tasks such as the rating of events, and the preparation and printing of invoices.  Schedules are also used to generate reports.  Tasks can be set up to run automatically at predefined intervals or at a specified time and date.  The schedule definition is determined in part by the associated schedule type.  When setting up a schedule, an instance on Convergent Billing can be specified to run the schedule.  If an instance is not specified, the schedule is run on the default instance defined for the scheduler.  (The default instance is defined in the STD configuration item.)  Preconfigured functions can be automatically executed on commencement or completion of a scheduled task, and notification messages provided to assist with system operations.  A schedule specifies:  When a task is to be run for the first time.  The Convergent Billing instance the schedule is run on.  The effective date (used as a base to compute the effective date for tasks that are created).  How often the task should be repeated.  What program the task needs to perform its function, and what parameters should be passed to it.  Selection parameters such as whether a report should include data on all customer nodes or only include data on a specific customer node.  Display parameters, such as whether the data included in a report is to be sorted, the sort order, and the sort sequence.  Creating a Schedule  To define a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Select the Create a new schedule option and click the New... button.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the data entry fields in the upper part of the form.  Complete the data entry fields on the Settings tab.  Complete the data entry fields on the Parameters tab.  Some of fields on this tab may be optional, depending on the associated schedule type.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Submit the schedule.  Need more information on schedules?  Schedules are required to run tasks at specific times and frequencies in Convergent Billing.  Schedules are used to manage all billing tasks such as the rating of events, and the preparation and printing of invoices.  Schedules are also used to generate reports.  Tasks can be set up to run automatically at predefined intervals or at a specified time and date.  The schedule definition is determined in part by the associated schedule type. pages.title: Task List for Schedule Form
pages.text: The Task List for Schedule form displays a list of tasks associated with the schedule.  The tasks are initially listed in descending task ID order, so that the most recent task is displayed at the top of the list.  The grid displays the task ID, schedule name, start date, scheduled start date, expected start date, effective date, task status, schedule type, and task type for each task.  Selecting a task and clicking on the Details... button results in the Task Detail form being displayed with the selected task.  Double-clicking on a task row achieves the same result.  To view details of a specific task, double-click the appropriate entry, or highlight the entry and click the Details… button.

pages.title: Task List Form
pages.text: The Task List form displays a list of tasks in the database, which match the specified search criteria.  The tasks are initially listed in descending task ID order, so that the most recent task is displayed at the top of the list.  By default, this first row is selected (that is, highlighted).  The grid displays the task ID, schedule name, instance name, start date, effective date, task status, schedule type, and task type.  Selecting a task and clicking on the Details... button results in the Task Detail form being displayed with the selected task.  Double-clicking on a task row achieves the same result.  If the search was initiated from the Prerequisites tab of the Task Details form, the Assign… button is enabled.  Selecting a task and clicking on the Assign… button allows the user to assign a prerequisite task to the task displayed in the Task Details form.

pages.title: Template Definition Form
pages.text: The Template Definition form is used to view, define, or maintain a template.  The name of the template, description, effective dates, type, context in which it is used, and associated database view can be specified.  Entity containing document processing instructions that are used by the IGP when creating a document image.  The Invoice Design Tool is used to manage template design.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Singleview  See also Document, IGP, and Invoice Design Tool.  The lower part of the form consists of a single field for the output of the template to be defined in a typesetting language, such as TEX or XML.  Microsoft Word 2007 XML document images can be loaded and viewed if the Microsoft Word XML Document Image template type is selected.  Alternatively, the definition saved in a separate file can be loaded into the lower part of the form (using the Load File button).  The form allows the definition to be saved to file (using the Save File button), and eligibility expressions to be defined that:  Determine whether the template is eligible for inclusion by the IGP (using the Eligible… button).  Are to be evaluated after the template is processed by the IGP (using the Post Eligible… button).  The form can be displayed in one of three form modes, with the current mode indicated in the form’s title. Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified). pages.title: Type Options Form
pages.text: The Type Options form is used to customise the contents displayed for the selected configuration object, and to filter the information displayed on the Convergent Billing Configuration Explorer form.  Associated Actions  Viewing a Diagram of the Configuration  To display a diagram of the configuration for the object selected in the left-hand panel:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer @ Diagram View option.  Select an object.  The diagram is displayed in the right-hand panel of the form.  To view the configuration object's:  Properties, select the Explorer @ Properties View option.  Contents, select the Explorer @ Grid View option.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Viewing the Properties of a Configuration Object  To view the properties of a configuration object:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer @ Properties View option.  Click the relevant object.  Click in the second level of the hierarchy, then select the relevant object from the third level to display that object's properties in the right-hand panel.  The properties can also be viewed by right-clicking on the relevant object and selecting Properties.  To view a configuration object's:  Diagram of the properties, select the Explorer @ Diagram View option.  Contents, select the Explorer @ Grid View option.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Viewing the Items Referenced by a Configuration Object  To display the items referenced by a configuration object:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer @ Grid View option.  Right-click on the configuration object and select References.  The References form with the items referenced by the selected object is displayed in the right-hand panel of the form in grid view.  To view the configuration object's references in diagram view, select the Explorer @ Diagram View option.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?   Viewing the Contents of a Configuration Object  To view the contents of a configuration object:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select Explorer @ Grid View option.  The contents of the object are displayed in the right-hand panel.  When viewing a grid, objects can be expanded or collapsed by double-clicking the object in the right-hand panel.  To view the configuration object's:  Diagram, select the Explorer @ Diagram View option.  References to the object are displayed to the left of the object.  Properties in a grid format, select the Explorer @ Properties View option.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Modifying the Presentation of Configuration Information  To change how configuration information is displayed:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer option, then the appropriate method of displaying the configuration information (Grid View, Diagram View, or Properties View).  Selecting Properties View displays the properties of the selected configuration object in a grid format.  When viewing a grid, each object can be expanded or collapsed by double-clicking the object in the right-hand panel.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Modifying the Configuration Details  To modify configuration details:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer option, then the appropriate method of displaying the configuration information (Grid View, Diagram View, or Properties View).  Navigate to the relevant entity by expanding or collapsing the view.  Highlight the entity, click the right mouse button, and select the Detail… option.  Use the Insert, Update, or Delete buttons on the toolbar to modify the configuration.  The buttons are only enabled if appropriate security settings are available.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Modifying the Explorer Options  To modify the Configuration Explorer options:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer @ Options... option.  The Explorer Options form is displayed.  Modify the relevant options and click OK.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Viewing the Explorer Legend  To view the explorer legend:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select the Explorer @ Legend... option.  The Explorer Legend form is displayed.  To view a specific entity, folder type, or icon, right-click on the relevant object and select the appropriate option.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?  Printing Configuration Information  To print configuration information:  Select the Maintenance @ Configuration Explorer option.  The Convergent Billing Configuration form is displayed, and the Explorer option is added to the menu bar.  Select Explorer @ Diagram View option.  Select the relevant diagram.  Right-click on the diagram and select Print Diagram.  The Print Selection form is displayed.  Enter the required printer selections and click OK.  Need more information on Configuration Explorer?

pages.title: Usage Detail Search Form
pages.text: The Usage Detail Search form is used to:  Search for specific usage details.  Restrict the search by specifying a period of time, service number, service type, destination number, and normalised event type as search criteria.    If a normalised event type is selected as one of the search criteria, additional fields may be displayed to further refine the search.  The Show all usage liability? check box can be enabled and disabled by updating the form role access level settings for the form.  Associated Actions  Viewing Customer Usage Details  To view a customer’s usage details:  Select the Accounts @ Account History option.  The Account History form is displayed in View Only mode.  Enter the appropriate account number in the Account Number field and tab out of the field or click the Refresh History button.  The account’s transaction details are displayed.  Click the Usage Details… button.  The Usage Detail Search form is displayed.  Enter the appropriate search criteria.  Specify the appropriate type of usage details to be included in the search by selecting the appropriate option in the Search for group.  To include all events associated with the specified customer node and its child nodes, select the Show all usage liability? check box.  Click the Search… button.  The Call Usage Display form is displayed.  One or more service numbers are listed in the Service Number column.  To view the usage details of a specific service number, double click on the appropriate number.  The usage details are displayed in the Usage Details grid on the right-hand side of the form.  Need more information on customer usage details?  Printing Customer Usage Details  To print a copy of a customer’s usage details:  Display the appropriate usage details.  Click the Report… button.  The Printing Call Detail Image form is displayed.  The Report... button is only enabled if Hyperion SQR is installed.  Select a printer from the drop-down list and click OK.  Need more information about customer usage details?

pages.title: User Preferences Form
pages.text: The User Preferences form is used to:  View, define, and maintain user preferences.  Select options to help navigate through Convergent Billing, and to display the Summary of Changes column on history forms.  The form is divided into the following tabs:  Mandatory fields  The Mandatory Fields tab is used to:  Specify whether or not mandatory fields are emphasised, and provides examples of the mandatory field settings defined in this form.  Define settings for mandatory fields and their labels.  For example, the colour and characteristics of the font used for mandatory field labels, colour of the text displayed in mandatory fields, and background colour of mandatory fields can be specified.  Form Navigation  The Form Navigation tab is used to:  Select options to view the Quick Window List and the location on the desktop for it to be displayed.   Selecting the Show Quick Window List? option makes navigating through forms easier by being able to view a list of all opened forms grouped by their entity, order in which the forms have been opened, or by bookmark.  Display the option to enable bookmarking, which makes navigating through forms easier by being able to use shortcut keys to make the required form active.  To bookmark a form, press Ctrl+Shift+Number, where Number is the number to select to identify the form.  When the form is bookmarked, pressing Ctrl+Number makes the form active.  General  The General tab is used to select the option to display the Summary of Changes column on history forms.  The form can be displayed in View or Update mode, with the current mode indicated in the form’s title.  Related Topics  Updating User Preferences  Enabling Bookmarking  Quick Window List

pages.title: User Definition Form
pages.text: The User Definition form is used to view, define, and update user definitions; the current mode of the form is indicated in the form's title.    A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  User-defined, is the entity that controls access to Singleview and its elements.  A user's access to forms and data, and the range of permitted operations (for example, update or delete), is controlled using a profile.  User is shared between Convergent Billing and Process Engine.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine, Configuration Studio  See also Access Level, Security Group, User Profile, Form Role, and Work Group.  The upper part of the form is used to enter general details about the user such as their user name, full name, profile, and email address.  The Last Login, Last Logout, and Current Sessions fields, are read-only and display the user's login details.  The lower part of the form:  Displays and maintains the user's account status.  Records auxiliary attributes such as phone number.  Allows for assignment of a person entity to record more information.  Includes the Password button to change the user's password.    The button is enabled only if the user has an Oracle account (Enabled? field is selected).  Auxiliary attributes are recorded on the following tabs:  Settings   The Settings tab is used to enter additional details about the user (for example, phone and fax numbers).  If more information is required, the user can be entered into Convergent Billing as a person, and assigned to the user definition.  General  The General tab is used to add additional fields to the Operator Definition form using entity validation.  If internal authentication is in use, user login to Convergent Billing is managed by the user's account status.  If external authentication is in use, user login is managed by the application providing external authentication; for example, access using single sign-on is managed using Microsoft Active Directory.  The data and forms that a user has access to are controlled by access levels assigned to the elements (for example, form role) of the security profile.  Associated Actions  Viewing a User  To view a user:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Users option.  The User Definition Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of users matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate user and click the Detail… button, or double-click the appropriate user.  The User Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine, using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Defining a User  To define a user:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Users option.  The User Definition Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The User Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the appropriate data entry fields on the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Password button is only available if:  All the required fields have been completed and the record has been saved   Internal authentication is enabled in the security profile.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Updating a User  To update a user's access:  View the appropriate user definition.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The User Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  Update user details as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Deleting a User  To delete a user:  View the appropriate user definition.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the user definition is to be deleted.  A user cannot be deleted if it is referenced by an entity.  Checking user references during a delete operation can cause timeouts. To avoid this, CSG International recommends disabling users by deselecting the Enabled? checkbox.   If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: User Definition Search Form
pages.text: This form is used to search for one or more user definitions using a specific field, criteria, and method.  The lower part of the form lists the user definitions (returned by the search) that match the specified criteria.  Multiple instances of the User Definition form can be displayed by clearing the Reuse form? check box.  If multiple instances of the form are required for display (for example, to access details for several account types), do not select the Reuse form? check box.  If selected, the Reuse form? check box overrides display of information in a new form, and details are displayed in the existing form.  Associated Actions  Viewing a User  To view a user:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Users option.  The User Definition Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of users matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate user and click the Detail… button, or double-click the appropriate user.  The User Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine, using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Defining a User  To define a user:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Users option.  The User Definition Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The User Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the appropriate data entry fields on the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Password button is only available if:  All the required fields have been completed and the record has been saved   Internal authentication is enabled in the security profile.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Updating a User  To update a user's access:  View the appropriate user definition.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The User Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  Update user details as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Deleting a User  To delete a user:  View the appropriate user definition.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the user definition is to be deleted.  A user cannot be deleted if it is referenced by an entity.  Checking user references during a delete operation can cause timeouts. To avoid this, CSG International recommends disabling users by deselecting the Enabled? checkbox.   If Process Engine is enabled, user accounts must be defined, updated, and deleted in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Need more information on security?  Updating a User's Access  If internal authentication is in use, the user's user name and password for Convergent Billing is managed by the user's account status.  If single sign-on is in use, access is managed using Windows Active Directory.  Data and forms that a user has access to are controlled by a profile, and access levels assigned to elements (for example, form role) of the profile.  To change a user's access to data and forms, do one of the following:  Change the user's primary security group.  Assign the user a different profile.  Change the attributes (security groups, form roles, access levels) of the user's assigned profile.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Variable Definition Form
pages.text: The Variable Definition form is used to view, define, and maintain a direct variable.  Variable mapped to data held in a database table or to a column in a database view.  The value of the variable is determined by the context in which the variable is used.  For example, each field of a normalised event record is mapped to a direct variable.  Direct variables are used in expressions to calculate values and used as the basis for deriving other variables.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Context and Variable.  The upper part is used to enter general information about the direct variable, such as its name and description, and the application environment and context in which it is to be used.  Environment in which a variable or function is used.  Must be one of the following:  Any (for functions only)  Billing  Data Entry  EVS (for Entity Validation Server (EVS) functions)  GL Guidance  IGP Report  Invoicing  PE  Rating  TRE Table (unavailable for functions).  Functions with an application environment of Any can be called from Convergent Billing or Process Engine.  The PE application environment is specific to Process Engine functions and direct variables defined in Process Engine.  Functions with an application environment of PE are read-only and cannot be deleted.  All other application environments are specific to functions and variables defined in Convergent Billing.  Functions with an application environment of EVS are read-only and cannot be deleted.  They cannot be specified or updated in Convergent Billing or Process Engine.    Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Context and Variable.  The lower part of the form is used to define parameters for the variable, or displays any variables that the variable references.  The form can be displayed in one of three form modes, with the active mode indicated in the status bar.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified). Updating a Variable  The method to update a variable depends on its type:  Derived Attributes  Direct Variables  Subtotals  Tariffs (Tariff Configurations)  Tariffs (Tariff Definitions)  Need more information on variables?  Deleting a Variable  A variable that is used by another variable cannot be deleted.  The method to delete a variable depends on its type:  Derived Attributes  Direct Variables  Subtotals  Tariffs (Tariff Configurations)  Tariffs (Tariff Definitions)  Need more information on variables?

pages.title: Variable Definition History Form
pages.text: The Variable Definition History form is used to view a:  List of records for the specified variable.  Named entity containing a value that is referenced in Convergent Billing.  A variable is a field in a database record or a more complex expression based entity (containing other variables, calculated values, and constants).  Convergent Billing supports the following types of variable:  Local variables  Direct variables  Entity validation variables  Functions  Derived attributes  Subtotals  Tariffs.  Variables have specialised properties such as data type, context, and application environment, and are generally used in expressions. Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Current Record and Future Record.  Record having a start date before or equal to today, and an end date equal to or after today.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Process Engine  See also Future Record and Historical Record.  Specific record and, if appropriate privileges are available, to update records. pages.title: Where Clause Form (Output Method Definition)
pages.text: The Where Clause form is used to view, define, or update an SQL statement that specifies how the item selected on the Output Method Definition form is to be printed.  The form consists of a single field in which the SQL Where clause can be defined.  The form can be displayed in one of three form modes, with the current mode indicated in the form’s title.  The mode in which the form is opened depends on the mode in which the Output Method Definition form is opened.  For example, the information about this form can only be updated if the Output Method Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified). To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  Associated Actions  Viewing an Output Method  To view an output method:  Select the Maintenance @ Printing @ Output Methods option. pages.title: Work Group Definition Form
pages.text: The Work Group Definition form is used to view, define, and update a work group definition.  The form displays the name and description of each work group.  Group of users with similar roles to whom actions or queries can be assigned. Each user is associated with a specific work group and is permitted to progress a query to another work group (if the work group is specified as one of a predefined set of work groups for that user).  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Process Engine  See also Action, Action Group, Progress, Query, and User.  The form can be displayed in one of two form modes: View Only and Update, with the current mode indicated in the form’s title.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  Associated Actions  Viewing a Work Group  To view a work group:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Work Group option. Click the Search button.  A list of existing work group names is displayed.  Select the required work group and click the Detail... button, or double-click the required work group.  The Work Group Definition form is displayed in View mode.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Work Group Definition form is displayed in Update mode. pages.title: How Do I - General Operations
pages.text: This section describes general operations performed by all users.

pages.title: Display/Hide Hint Text
pages.text: To turn on the display of hint text for each field and field value hints for grid fields, select the Options @ Show Hints option (when selected, a tick is displayed to the left of the option).  To turn off the display of hint text for each field and field value hints for grid fields, deselect the Options @ Show Hints option.  To display the hint text for a field:  Ensure that the display of hint text is turned on.  Position the cursor over the field.  Hint text for the field is displayed either below the field or below and to the right of the field.  To display the field value hints for a field in a grid:  Ensure that the display of hint text is turned on.  Position the cursor over the field in a grid.  The field value for that field is displayed below the field.

pages.title: Obtain Help on Error Messages
pages.text: Whenever an error occurs, an error message is displayed in a pop-up window.  For example, an error message is displayed if a mandatory field is not completed.  To obtain further details about the error:  Click the Help button on the Error window.  A Message Help window is displayed detailing the cause of the error and actions to correct it.  After reading the details on the Message Help window, click one of the following:  Retain button to return to the Error window, leaving the Message Help window open for reference.  Close button to return to the Error window, closing the Message Help window.  Click the OK button on the Error window.  Fix the problem causing the error before continuing.

pages.title: Refresh Security Settings
pages.text: By default, any changes to security settings take effect only when next logging in to Convergent Billing.  If the changes need to take effect immediately, update (refresh) security settings.  To update (refresh) the security settings for the current Convergent Billing session, do either of the following:  Select the File @ Refresh Security Settings menu option.  Press Ctrl-F5.  Related Topic  Configuring Caching for Performance  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Change Convergent Billing Password
pages.text: Setting a password is relevant only for users using internal authentication.  Consult the system administrator to determine if passwords are:  Authenticated internally  Case-sensitive.  To change a Convergent Billing password:  Select the File @ Change Password option.  The Set/Change Password form is displayed.  Enter current password in the Old Password field.  Enter new password in the New Password and Verify New Password fields.  Click the OK button.  The new password becomes effective at the next log in to Convergent Billing.  If Process Engine is enabled, it is highly recommended that the password is updated in Process Engine using the User Tool to ensure integrity of additional Process Engine data.  Related Topic  Rules for Singleview Passwords  Setting a password is valid only for users using internal authentication.  Consult the system administrator to determine if passwords are:  Authenticated internally  Case-sensitive.  The new password must comply with the rules of the validation function associated with the security profile. The default rules require the new password to:  Be at least six characters in length.  Not include the @ or " characters.  Include at least one non-alphabetical character.  Be different from the old password.  There is no maximum limit on the number of characters in a password.  If password reuse rules are enabled by the System Administrator (in the user's profile), a password can be reused if the following conditions are met since the password was last used:  The password was changed the minimum number of times specified in the Reuse Max field.  The number of days specified in the Reuse Time field have elapsed.

pages.title: Open a Form
pages.text: To open a form, select either of the following:  Appropriate menu option.  For example, to open the Account History form, select the Accounts @ Account History option.  Appropriate button (if available) on the active form.  For example, to open the Account History form, select the Account History… button on the Customer Detail form.  Convergent Billing allows multiple forms to be open at the same time.  Only one of these forms can be active at any one time.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Make a Form Active
pages.text: To make a form active (that is, give the form input focus), click on the form.  When active, the form is displayed in front of all other forms displayed.

pages.title: Cancel the Changes Made to a Form
pages.text: To cancel any changes made to a form:  Use one of the following methods:  Click the Cancel button.  Select the File @ Cancel option.  Press F3.  A Confirm window is displayed to confirm that the current form be cancelled.  To cancel the changes without saving them, click the Yes button.  To remove the request to cancel the changes, click either the No button or the Cancel button.  To obtain help on current options, click the Help button.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Close a Form
pages.text: Save any changes to the information on the form before closing it.  To close a form:  Use one of the following methods:  Click the Close icon (X).  Click the Close button on the toolbar.  Press Ctrl+F4.  If changes have been made to the form, a Confirm window is displayed prompting confirmation of the changes.  To save the changes and close the form, click the Yes button.  To ignore any changes made and close the form, click the No button.  To cancel the request to close the form and return to that form, click the Cancel button.  To obtain help on what current options are, click the Help button.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Close All Forms
pages.text: To close all displayed forms, select the File @ Close All option.  If a large number of forms are open, it may be quicker to use this option and then reopen the forms later, rather than close each unwanted form individually.  If changes made to data have not been saved on any of the forms being closed, a Confirm window is displayed for confirmation that changes are to be saved.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Change Form Mode
pages.text: To change the mode in which a form is displayed:  Make the required form active.  Click toolbar button appropriate to the form mode required.  A form can be displayed in one of the following modes:  Form Mode  Description  View Only mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed, but not updated (modified).  Insert mode  Allows new information to be recorded (entered) in Convergent Billing.  Update mode  Allows information held in Convergent Billing to be viewed and updated (modified).  To change the form mode:  Current Form Mode  New Form Mode  Click the …  View Only mode  Update mode  Update button  Update mode  View Only mode  Save or Cancel button  View Only mode  Insert mode  Insert button  Insert mode  View Only mode  Save button  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Move Around a Form
pages.text: Convergent Billing provides facilities to:  Move between fields  Move between fields in a form grid  Move between form tabs  Move between forms  Manipulate the active form.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Manipulate a Form
pages.text: The active form can be moved (re-positioned), re-sized, maximised, minimised, and closed.  The procedures to perform these actions are identical to those in other Windows applications.  The following can be minimised:  Open forms (irrespective of which form is active).  Select the Window @ Minimise All Windows option.  Inactive forms (that is, all forms except for the active form).  Select the Window @ Minimise Inactive Windows option.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: View Form Properties
pages.text: To view the properties of a data entry form:  Make the form active.  Select the Edit @ Properties option.  The Properties form is displayed.  The form displays the security group to which the data in the form belongs, name of the user who last made changes to the form, and date on which those changes were made.  Click the OK button to close the form.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Modify Form Properties
pages.text: To modify properties of a data entry form:  Make the form active.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  Select the Edit @ Properties option.  The Properties form is displayed.  Modify the group by selecting an alternative group from the drop-down list.  Click the OK button to close the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Add or Remove a Category
pages.text: To add or remove a Category to a data entry form:  Make the form active.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  Select the Edit @ Properties option.  The Properties form is displayed.  Click the Edit Categories button.  Assign a Category by selecting the required category in the Available Categories window and select the right-pointing arrow to move this Category across to the Assigned Categories window.    Remove a Category by selecting the Category in the Assigned Categories window and select the left-pointing arrow to move the Category to the Available Categories window.  Click the OK button to close the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on Category?

pages.title: Enter Data
pages.text: To enter data, a form must be displayed in either Insert or Update mode.  Enter data into a field by:  Keying in the data.  Selecting an option on the drop-down list associated with that field.  Pasting copied data into the field.  Convergent Billing provides a number of ways to enter a date.

pages.title: Insert Data in a Grid
pages.text: Data Grids  On some forms, one or more records can be entered.  For example, on the Customer Contacts form, details for a number of secondary contacts can be included.  The details for each secondary contact are entered on a single row.  To enter more than one secondary contact, a new row must be inserted into the list of entries and then the appropriate details entered.  As each row is a separate data record consisting of a series of fields, the list of records is referred to as a grid or table.  Field value hints are available to display the full contents of a grid field.  Field value hints are useful for viewing data in fields not wide enough to display the full value.  To insert a new row, do either of the following:  Before the current grid row, click the Insert button on toolbar.  After the last grid row, position the cursor in the last grid row and press the Down Arrow key.  Whichever method is used, a new row is created to enter appropriate details.

pages.title: Key in Data
pages.text: To enter data into a field directly, place the cursor in the required field and key in the data.  If a mistake is made while keying in data, edit the data.  Task  Press  Undo the last change to the current field  Esc  Delete the character to the left of the cursor  Backspace  Delete the character to the right of the cursor  Delete  Move the cursor one character to the right  @ (right arrow key)  Move the cursor one character to the left  @ (left arrow key)  Display a drop-down list  Alt+DownArrow  All leading and trailing spaces are stripped from text entered into forms in Convergent Billing.  To reset all the fields on a form to their default settings, close the form and then reopen it.  For example, to remove all the selection criteria on a customer care search form (for example, Person Search form), close the form and then reopen it.  If a field's data cannot be seen because it is masked or encrypted, it can still be updated if the appropriate update privileges are available.  When a masked or encrypted field is updated by a user without view access to the data, all previous data is automatically deleted from the field and replaced with the new data.  New data is masked or encrypted when the record is saved.

pages.title: Select an Option from a Drop-down List
pages.text: An option on a drop-down list can be entered in a field by:  Selecting the option from the drop-down list  Using the speed entry facility.  Alternatively, if the drop-down list allows an alternative (not predefined) value to be entered, key in the required value.  If none of the drop-down list options are to be displayed in an optional field, and that field allows a value to be keyed in, highlight the current entry and press the Backspace key.  To select an option from a drop-down list:  Click the arrow located at the far right-hand side of the field.  A list of the available options is displayed.  Click the option required.  The selected option is displayed in the field and the drop-down list is removed from the display.  If a large number of options are in a drop-down list, it may be necessary to use the vertical scroll bar on the right of the list to access the options not displayed.  To use the speed entry facility, enter:  The first few characters of option required.  Convergent Billing completes the option by matching the characters entered to the available options.  The match is performed based on the characters entered; the country displayed therefore may change as more characters are entered.  However, in each case the first predefined option that matches the entered characters is displayed.  Examples are:  Character(s) entered  Match (option) displayed   a  Afghanistan  an  Andorra  ant  Antarctica  anti  Antigua  Additional characters until the required option is displayed.

pages.title: Cut, Copy, and Paste Data
pages.text: Data entered in a field can be:  Copied into a buffer for subsequent pasting into another field.  Cut (deleted) from the field and copied into a buffer for subsequent pasting into another field (if required).  Convergent Billing supports keyboard equivalents to the Cut, Copy, and Paste menu options.  Menu Option  Press  File @ Save  Ctrl+S  File @ Cancel  F3  File @ Close  Ctrl+F4  File  @ Exit  Alt+F, X  Edit @ Insert  Ctrl+Insert  Edit @ Delete  Ctrl+Delete  Edit @ Update  F9  Edit @ Cut  Ctrl+X  Edit @ Copy  Ctrl+C  Edit @ Paste  Ctrl+V  Edit @ History  F12  Edit @ Properties  Alt+E, R  File @ Open  Ctrl+D  File @ Open @ Configuration Explorer  Ctrl+E  To copy data into the buffer:  Select the data to be copied.  Select the Edit, Copy option.  The selected data is copied into the buffer.  To paste data held in the buffer:  Place the cursor at the point in a field where the data is to be inserted.  Select the Edit, Paste option.  The data held in the buffer is inserted into the field at the cursor position.  To cut (delete) data and copy it into the buffer:  Select the data to be cut.  Select the Edit, Cut option.  The selected data is copied into the buffer and deleted from the current field.

pages.title: Edit/Modify Entered Data
pages.text: Data can be edited in:  A data record being created (record not yet saved).  An existing data record, if sufficient security privileges are available.  Update privileges required for types of update:  Type of Update  Privilege Required  Used To  Normal  Update  Update current and future records.  Historical Update  Update an historical record, or the current record and backdate the changes.  Date range  Date Range Update  Modify the date range of an historical record.  To edit data in a data record being created, edit the field details displayed.  To edit a data record:  Display the record details on the appropriate form.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  Edit the field details as required.  Save the details.

pages.title: Enter a Date
pages.text: Date Format  Dates must be entered in the format DD/MM/YYYY, where:  DD is the day  MM is the month  YYYY is the year.  For example, to insert the date 5 October 1996, enter 5/10/1996.  The format in which dates are displayed in Convergent Billing is determined by the Windows regional date format.  To change the format so that it reflects the format in which dates are entered in Convergent Billing, refer to Windows documentation.  Enter a date using any one of the following methods:  Directly  Using the drop-down calendar  Using keyboard commands.  To enter a date directly, key in the required date in the correct format.  To enter a date using the drop-down calendar, open the calendar by clicking on the drop-down calendar icon.  Click the Calendar icon or press Alt+DownArrow to display the drop-down calendar.  By default, the current day, month, and year are selected.  Click the right arrow to display the next month.  Click the left arrow to display the previous month.  To change the date:  Click the right arrow on the calendar to select the month after the current month or click the left arrow on the calendar to select the month before the current month.  The date displayed at the top of the calendar changes to reflect the month and year selected.  Click on the required day.  The drop-down calendar is closed and the selected date is displayed in the date field.  To enter a date using keyboard commands:  Insert the current date by pressing Ctrl+; (Ctrl + semicolon).  If required, modify the date using one or a combination of the available keyboard commands.  To  Press  Insert the current date  Ctrl+; (Ctrl plus semicolon)  Set the current date back by 1 day  Ctrl+UpArrow or Keypad '-'  Set the current date forward by 1 day  Ctrl+DownArrow or Keypad '+'  Set the current date back by 1 month  PageUp  Set the current date forward by 1 month  PageDown  Set the current date back by 1 year  Ctrl+PageUp  Set the current date forward by 1 year  Ctrl+PageDown  Open/close the drop-down calendar  Alt+DownArrow

pages.title: Search for a Data Record
pages.text: To perform a search:  Select the menu option appropriate to the type of search required.  Enter search criteria as required.  Select a search method.  Select a display format option, if required.  Click the Search... button.

pages.title: Tips for Searching
pages.text: The more specific the search criteria entered, the fewer records returned.  Whenever possible, limit a search to the relevant record.  For example, when searching for a query, progression, payment, invoice, or adjustment, enter the number of the query, progression, receipt, invoice, or adjustment.  Ensure that the record to be retrieved exists on the effective search date.  By default, only records effective on the date that the search is performed are included in the search.  On some search forms, an alternative date can be specified in the Effective Date or Search Date field, on which date records must be effective to be included in the search.  Specifying a date is useful if the search is for records effective at a past date (that is, historical records), or records that were created, but become effective at a future date.  On some search forms, the field can consist of either a single component (date), or two components (date and time).  Granularity (date or date-time) of the field is set when Convergent Billing is installed.  The default value for the field is affected by the granularity, and is described in the associated field help.  Searches are usually case-sensitive.  Searches for customers and contacts (using the Customer Search and Person Search forms) are not case-sensitive.  For example, entering a search string of 'Carol' on either the Customer Search or Person Search form, is equivalent to entering 'carol' or 'CaRoL'.  If unsure of the exact spelling of a person's name, select the Soundex search option (when available).  The Soundex search option (available on the Customer Search and Person Search forms) is useful if the exact spelling of a customer's or person's name is not known.  If this option is selected when the search is performed, any records that sound like the name entered in the search criteria are retrieved.  For example, if the name 'Newtown' is entered in the Family Name search field on the Person Search form, and the Soundex option selected, records for 'Newton', 'Newtown', and 'Newtonne' could be retrieved.  Whenever possible, use the search options available on some search forms to restrict the search to specific records.  For example, the Customer Query Search form can be used to specify that the search should include only active (open) queries, rather than both active and resolved (closed) queries.  If a search fails to retrieve the required record, perform at least one other search using alternative search criteria or the same criteria, but a different search method.

pages.title: Specify Search Criteria
pages.text: Search forms are used to specify one or more criteria on which to base a search.  Only data records that match the specified criteria are retrieved.  Leaving the search criteria fields blank results in a general (non-specific) search being performed with possibly a large number of records being retrieved.  If a search that may result in a large number of records being retrieved is performed, a Confirm window asking to confirm that that search should continue is displayed.  To continue with the search, click the Yes button.  If more than 100 records are retrieved, only the first 100 records are displayed.  To cancel the search, click the No or Cancel button and then enter more specific search criteria to narrow down the search.  For example, rather than specifying only the customer type when searching for a customer (which retrieves every customer record having that customer type), specify the customer's name.

pages.title: Specify a Search Method
pages.text: The search method determines how stringent a search is.  The following table lists search methods.  Search Method  Description  Exact Match (default)  By default, only records that match the search string exactly are retrieved.  For example, if the search string 'Carol Bailey' is entered when searching for a customer, only the record that matches it exactly is retrieved.  Records such as 'Karol Bailey' or 'Carol Bayley' are not retrieved.  To perform a less stringent search, use the Wildcard search method.  Wildcard  To make a search less stringent and therefore increase the likelihood of the required record being retrieved, use one or more wildcards.  Convergent Billing supports the following wildcards:  _ (underscore), which substitutes for a single character.  % (percentage), which substitutes for zero or more characters.  Examples.  Single character substitution  Ba_ley  Retrieves any record starting with the character string 'Ba' or 'ba' and the 4th, 5th, and 6th characters being 'ley'.  _arol  Retrieves any record having the character string 'arol' immediately after the first character.  Multiple character substitution  Carol B%  Retrieves any record starting with the character string 'Carol B'.  C%y  Retrieves any record starting with the character string 'C' and ending in 'y'.  %ley  Retrieves any record ending with the character string 'ley'.  Combinations  %rol%  Retrieves any record containing the character string 'rol'.  _rol%  Retrieves any record where the 2nd, 3rd, and 4th characters in a character string are 'rol'.  SQL  The Structured Query Language (SQL) search method is allowed on some search forms.  Conditional criteria can be specified so that only records that match the specified conditions are retrieved.  For example, an SQL search can be used to retrieve only records within a certain range of values.  This method is very powerful and can be complex.  It requires good understanding of the syntax of the SQL WHERE clause.

pages.title: View Historical Data Records
pages.text: To view a historical record:  Display the details of the current data record on the appropriate form.  For example, to display the details of a customer, access and display the Customer Detail form with the customer's details.  Click the History button on the toolbar.  The appropriate history form is displayed listing each of the historical records associated with the current record.  To view a specific historical record, double-click the appropriate entry in the list of historical records, or select one of the entries and click the Details... button.  The relevant form is displayed with details of the historical record.  Need more information on data records?

pages.title: View Summary of Changes to Data Records
pages.text: To view a the summary of changes for a record:  Display the details of the current data record on the relevant form (for example, to display the details of a specific customer, access and display the Customer Detail form).  Click the Changes… button on the form.  The Summary of Change form is displayed.  The Summary of Change form can also be accessed from any of the history forms (using the Changes… button displayed on the relevant history form).  Need more information on summary of changes?

pages.title: Obtain Information about the Data Record
pages.text: To obtain information about the data record displayed in the active form:  Select the Edit @ Properties option.  Details about the group in which the data is recorded, the user who created or last modified the data record, and date on which the record was created or last modified are displayed.  Click the OK button.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Update a Data Record
pages.text: To update the current record:  Ensure that the form is in View Only mode.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  If appropriate Update Privileges are available, the relevant form is opened immediately for performing a normal update.  Type of Update  Used To  Normal  Update details of a specified record, but restricts movement of the start and end dates to within the date range specified for that record.  Date range  Modify the date range specified for a record (that is, start date and end date of a record can be moved.  Date range updates can only be performed using a history form.  If historical update privileges are available, and the start date of the record is before today's date, a Confirm window is displayed prompting whether to default the start date for the new record to today's date.  When updating the current record, a Confirm window may be displayed prompting confirmation of whether to default the start date for the new logical record to today's date.  The Confirm window is displayed only if historical update privileges are available, and the start date of the record is before today's date.  If either of these conditions is false, only a logical record with a start date of today's date can be created.  To create a new logical record with a start date of today's date, click the Yes button on the Confirm window.  The appropriate form is displayed in Update mode, with the start date defaulted to today's date.  To modify the logical record (that is, backdate any required changes), click the No button on the Confirm window.  The appropriate form is displayed in Update mode, with the start date and end date unchanged.  To cancel the request to update the record, click the Cancel button on the Confirm window.  Make the required changes on the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The updated data is saved and the form is returned to View Only mode.  The minimum date range is one day.  Convergent Billing therefore regards any changes made to a record on the same day as the record was created to be part of the same record.  Need more information on forms?

pages.title: Save a Data Record
pages.text: To save data entered on a form, use one of the following methods:  Click the Save button (located on the toolbar).  Select the File @ Save option.  Press Ctrl+S.  If all mandatory fields on the form contain data, the data is saved, a message indicating that the data is saved successfully is displayed on the Status bar, and the form is reopened in View Only mode.  What if I forget to complete a mandatory field?  If one or more mandatory fields do not contain data when attempting to save data, Convergent Billing displays an error message indicating the first field in error.  The required date must be entered before the form can be saved.  Convergent Billing only identifies one error at a time, meaning that each time an attempt is made to save the form a new error is identified.

pages.title: Delete a Data Record
pages.text: Restrictions on Deleting Data Records  A data record can usually only be deleted from the database if it is not referenced by other data in the database.  For example, details of a contact cannot be deleted, if that contact is assigned to a customer.  Each Convergent Billing entity (for example, customers, contacts, products, services, and queries) is governed by its own set of rules and restrictions.  For example, a contact cannot be deleted if that contact is not assigned to a customer and/or has no queries assigned to it.  In practice therefore, these restrictions mean that only a data record that has just been created can be deleted.  In fact, the facility to delete a data record is provided only so that a data record entered in error can be deleted.  Data records no longer active must be archived.  To delete a data record:  Display the form relevant to the data record to be deleted in View Only mode.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  Assuming that the record is not referenced by another entity in the database, a message is displayed prompting confirmation that the specified record is to be deleted.  Click the Yes button to delete the data record.  A message that the record is deleted successfully is displayed.

pages.title: Drag and Drop Items
pages.text: The technique of dragging and dropping is used to select a graphical item, drag it to a new location, and then drop it.  Drag and drop is used in Convergent Billing when the Customer Hierarchy form is displayed to:  Create a new customer record.  Assign a base product to an existing customer.  Assign a contract to an existing customer.  Create a new query for an existing customer.  Re-organise the relationship between customer nodes.  Move a base product between customer nodes.  In the first four cases, dropping the appropriate graphical item results in the corresponding form being displayed in Insert mode to allow the item to be created.  For example, dragging the customer icon into the left-hand panel of the Customer Hierarchy form and dropping it results in the Customer Detail form being displayed.  Similarly, dragging a product icon over a customer name in the left-hand panel and dropping it displays the Product Instance Detail form.  In last two cases, dragging and dropping simply involves changing the relationship between items stored in the Convergent Billing database.

pages.title: Exit Singleview Convergent Billing
pages.text: To exit from Convergent Billing, use one of the following methods:  Select the File @ Exit option  Click the Close Icon (X)  Press ALT+F4  Press ALT+F, then X.

pages.title: Configure Caching for Performance
pages.text: Client PCs require regular attention and configuration for optimum Convergent Billing performance.  For efficiency and performance, static data and operational queries can be cached to a local PC, speeding the execution next time data is selected.  Caching follows the 'first in, first out' rule.  'First in, first out', also known as FIFO, means that when the cache is full, the oldest item in the cache is deleted first.  Associated Actions  Saving the Cache  When first logging in to Convergent Billing, the query cache is empty.  The first time an activity is performed, the queries are reconstructed and executed to retrieve the required data.  Therefore, the first time an activity is performed, it is slower than the subsequent executions of the same activity during that session.  Alternatively, the query cache can be saved to a file, increasing the performance of first use.  The saved query cache is loaded automatically when Convergent Billing is started.  To save the cache to disk:  Select the File @ Cache Status… option.  The Cache Status form is displayed.  Select the Save cache to disk? check box.  A saved cache is unique to the user who saves it, allowing multiple users to save caches on one PC.  Clearing the Cache  If the Save cache to disk? check box is not selected, the cache is cleared during every log-off operation.  The cache needs to be cleared after configuration or security changes have been made.  The preferred methods of clearing the cache are to select the File @ Refresh Security Settings option or press Ctrl-F5.  It is also possible to clear the cache by clicking the Clear Cache button on the Cache Status form.  Related Topic  Save the Cache  When first logging in to Convergent Billing, the query cache is empty.  The first time an activity is performed, the queries are reconstructed and executed to retrieve the required data.  Therefore, the first time an activity is performed, it is slower than the subsequent executions of the same activity during that session.  Alternatively, the query cache can be saved to a file, increasing the performance of first use.  The saved query cache is loaded automatically when Convergent Billing is started.  To save the cache to disk:  Select the File @ Cache Status… option.  The Cache Status form is displayed.  Select the Save cache to disk? check box.  A saved cache is unique to the user who saves it, allowing multiple users to save caches on one PC.  Configuring the Cache  The default size for the cache is 80.  Users who perform regular customer hierarchy searches and product instance creations need a cache size of '100'.  All users can set the cache size to this level if desired.  When configuring functions, reference types, and attributes, it is advisable to set the cache size to '0'.  A cache size of '0' alleviates the requirement to manually clear the cache by continually refreshing the security settings.  The cache details are found on the Cache Status form.  To open the Cache Status form, select the File @ Cache Status… option from the menu options.  It is important to reset the cache to the recommended size of '100' when configuration is complete.  Starting or Stoping the Cache  The cache is on by default.  To turn it off, set the Desired Cache Size to 0.    If Desired Cache Size is 0, and caching needs to be turned back on, configure the cache.  The default size for the cache is 80.  Users who perform regular customer hierarchy searches and product instance creations need a cache size of '100'.  All users can set the cache size to this level if desired.  When configuring functions, reference types, and attributes, it is advisable to set the cache size to '0'.  A cache size of '0' alleviates the requirement to manually clear the cache by continually refreshing the security settings.  The cache details are found on the Cache Status form.  To open the Cache Status form, select the File @ Cache Status… option from the menu options.  It is important to reset the cache to the recommended size of '100' when configuration is complete.  To activate the changes made to the cache:  Close all Convergent Billing forms.  Select File @ Refresh Security Settings option.

pages.title: How Do I - Customer Care Tasks
pages.text: This section describes customer care tasks performed by customer service representatives.

pages.title: How Do I - Customer Care Tasks - Adjustments
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the required task.

pages.title: View an Adjustment
pages.text: To view an adjustment:  Select the Accounts @ Adjustments @ Manage Individual Adjustments option.  The Adjustment Detail Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  If the adjustment date is unknown, remove the date from the Adjustment Date field.  If appropriate, select the Always Display List? option.  If a single adjustment record is returned from a search, the details of that record are displayed on the Individual Adjustment Detail form.  If more than one adjustment record is returned, the records are listed on the Adjustment Detail List form.  The required record can then be selected and its details displayed on the Individual Adjustment Detail form.  If selected, the Always Display List? option overrides the automatic display of the Individual Adjustment Detail form when only a single record is retrieved; in such cases the Adjustment Detail List form is displayed.  Click the Search… button.  If the search returns:  A single record, the Individual Adjustment form is displayed (if the Always Display List? option was not selected).  Multiple records, or the Always Display List? option was selected, the Adjustment List form is displayed.  To access the Individual Adjustment form from the Adjustment List form, double-click the appropriate adjustment in the list of retrieved adjustments, or select the appropriate adjustment and click the Details… button.  The Individual Adjustment form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on adjustments?

pages.title: Record an Adjustment
pages.text: Adjustments can be entered in either of the following ways:  Individually  In batches of the same adjustment type.  Before entering an adjustment, ensure that accurate information about the customer is available, amount of the adjustment, and the adjustment type.  The details need to be recorded or verified to successfully enter an adjustment.  When entering an adjustment, it is useful to have the Customer Detail form open for the customer getting the adjustment.  The customer's account number can then be copied from the Customer Detail form and pasted into the Account Number field on the relevant form.  Need more information about adjustments?

pages.title: Enter an Adjustment
pages.text: To enter an adjustment:  Select the Accounts @ Adjustments @ New Individual Adjustment option.  The Individual Adjustment Detail form is displayed.  Enter the adjustment details in the Details tab.  Select the General tab, and complete the appropriate data entry fields.  Select the Invoices tab, and allocate (enter) the adjustment to one or more of the listed invoices.  When an adjustment is being recorded, it (or part thereof) can be allocated to one or more of the outstanding invoices or simply recorded as a credit (or debit if it is a negative adjustment).  Recording an adjustment as a credit or debit (rather than against a specific invoice) may be necessary if, for example, it is not clear which invoice should be allocated the adjustment.  When an adjustment is made, Singleview automatically makes an initial allocation of the funds against any outstanding invoices (if there are any).  The initial allocations can be modified before the adjustment is applied.  Adjustments are allocated differently depending on the allocation function specified for the adjustment type.  After the initial allocation is made, view and update the allocations by selecting the Invoices tab (for an individual adjustment) or by selecting an adjustment and clicking the Invoices button (for a batch adjustment).  The amount allocated to each invoice and receivable type is displayed in This Adjustment field (in the Individual Adjustment Detail form for individual adjustments or in the Invoices for Adjustment form for batch adjustments). Any credit amount not allocated to an invoice is displayed in the Credit field. The Credit field is updated as funds are allocated or de-allocated to an invoice or receivable type.  To adjust the initial allocations made to the adjustment (whichever form is displayed):  Enter zero in the This Adjustment field of the invoices not being allocated any funds.  If the whole amount is being allocated against a single invoice, the full amount is entered in the This Adjustment field of the appropriate invoice.  If the amount is being allocated against one or more receivable types, enter the amount in the This Adjustment column for the appropriate receivable type.   If the adjustment is being split between two or more invoices, the required amount for each invoice is entered in the This Adjustment field.  Each time an amount is entered, an equivalent amount is deducted from the amount in the Credit field.  If the adjustment is more than the combined total of the outstanding invoice balances, the funds remaining are treated as a credit against the specified account.    The amount in the Credit field is displayed in brackets if amounts are entered with a total of more than the adjustment amount.  View and modify how an adjustment is allocated at any stage.  If appropriate, select the Debit Account Invoices Tab and enter the appropriate amounts.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Clicking the Save button assigns an adjustment number, saves the adjustment details, and posts the adjustment amount to the specified account.  Control is returned to the Individual Adjustment Detail form.  Rather than entering a number of adjustments individually, create a batch for each type of adjustment and add adjustments, as they are received, to the relevant adjustment batch.  The adjustment batch can then be applied at the end of a predefined period (for example, at the end of the day, or end of a week).  An organisation's business practices and billing cycles determine whether this is viable, and if so, the frequency at which adjustment batches need to be applied.  Need more information on adjustments?

pages.title: Search for an Adjustment
pages.text: Search for and view:  A specific adjustment (if the adjustment number, account number into which the adjustment was made, or the customer's name is known).  An adjustment within an adjustment batch (if the adjustment batch number is known).  If neither the adjustment number or the adjustment batch number is known, perform a general (non-specific) search for adjustments or adjustment batches and select the appropriate adjustment from the list retrieved.  Need more information on adjustments?

pages.title: View an Adjustment Allocation
pages.text: To view an adjustment allocation:  View the appropriate adjustment.  Select the Allocations tab.  The allocation is displayed in the fields on the tab.  To view the invoices to which an adjustment in an adjustment batch is allocated:  View the appropriate adjustment batch.  Select the appropriate adjustment.  Click the Invoices… button.  The Invoices for Adjustment form is displayed.  Need more information on adjustments?

pages.title: Modify an Adjustment Allocation
pages.text: The allocation of an adjustment can be modified for an:  Individual adjustment  Adjustment within an adjustment batch.  To modify the allocation of an individual adjustment:  View the appropriate adjustment.  Select the Allocations tab.  The allocation is displayed in the fields on the tab.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Adjustment form is displayed in Update mode.  Modify the allocation as required.  The allocation of a payment to an invoice may be changed after the payment is posted to a customer's account.  However, the total amount of the transaction cannot be changed, only the allocation.  Click Save on the toolbar.  To modify the allocation of an adjustment within an adjustment batch:  View the appropriate adjustment batch.  Select the appropriate adjustment.  Click the Invoices… button.  The Invoices for Adjustment form is displayed for viewing the specified adjustment.  Modify the allocation as required.  Click Save on the toolbar.  Need more information on adjustments?

pages.title: Reverse an Adjustment
