pages.title: Assign a Value to a Variable
pages.text: To assign a value directly to a variable, use an expression in the following format:  Combinations of operators (arithmetic and relational) and variables that return a single value when evaluated.  Variables used in an expression depend on the variable type, and the context and application environment in which the expression is being used.  Use of direct variables in expressions also depends on the defined database view.  Expressions are used in client and server processes.  In Process Engine, expressions can be used in searches, rule validations, parameters, and derivations; they can also be used to conditionally trigger the execution of EPM scripts.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Expression Block, Expression Parser Module (EPM), Expression Type, and Variable. pages.title: Define a Conversion Rate
pages.text: To define a currency and associated conversion rate to an existing currency:  Ensure that the currency for which a conversion rate needs to be added is defined.  If not, define the currency before proceeding.  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Currencies option.  The Currency Search form is displayed.  Set the Search field to Currency Name.  In the Search Criteria field, enter the name of the currency to which a conversion rate is being added, then click the Search button.  Select the currency record to add a conversion rate to, and click the Detail… button.  The Currency Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Position the cursor in the table in the lower part of the form and click the Update button on the toolbar.  Click the Insert button on the toolbar.  An empty row is inserted in the table.  Select the required currency from the drop-down list of currencies and then enter the conversion rate between the selected currency and the local currency.  The drop-down list displays only the names of currencies that have been defined in the system.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on currencies?

pages.title: Define a Currency
pages.text: To define a currency:  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Currencies option.  The Currency Search form is displayed.  Click the New... button.  The Currency Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the data entry fields on the upper part of the form and insert a row in the table in the lower part of the form for each currency requiring conversion.  To allow the billing engine to perform automatic currency conversion (using the conversion rates specified in the lower part of the form), select the Convertible? check box.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on currencies?

pages.title: Remove a Conversion Rate
pages.text: To remove a conversion rate:  View the appropriate currency.  Position the cursor in the table in the lower part of the form and click the Update button on the toolbar.  Select the row containing the currency (and its associated conversion rate) to be removed.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information about currencies?

pages.title: Define an Accounting Year
pages.text: To define an accounting year:  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Accounting Year option.  The Accounting Year Search form is displayed.  Click the New... button.  The Accounting Year Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  In the top part of the form, complete the appropriate data entry fields on the form for the accounting year.  To add accounting periods:  Click in the grid in the middle part of the form.  Click the Insert button.  Complete the appropriate data entry fields in the Accounting Period Details group.  Accounting years and periods defined must conform to the accounting year rules.  Accounting years and periods, defined using the Accounting Year Definition form, have the following characteristics:  No two accounting years belonging to the same accounting calendar can have overlapping date ranges.  At least one accounting period must exist for an accounting year.  The set of accounting periods for an accounting year must be contiguous; that is, they must completely span the accounting year, with no gaps or overlaps.  An accounting period specifies the expected book close date for the period, and the actual book close date.  An initial set of accounting years and periods can be created using the Generate Accounting Periods schedule type.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on accounting years?

pages.title: View an Accounting Year
pages.text: To view an accounting year:  Select the Maintenance @ Accounts @ Accounting Year option.  The Accounting Year Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria, method, or date.  Click the Search button.  A list of accounting years that match the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate accounting year and click the Detail... button (or double-click the appropriate accounting year).  The Accounting Year Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on accounting years?

pages.title: Update an Accounting Year
pages.text: To update an accounting year:  View the appropriate accounting year.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Accounting Year Definition form is displayed in Update mode.  In the top part of the form, update the accounting year fields.  The accounting year's status, start date, and end date cannot be updated; they are updated automatically, based on the corresponding fields of the last defined accounting period.  To update accounting periods:  Select an accounting period in the grid in the middle of the form.  Update the fields in the Accounting Period Details group for the selected accounting period.  Accounting years and periods defined must conform to the accounting year rules.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on accounting years?

pages.title: Delete an Accounting Year

pages.text: Events are usually rated using a bill run schedule.    Rate files on demand using a one-off task, as follows:  Ensure that the file to be rated is in the appropriate input directory. pages.title: Correct Corrupted Events
pages.text: Events that cannot be parsed by the ENM are written to the error directory as corrupted events.  To resolve corrupted events:  Go to the error directory.  View the event to determine the cause of the corruption.  Correct the event data.  In severe cases, it may be necessary to refer the problem to the originator of the event.  Move the corrected file to the input directory.  Rename the corrected file to reflect its origin and status.  Rate the file.  Want more information on event rating?

pages.title: Correct Error Events
pages.text: If an error is detected during normalisation or rating, the event is called an error event.  To resolve error events:  View the normalised event error  Determine if the event is required.  If not, run a Purge Error Events task to purge the event.  If it is, continue.  Determine what caused the error.  It may be in the event data or a tariff, derived attribute, function, or other rating component.   Resolve the error by correcting the appropriate component or event data.  For a single error event, assign the event to a rerated file.  For multiple error events, run the appropriate schedule type to reprocess the events.   Want more information on event rating?

pages.title: Correct Incorrect Charges
pages.text: If normalised events and charges are created without apparent error, but the charges are consistently incorrect:  Determine what caused the incorrect charge generation.  It may be in a tariff, derived attribute, function, or other rating component.  Correct the element causing the incorrect charge generation.  Determine the extent of reprocessing required.  This depends on the number of events that need to be reprocessed and their effect on any rating subtotals.  Run the appropriate schedule type to rerate or reprocess the events according to reprocessing required.  For possible schedule types, refer to the System Operations Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Want more information on event rating?

pages.title: How Do I - Operations - Schedules
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the required task.

pages.title: View a Schedule
pages.text: To view a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of schedules matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate schedule and click the Details... button, or double-click the appropriate schedule.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on schedules?  Schedules are required to run tasks at specific times and frequencies in Convergent Billing.  Schedules are used to manage all billing tasks such as the rating of events, and the preparation and printing of invoices.  Schedules are also used to generate reports.  Tasks can be set up to run automatically at predefined intervals or at a specified time and date.  The schedule definition is determined in part by the associated schedule type.  When setting up a schedule, an instance on Convergent Billing can be specified to run the schedule.  If an instance is not specified, the schedule is run on the default instance defined for the scheduler.  (The default instance is defined in the STD configuration item.)  Preconfigured functions can be automatically executed on commencement or completion of a scheduled task, and notification messages provided to assist with system operations.  A schedule specifies:  When a task is to be run for the first time.  The Convergent Billing instance the schedule is run on.  The effective date (used as a base to compute the effective date for tasks that are created).  How often the task should be repeated.  What program the task needs to perform its function, and what parameters should be passed to it.  Selection parameters such as whether a report should include data on all customer nodes or only include data on a specific customer node.  Display parameters, such as whether the data included in a report is to be sorted, the sort order, and the sort sequence.

pages.title: Define a Schedule
pages.text: To define a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Select the Create a new schedule option and click the New... button.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the data entry fields in the upper part of the form.  Complete the data entry fields on the Settings tab.  Complete the data entry fields on the Parameters tab.  Some of fields on this tab may be optional, depending on the associated schedule type.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Submit the schedule.  Need more information on schedules?  Schedules are required to run tasks at specific times and frequencies in Convergent Billing. pages.title: Change Effective Date of a Schedule
pages.text: Changes to the first date or the effective date of a schedule cause the Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) to recalculate the effective dates of all pending tasks for the schedule so that the difference between the start date and the effective date for the pending tasks is the same as the first date and the effective date of the schedule.  Therefore, to change the effective date of a schedule, both the first date and the effective date of the schedule need to be changed.  If only the effective date is changed, and tasks for the schedule have run in the past, unexpected results can occur.  To change the effective date of a schedule, change and re-submit the schedule as follows:  Change the values in the First Date field to the new first date for the schedule.  Change the values in the Effective Date field to the new effective date for the schedule.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Submit the schedule.  Select the Regenerate tasks? check box to cancel tasks for the schedule and regenerate new tasks.  Need more information on schedules? pages.text: To examine the status of a task:  Select the Server Tasks @ Tasks option to display the Task Search form.  Enter the relevant parameters. pages.title: How Do I - Security Tasks
pages.text: This section describes security tasks performed by configurers, system administrators, and system operations personnel.

pages.title: How Do I - Security Tasks - Audit Reports
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the task.

pages.title: Define an Auditing Configuration Item
pages.text: To define an auditing configuration item:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Configuration Items option.  The Configuration Item Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The Configuration Item Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Select AUDIT_TABLE from the Configuration Item Type drop-down list.  The Configuration Item Name and Sequence Number fields are automatically populated.  Complete the Description field.  Select the required value for the Enabled attribute in the Base Attributes grid.  Select the table to be audited as the Table Name attribute in the Base Attributes grid.  Select the required value for the Include New Data in Audit attribute in the Base Attributes grid.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on audit records?

pages.title: View Audit Records
pages.text: To view audit records:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ View Audit Records option.  Select the database table with audit records to be viewed from the drop-down list in the Table field.  Optionally, enter any other search criteria to restrict the search.  Click the Audit… button to retrieve the audit records.  The Audit form displays a grid with one row for each audit record and a column for each field in the database table.  More than one audit record window can be open at the same time.  If this is required, enter new selection criteria in the Audit Search form and click the Audit… button.  However, if the new selection is to overwrite the previous selection, select the Reuse last audit form? check box before clicking the Audit… button.  Need more information on audit records?

pages.title: Edit Configuration Items
pages.text: To edit a configuration item for a database table to set auditing on or off:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Configuration Items option.  The Configuration Item Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  For example, to find a list of configuration items, select Configuration Item Type from the drop-down list in the Search field, and enter the required value AUDIT_TABLE in the Search Criteria field.  Click the Search button.  A list of the defined configuration items matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate configuration item and click the Detail… button, or double-click the configuration item to be changed.  The Configuration Item form is displayed in View Only mode.  Click Update on the toolbar.  The appropriate configuration item is displayed in Update mode.  Update the form:  Select TRUE or FALSE as required for the value of the Enabled attribute in the Base Attributes grid.  Select the appropriate table.  Select TRUE or FALSE as required for the value of the Include New Data in Audit attribute in the Base Attributes grid.  Select TRUE to save all data for both the new and old record.  Click Save on the toolbar.  Need more information on audit records?

pages.title: Reset Oracle Triggers
pages.text: To control the auditing process by resetting the Oracle triggers:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Select Reconfigure Auditing from the Schedule Type drop-down list.  Complete the parameters for a one-off task.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Click the Submit button.  The new audit configuration takes effect as soon as the Reconfigure Auditing task has completed successfully.  Need more information on audit records?

pages.title: Define a Form Role
pages.text: To define a form role:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Form Roles option.  The Form Role Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The Form Role Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the Name and Description fields.  Complete a line in the grid for each menu item or form to which the form role is to provide access.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: View a Form Role
pages.text: To view a form role:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Form Roles option. The Form Role Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of the defined roles matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate role and click the Detail… button, or double-click the appropriate role.  The Form Role form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: View Access Privileges on a Form Role
pages.text: To view the access privileges of a form:  View the desired form role.  Select the desired form and click on the Access Level Settings button.  The access levels for that form are displayed.  The descriptions below highlight the difference between a detail record and a record:  A record is an entity being viewed in a form.  For example, if the Service Detail form is being used, the record is of a service.  A detail record is data that relates to the original record, but which belongs to another entity.  Using the same example, the charge categories that can be viewed on the Service Detail form are detail records.

pages.title: Update a Form Role
pages.text: To update a form role:  View the appropriate form role.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Form Role form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the form role details as required:  Click on the Insert button to insert a new line in the grid for a menu item or form to which the form role is to provide access.  Highlight a form and click on the Access Level Settings button to display the access levels for that form.  Select the appropriate access levels for the form.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Delete a Form Role
pages.text: To delete a form role:  View the appropriate form role.  Click the Delete button on the toolbar.  When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the form role is to be deleted.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Enable Date-time Granularity
pages.text: To enable date-time granularity, use the Update a Form Role option to change the access level for the forms for the relevant entity by selecting the Allow date range time granularity of less than one day access level check box.  For a list of form codes, associated form descriptions and form fields affected by the Allow date range time granularity of less than one day access level, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Date-time granularity is configured using form roles, so the same form can have different granularity for different users.  To avoid user confusion, it is recommended that a form's date-time granularity be configured the same in all form roles.  Because the TRE is not subject to form role security, TRE functions can specify time components for dates, regardless of the form role configuration.  When an entity's date fields are updated by TRE functions, if the dates :  Require time components, enable date-time granularity for users.  Do not require time components, disable date-time granularity for users, and ensure that TRE functions are called without time components in parameters.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Disable Date-time Granularity
pages.text: To disable date-time granularity for a form, update the form role by clearing the Allow date range time granularity of less than one day access level for each form, as required.

pages.title: Define a Function Role
pages.text: To define a function role:  Select the Maintenance @ Security @ Function Role option.  The Function Role Search form is displayed.  Click the New… button.  The Function Role Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the Name and Description fields in the top part of the form.  Add function roles to the table in the lower part of the form as required.  Each function role must be entered on a separate row of the table.  The Invoked Function column displays the name of the remote TRE function to be invoked when a TRE client calls the function in the Called Function column.  The invoked function must be defined as 'remote' and return the same data type as the function in the Called Function column.   To add a row to the table, press the Down Arrow key.  To insert a blank row before the current row, click the Insert button on the toolbar.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  If required, multiple functions can be added to the function role. When prompted, click the Yes button to confirm that the user definition is to be deleted.  A user cannot be deleted if it is referenced by an entity. pages.title: Update a User's Access
pages.text: If internal authentication is in use, the user's user name and password for Convergent Billing is managed by the user's account status.  If single sign-on is in use, access is managed using Windows Active Directory.  Data and forms that a user has access to are controlled by a profile, and access levels assigned to elements (for example, form role) of the profile.  To change a user's access to data and forms, do one of the following:  Change the user's primary security group.  Assign the user a different profile.  Change the attributes (security groups, form roles, access levels) of the user's assigned profile.  Need more information on security?

pages.title: Schedule a Periodic Report
pages.text: To schedule a periodic report:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedules option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Select the Create a new schedule option and click the New… button.  The Schedule Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Select the report name from the drop-down list in the Schedule Type field.  All report schedules are prefixed with 'Report'.  Complete the remaining fields as required.  If there are any problems in completing a field, position the cursor in the field and press F1 to obtain help on that field.  Complete the fields in the Task Generation, Parameters, and Prerequisites tabs.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Click the Submit button to submit the schedule; no options on the Submit Schedule form need to be selected.  The schedule creates one or more tasks run for generating the report at the dates and times specified.  If an email address is specified, an email message is received when each task is completed.  Receiving an email does not indicate whether the report was created successfully.  The task status must be examined to check this.  For more information, refer to Examine the Status of a Task.  Need more information on reports?

pages.title: Schedule an Immediate Report
pages.text: To schedule an immediate, one-off report:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-Off Task option.  Choose the report name from the drop-down list in the Schedule Type field.  When this field loses input focus (when another field is selected), the lower part of the form is populated with fields for any parameters the report requires.  Enter a value in each parameter field.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on reports?

pages.title: View and Print a Report
pages.text: The default format for reports is Microsoft Excel XML; however, the format can be altered by using alternate stylesheets.  The client workstation used to view reports must have the appropriate software to view the report in its output format.  To view a generated report:  Display the Task Details form.  Click the Report button to start the report viewing software (if it is not running), and display the report.  View, edit, or print the report as required.  Need more information on reports?

pages.title: Perform a Bill Run using a Schedule
pages.text: To perform a bill run using a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedule option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Select the Create a new schedule option and click the New… button.  The Schedule Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  Complete the appropriate fields on the form.  For possible schedule types, refer to the System Operations Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Submit the schedule.  Need more information on bill runs?

pages.title: Perform a Bill Run using a One-off Task
pages.text: To perform a bill run using a one-off task:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-off Task option.  The One-Off Task Definition form is displayed.  Select the appropriate bill run from the Schedule Type drop-down list.  The lower part of the form displays the parameters associated with the bill run.  Enter the appropriate parameters for the bill run.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The bill run is saved and a one-off task is submitted.   Click the Display Task… button to open the Task Detail form and monitor the progress of the bill run.  When the bill run is complete, a notification is sent by email.  Need more information on bill runs?

pages.title: Modify a Bill Run
pages.text: The method of searching for and viewing the details of a bill run depends on if the bill run was set up:  Using a schedule.  As a one-off task.  If the bill run was set up using a schedule:  Select the Server Tasks @ Schedule option.  The Schedule Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  Click the Search… button.  A list of schedules matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate schedule and click the Details… button or double-click the appropriate schedule. The Schedule Definition form is displayed in View Only mode.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The form is displayed in Update mode.  Make the appropriate changes to the bill run.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The Submit Schedule form is displayed.  Select the appropriate submit option.  Option  Used To  Regenerate tasks?  Cancel any pending jobs associated with the original schedule.  Regenerate tasks? is only used when modifying a schedule.  Be notified on receipt?  Direct the scheduler to open a window on the workstation to notify the user when the submitted schedule is received at the server.  Be notified on completion?  Direct the scheduler to open a window on the workstation to notify when the first scheduled task is completed.  User must be logged in to Convergent Billing at the time the notification is sent for it to be displayed.  A notification of the completion of any remaining tasks is performed using email (to the schedule's email address).  Submit the schedule.  If the bill run was set up as a one-off task:  Select the Server Tasks @ Bill Runs option.  The Bill Run Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  Click the Search… button.  A list of one-off tasks matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the appropriate one-off task, and click the Details… button or double-click the appropriate one-off task.  The Bill Run Detail form is displayed in View Only mode.  Select the Detail tab, and in the Creation Task group, click the Details… button.  The Task Details form is displayed in View Only mode.  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The form is displayed in Insert mode.  Make the appropriate changes.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Entitlements that are aligned with customer bill cycles are dependent on the effective date of the bill run task.  Changing the effective date of a bill run task may require a large number of entitlements to be rescheduled.  The Task Details form detects entitlement dependencies and raises a warning if such a change is attempted.  Need more information on bill runs?

pages.title: View a Bill Run
pages.text: To view bill run details:  Select the Server Tasks @ Bill Runs option.  The Bill Run Search form is displayed.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  Click the Search… button.  If the search returns only a single bill run, the Bill Run Details form is displayed in View Only mode (if the Always Display List? option is not selected).  If a single bill run record is returned from a search, the details of that record are displayed on the Bill Run Detail form.  If more than one bill run record is returned, the records are listed on the Bill Run List form.  The required record can then be selected and its details displayed on the Bill Run Detail form.  If selected, the Always Display List? option overrides the automatic display of the Bill Run Detail form when only a single record is retrieved; in such cases the Bill Run List form is displayed.  If the search returns more than one bill run, or the Always Display List? option is selected, the Bill Run List form is displayed.  Select the appropriate bill run and click the Details… button, or double-click the appropriate bill run.  The Bill Run Details form is displayed in View Only mode.  Need more information on bill runs?

pages.title: Perform an Operation on a Bill Run
pages.text: The Perform Operation… button is enabled only if the user has:  Sufficient privileges to access the One-Off Task Definition form  Schedule creation privileges for at least one of the operation tasks supported by the current bill run type.  To perform an operation on a bill run:  View the appropriate bill run details.  Click the Perform Operation… button.  The Perform Operation form is displayed.  Highlight the customer billing operation to be performed, and click the Submit button.  The One-Off Task Definition form is displayed.  Click the Save button on the toolbar to submit the task.  Click the Display Task… button to open the Task Details form and monitor the progress of the task.  When the task is complete, a notification is sent by email. pages.title: Search for and Assign an Account Number
pages.text: To insert an account number into the From Account Number or To Account Number fields on the Charge Category Definition form:  Position the cursor in the appropriate field and click the Search To Account… or the Search From Account… button.  The Account Number Search form is displayed.  Enter the appropriate criteria and click the Search button.  Search for and select the required account number.  Double-click on the list entry for the account required.  The selected account number is inserted into the current field on the Charge Category Definition form.  Need more information on charge categories?  Charge Category Examples  A charge category specifies an account type and, optionally, an account, to which a tariff’s charge or benefit is posted, and is an essential part of tariffing.  Another account type can also be defined and, optionally, an account, to which a balancing (opposite) entry can be posted (known as the ‘from’ account).  The term ‘tariff/charge category pair’ is often used to emphasise that the two objects are independent, but always go together.  Charge categories cannot reference account types that permit multiple accounts of the same type on a customer node.  The account inferred from an account type assigned to a charge category must be unambiguous.  A charge category instance is created for every tariff used by a service whenever a product containing the service is sold, creating a product instance.  The charge category instance is located at the customer node, the customer (root node), or the service level, depending on the context defined for the associated tariff.  A different instance of the charge category can exist at each level, for use by tariffs with different contexts.  A charge category instance is created using values from the default charge category specified in the appropriate tariff configuration.  The values used can be overridden.  Only one instance of the charge category is created at each location, no matter how many services reference the tariff.  Any defaults for services after the first are ignored.  A charge category instance can be re-defined so that proportions of a charge are posted to more than one account.  They can also be edited after creation, to redirect payments to a different account.  When the rating or billing engine processes an event, the process involves looking up details of the service stored at the customer node, identifying the applicable tariffs, and then using the tariffs to calculate the value of each charge or benefit.  The appropriate charge category instance is then used to identify the account.  The combination of the charge and the account information makes up the charge record in the CHARGE table of the database.  A charge category instance can also define a GL code to assign to the charge or benefit, if required.  However, using charge categories to assign GL codes is deprecated and provided for backward compatibility only. GL codes are assigned to charges using GL guidance (for more information, refer to the Finance Guide for Singleview).

Click the Save button on the toolbar. The one-off task is submitted and the PartitionUtilisation derived attribute table is updated.  Need more information on table partitioning?

pages.title: How Do I - System Administration Tasks - Test Expressions
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the required task.

pages.title: Test an Expression
pages.text: To test an expression:  Select the Maintenance @ Data Definition @ Expression Test option.  Maximise the form to expand the Results field to its maximum size.  Enter the expression to be tested in the Expression field.  Skeleton code containing a function call to a defined function with appropriate variables can be inserted in the upper part of the form.  To insert the skeleton code, enter a function name in the Function Name field and click the Generate Function Call button.  The skeleton code can be modified, as required, before the expression is evaluated.  Click the Evaluate button.  The results of the expression are displayed in the Results field.  Expression blocks can be evaluated by entering them as described.  The braces are required around the expression block, and each expression in the block must end with a semicolon.  Functions can be called within a test expression.  Direct variables can be used in test expressions.  Other variables used in expressions are empty unless declared as local variables and assigned a value in the expression block.  Need more information on expressions?

When a new or modified DIL definition is saved, the server validates the definition by performing an automatically-created one-off task.  A message states that validation is in progress, and offers the opportunity of cancelling it.  If cancelled, the DIL definition is not saved.  When the validation is completed, the two possible outcomes are success or failure.  If the validation fails, the Task Detail form is displayed with the reasons for failure.  The Data Interface Language Definition form remains open in Update or Insert mode.  If the validation succeeds, the changes are committed and a message appears on the status bar to this effect.  Need more information on DIL Definitions?

The Scheduled Functions Transaction List form is displayed.Need more information on scheduled functions?

pages.title: Reschedule Scheduled Functions

Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of summary rows matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the scheduled functions to update, and do one of the following:  Highlight the appropriate summary row or rows and click the Bulk Update button.    Highlight the appropriate summary row and click the View List... button, or double-click the appropriate summary row.  A list of scheduled functions matching the criteria in the summary row is displayed in the List grid.  Select the appropriate row or rows and click the Update... button.    If viewing a scheduled function in the Scheduled Functions form, click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Scheduled Functions form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the Status field of the specified scheduled functions from Failure to Failure (Retries Pending).  Update other required details.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The updated scheduled function is saved and submitted for reprocessing.  Need more information on scheduled functions?

pages.title: Stop Scheduled Functions

Enter or select the appropriate search criteria and search method.  Click the Search button.  A list of summary rows matching the specified criteria is displayed.  Select the scheduled functions to update, and do one of the following:  Highlight the appropriate summary row or rows and click the Bulk Update button.    Highlight the appropriate summary row and click the View List... button, or double-click the appropriate summary row.  A list of scheduled functions matching the criteria in the summary row is displayed in the List grid.  Select the appropriate row or rows and click the Update... button.    If viewing a scheduled function in the Scheduled Functions form, click the Update button on the toolbar.  The Scheduled Functions form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the Status field of the scheduled functions.  Valid status updates to stop processing a scheduled function are:  Pending to Failure    Failure (Retries Pending) to Failure.    Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The updated scheduled functions are saved and submitted for reprocessing.  Need more information on scheduled functions?

pages.title: Define an External Definition Namespace
pages.text: To define an external definition namespace:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition Namespace option.  The External Definition Namespace Search form is displayed.   Click the New... Button.  The External Definition Namespace form is displayed.   Enter a namespace name in the Namespace Name field.  The namespace name must be unique.  Enter a namespace abbreviation prefix in the Prefix field.  If a specific location is required, enter an absolute path in the Schema Location field that describes the location of the XML schema for the namespace.  If generating an XML schema with unqualified elements, select the Unqualified Elements? checkbox   Complete the Description field for the namespace, if required.   Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Need more information on external definition namespaces?

pages.title: View an External Definition Namespace
pages.text: To view an external definition namespace:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition Namespace option. The External Definition Namespace Search form is displayed.  Enter the search criteria and select the search method.  Click the Search button. Namespaces matching the search criteria are displayed in the lower section of the form.  Select the namespace to update and click the Detail... button.  The External Definition Namespace form is displayed in View only mode.  Need more information on external definition namespaces?

pages.title: Update an External Definition Namespace
pages.text: To update an external definition namespace:  View the relevant external definition namespace.  To view an external definition namespace:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition Namespace option. The External Definition Namespace Search form is displayed.  Enter the search criteria and select the search method.  Click the Search button. Namespaces matching the search criteria are displayed in the lower section of the form.  Select the namespace to update and click the Detail... button.  The External Definition Namespace form is displayed in View only mode.  Need more information on external definition namespaces?  Click the Update button on the toolbar.  The External Definition Namespace form is displayed in Update mode.  Update the namespace definition as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.    Need more information on external definition namespaces?

pages.title: Generate XML Schema
pages.text: To generate XML schema from an external definition namespace, all external definitions in the namespace need to be validated.  To generate XML schema from an external definition namespace:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition Namespace option. The External Definition Namespace Search form is displayed.  Enter the search criteria and select the search method.  Click the Search button.  Namespaces matching the search criteria are displayed in the lower section of the form.  Select the required namespace and click the Detail... button.  The External Definition Namespace form is displayed in View only mode.  Click the Generate XML Schema... button.    The name of the XML schema file is derived from the value of Namespace Name.    The location of the XML schema file is derived from the value of Schema Location, if specified.  If Schema Location is not specified, the default location is $ATA_DATA_SERVER_CONFIG/xsd.  If the value of Schema Location is specified with environment variables, the environment variables are substituted by their values.    Need more information on external definition namespaces?

pages.title: Define an External Definition
pages.text: To define an external definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition option.  The External Definition Search form is displayed.   Click the New... Button.  The External Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.   Enter the external definition configuration.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Default external definition configurations can be generated from entity validation using the ExternalDefnGenerate&() function.  Need more information on external definitions?

pages.title: Generate an External Definition
pages.text: External definitions can be generated from XML schema files.  Restrictions apply when generating external definitions from XML schema files (see the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing).   XML schema files must be validated with a third party tool before importing them using the EDXmlSchemaRead&() function.  This function performs basic checks for conformance to external definition specifications, but assumes that the XML is valid and correctly aligned with XML Schema 1.0.   To generate external definitions from an XML schema file:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-Off Task option. The One-Off Task form is displayed.  In the Schedule Type field, select the External Definition XML Schema Read schedule type from the drop-down list.  In the Schema Files field, enter the name of the XML schema file.  The name of the XML schema file cannot have UNIX shell meta characters, and cannot be a directory.    In the ED Generation Mode field, select the generation mode from the drop-down list.  Click the Save button.   Complete and validate the generated external definitions (see the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing).  Need more information on external definitions?

pages.title: Validate an External Definition
pages.text: To validate an external definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition option.  The External Definition Search form is displayed.   Enter the search criteria and select the search method.  Click the Search button.  External definitions matching the search criteria are displayed in the lower section of the form.  Select the required external definition and click the Detail... button.  The Viewing External Definition form is displayed in View only mode.   On the Settings tab, click the Validate... button.  For information about validation checks that are performed, refer to the System Configuration Guide for Singleview Convergent Billing.  Need more information on external definitions?

pages.title: Generate an External Definition View
pages.text: To define an external definition that is eligible for view generation:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition option.  The External Definition Search form is displayed.   Click the New... Button.  The External Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.   Complete the View Name field.  In the View Generation drop-down list, select Pending.  Configure remaining fields as required.  Validate the configuration using the Validate... button on the Settings tab.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Run the dbsync server utility on the command line.  View generation can be initiated manually by a call to the biExternalDefnViewGenerate&() function.  Need more information on external definitions?

pages.title: Generate External Definition Interface
pages.text: To define an external definition and generate interfaces for it:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ External Definition @ External Definition option.  The External Definition Search form is displayed.   Click the New... Button.  The External Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.   Select the External? check box.  In the Interface Generation drop-down list, select Pending.  In the Content Model drop-down list, select a content model other than Simple Content.  Select relevant check boxes from the Access group to configure the interface functions to be generated.  Configure other fields as required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  Click the Validate... button on the Settings tab.  The validation process is initiated.  In the Status drop-down list, select Validated to ensure that validation continues.  Click the Generate Interface... button.  The interface generation process is initiated.  The Interface Generation field is updated with the results of the interface generation process. In the Interface Type drop-down list, select BatchOutbound.  Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button.  The Interface Template Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  If a tab has mandatory fields, another tab can be selected only after all mandatory fields have been selected.  If the Delayed Extract field of the Batch Extractor Static tab is set to:  No, the External Definition Static tab is displayed.  Yes, the Delayed External Definition Static tab is displayed.  Click the Save button to save the interface template.  Need more information on batch extraction?

pages.title: Configure a Batch Extraction Interface Definition (configurers and system operations)
pages.text: To configure a batch extraction interface definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Interface Definition option.  The Interface Definition Search form is displayed in View Only mode.  In the Interface Type drop-down list, select BatchOutbound.  Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button.  The Interface Definition Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Enter the interface definition name in the Name field.  In the Template Name drop-down list, select the name of the required interface.   The interface definition automatically inherits the configuration from the selected interface template.   Enter an appropriate description in the Description field.  In the File Process Manager tab, enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  In the Batch Extractor tab, enter or select the appropriate search criteria.      Data in the static tabs cannot be changed.  Click the Save button to save the interface definition.  Need more information on batch extraction?

pages.title: Run the Batch Extraction
pages.text: To run a batch extraction:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-off Tasks option.  The One-off Task form is displayed.  Select the Batch Extract schedule type from the drop-down list.  Select the required interface definition.  The interface definition selected must have been created using an interface template that was created using the BatchOutbound interface type.  Enter the file name, if required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The schedule is saved, and a one-off task is submitted.   Need more information on batch extraction?

pages.title: Run a Delayed Batch Extraction
pages.text: To run a delayed batch extraction:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-off Tasks option.  The One-off Task form is displayed.  Select the Delayed Batch Extract schedule type from the drop-down list.  Select the required interface definition.  The interface definition selected must have been created using an interface template that was created using the BatchOutbound interface type.  Enter the file name, if required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The schedule is saved, and a one-off task is submitted.   Need more information on batch extraction?

pages.title: How Do I - System Integration Tasks - Batch Loading
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the required task.

pages.title: Configure a Batch Load Interface Definition (configurers and system operations)
pages.text: To configure a batch load interface definition:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Interface Definition option.  The Interface Definition Search form is displayed in View Only mode.  In the Interface Type drop-down list, select BatchInbound.     Enter the name of the required interface template.    Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button.  The Interface Definition Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  The interface definition automatically inherits the configuration from the selected interface template.   In the Name field, enter the interface definition name.  In the Description field, enter an appropriate description.  In the File Process Manager tab, enter or select the appropriate criteria.  In the Batch Loader tab, enter or select the appropriate criteria.    Data in the static tabs cannot be changed.  Click the Save button to save the interface definition.  Need more information on batch loading?

pages.title: Configure a Batch Load Interface Template (configurers only)
pages.text: To configure the static data for a batch load:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Interface Template option.  The Interface Template Search form is displayed in View Only mode.  In the Interface Type field drop-down list, select BatchInbound.  Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button.  The Interface Template Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Enter or select the appropriate search criteria.  If a tab has mandatory fields, another tab can be selected only after all mandatory fields have been selected.  Click the Save button to save the interface template.  Need more information on batch loading?

pages.title: Run a Batch Load
pages.text: To run a batch load:  Select the Server Tasks @ One-off Tasks option.  The One-off Task form is displayed.  Select the Batch Load schedule type from the drop-down list.  Select the required interface definition.  The selected interface definition must have been created using an interface template that was created using the BatchInbound interface type.  Enter the file name, if required.  Click the Save button on the toolbar.  The schedule is saved, and a one-off task is submitted.   Need more information on batch loading?

pages.title: How Do I - System Integration Tasks - Singleview Workflow Engine
pages.text: Select the option most appropriate to the required task.

pages.title: Configure an Interface Template (configurers only)
pages.text: To configure an interface template for Singleview Workflow Engine configuration items:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Interface Template option.  The Interface Template Search form is displayed in View Only mode.  In the Interface Type drop-down list, select WorkflowEngine.  Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button.  The Interface Template Detail form is displayed in Insert mode.  Enter data in the mandatory general fields.  Click the Save button to save the interface template.  Need more information on the Singleview workflow engine?

pages.title: Configure an Interface Definition (configurers and system operations)
pages.text: To create an interface definition that configures the Singleview Workflow Engine configuration items:  Select the Maintenance @ Server @ Interface Definition option.  The Interface Definition Search form is displayed.   In the Interface Type drop-down list, select WorkflowEngine.  To create interface definitions based on this interface type, users must have security group access level for 'View decrypted data that has been encrypted using this security group'.   In the Interface Template drop-down list, select the appropriate interface template.    The interface definition inherits the configuration from the selected interface template.  Select the Create a new interface option.  Click the New... button. The Interface Definition form is displayed in Insert mode.  In the Process Details tab:  In the Enabled drop-down list, select True for the BMP to automatically start the Singleview Workflow Engine.  In the SV Username and SV Password fields, enter TREWFE and its password.    In the THP Instance drop-down list, select THP1 as the connection for the Singleview Workflow Engine to use to communicate with Singleview.     Click the Save button.    Need more information on the Singleview workflow engine?

pages.title: Abstract External Definition
pages.text: External definition that is not mapped to a Convergent Billing entity or a Process Engine class.  Context:  Singleview, Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Concrete External Definition, and External Definition.

pages.title: Abstract Model
pages.text: Defines Convergent Billing entities, their basic relationships, and characteristics.  Entity characteristics in the abstract model are defined in terms of the meta-model.  The abstract model excludes field detail (field detail can be customised by subordinate models), and focuses on the entities.  Context:  Singleview  See also Meta Model, and Unified Modelling Language (UML).

pages.title: Accelerator Keys
pages.text: Keyboard shortcuts used to select a menu option.  Key combinations are displayed beside the appropriate menu items.

pages.title: Accept
pages.text: To save or commit work in the current view or form.  The Process Engine Main Frame and Configuration Workbench contain Accept buttons.  Context:  Process Engine

pages.title: Access Level
pages.text: Security feature that determines what a user can do and what data they are permitted to access.  Security is based on form roles and security groups, which in combination, determine a user's privileges.  Each user is assigned a specific profile that defines the level of access for each role and security group.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Security Group, User, User Profile, and Form Role.

pages.title: Account
pages.text: Unique account to which financial transactions are posted.  Each customer has at least one account (known as the primary account) and optionally one or more secondary accounts.  Each account has a unique account number by which it is identified.  See also Account Type.

pages.title: Account Cache
pages.text: Used for caching database details associated with accounts.  Account cache fetches and updates are primarily performed by rating processes to total all of the unbilled charges for each account, and to provide a mechanism during rating to check these unbilled charges and see whether they exceed a predetermined limit.  Context:  Singleview  See also Event Rating (ERT) Process.

pages.title: Account Category
pages.text: Category (or subclass) of one of the available account classes a Convergent Billing account belongs to.  Although account categories are extensible, Convergent Billing does not validate account categories against account classes.  The following table lists default account categories supported in Convergent Billing.  Account Category  Account Class  Receivable  Asset  Payable  Liability  Deposit  Liability  Credit  Liability  Bank  Asset  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Account Class, Account Type, and General Ledger Account Category.

pages.title: Account Class
pages.text: Specifies whether a Convergent Billing account is an asset or liability account.  Account classes are not extensible.  Context:  Singleview  See also Account Category, Account Type, and General Ledger Account Class.

pages.title: Account Classification
pages.text: General accounting term used to categorise accounts into one of the following classifications:  Asset  Liability  Equity  Revenue  Expense.  Context:  Singleview  See also Asset, Equity, Liability, Revenue, and Expense.

pages.title: Account Type
pages.text: Specifies any defaults or entity validation for accounts specified with that type.  Account types are used in the definition of charge categories, payment types, adjustment types, and customer types to specify the type of account to which charges are applied.   Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management, Configuration Studio  See also Account and Charge Category.

pages.title: Accounting Calendar
pages.text: Entity in Convergent Billing to define the accounting timeline. Groups one or more accounting years.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also, Accounting Year.

pages.title: Accounting Period
pages.text: Specified period of time for which a set of financial statements is generated.  Within an accounting year, the length of the accounting period is arbitrary and fixed, based on the reporting requirements of the company (for example, day, week, month, quarter, or year).  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Accounting Year.

pages.title: Accounting Standards
pages.text: Accounting term.  Widely accepted set of rules, conventions, standards, and procedures that govern the preparation of financial statements (for example, Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP) and International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)).  The standards are not a specific set of laws; its principles are applied using laws in each country, and standards usually vary between countries.  Context:  Singleview

pages.title: Accounting Year
pages.text: Entity in Convergent Billing to define the accounting timeline, and it can be broken down into smaller accounting periods.  Accounting years and accounting periods in Convergent Billing must reflect the financial years and accounting periods of the service provider.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also Accounting Period.

pages.title: Accounts Payable (A/P)
pages.text: Accounting term.  Account that records amounts owed by a company to people or business entities that arise from business transactions; for example, money owed to trade creditors for goods and services.  Accounts payable are also referred to as trade creditors.  The accounts payable account is a liability account.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Accounts Receivable (A/R).

pages.title: Accounts Receivable (A/R)
pages.text: Accounting term.  Account that records amounts owed to a company by customers or business entities that arise from business transactions; for example, the sale of goods or services provided on credit.  The accounts receivable account is an asset account.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Accounts Payable (A/P).

pages.title: Accounts Receivable Sub-ledger
pages.text: Subsidiary ledger of the general ledger used to track the transaction-level detail of financial data for the Accounts Receivable account.  The financial data recorded in the Accounts Receivable Sub-ledger is aggregated into journal entries for posting to the general ledger.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Accounts Receivable (A/R).

pages.title: Accrual
pages.text: Adjustment to the general ledger that reflects the expenditure incurred or revenue earned for a potential liability or asset, which is not formally acknowledged; for example, advance recurring charges such as line rental where the revenue billed in advance is earned (accrued) only on a daily basis.  Context:  Convergent Billing

pages.title: Accrual Basis of Accounting
pages.text: Accounting term.  Accounting method, where:  Revenue is recognised when it is earned, regardless of when cash is received.  Cash can be received for revenue that is not earned in the same period.  Expenses are recognised when they are incurred, regardless of when cash is paid.  Cash can be paid for expenses not incurred in the same period.  The accrual basis of accounting provides a more accurate representation of earnings and expenses than the cash basis of accounting during an accounting period by using a matching process (that is, associating revenues with corresponding expenses).  Singleview supports the accrual basis of accounting.  Context:  Singleview  See also Basis of Accounting and Cash Basis of Accounting.

pages.title: Accrual GL Guidance Entity
pages.text: GL guidance entity used for amounts earned or incurred before they are billed, and then billed at a later time (for example, post-paid usage charges that are later invoiced).  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also GL Guidance Entity, Actual GL Guidance Entity, Deferral GL Guidance Entity, and Non-billable GL Guidance Entity.

pages.title: Action
pages.text: Activity assigned to a workgroup or user to handle a specific issue.  Actions are often preconfigured according to business processes.  Actions and action groups are usually attached to an issue.  Context:  Process Engine, Customer Management  See also Issue, Action Group, Case, and Contact.

pages.title: Action Group
pages.text: Collection of actions organised into a hierarchy.  Actions within an action group are performed in a specific order.  An action group can contain any number of action types.  Context:  Process Engine, Customer Management  See also Action and Action Type.

pages.title: Action Hierarchy
pages.text: Refer to Action Group.

pages.title: Action Type
pages.text: Defined in the Process Engine Configuration Workbench, and used as a template for actions created in Customer Management.  An action type determines default values.  Context:  Customer Management, Process Engine  See also Action and Action Group.

pages.title: Action View
pages.text: Display that uses actions as the primary object.  The List section of an action view displays details of the selected action, and the Tab section displays details of objects associated with the selected action.  Context:  Customer Management, Process Engine  See also Action and View.

pages.title: Active
pages.text: A Singleview instance state where the server is running and performing normal operations, including CSR connections and transactions.  Context:  Singleview, High Availability

pages.title: Active Period
pages.text: Proportion of the charge period during which the product, tariff, and tariff/product link was active.  Charges are only incurred for the active period.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Charge Period, Recurring Tariff, and Rental Generation Process (RGP).

pages.title: Actual GL Guidance Entity
pages.text: GL guidance entity used for amounts that have been billed and completely earned or incurred (for example, prepaid usage charges, rental charges in arrears, and taxes payable on use of a service).  Context:  Convergent Billing, Configuration Studio  See also GL Guidance Entity, Accrual GL Guidance Entity, Deferral GL Guidance Entity, and Non-billable GL Guidance Entity.

pages.title: Adapter
pages.text: Enables communication between an application and an external system or process.  An adapter provides a data translation from the external system format to the Singleview format, and vice versa.  An inbound adapter sends the transformed request to the TRE, and then the transformed response to the external system or process.  An outbound adapter sends the transformed request from the TRE to the external system or process, and then returns the transformed response to the TRE.  Context:  Singleview  See also Enterprise Application Integration (EAI).

pages.title: Address Format
pages.text: Specifies the layout and style of the address fields, and defines a list of attribute types applied to those fields.  Address formats are specified for customer types, person types, service types, and equipment types.  Two address styles (5 line and 6 line) are provided.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Attribute Type.

pages.title: Adjustment
pages.text: Transaction outside of the normal billing cycle transactions (namely, invoices and payments) that affects the outstanding balance of a customer's account.  An adjustment is recorded against a specific customer's account and optionally against one or more specified invoices.  Debit and credit notes are commonly referred to as adjustments in Convergent Billing.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Singleview  See also Adjustment Batch, Adjustment Type, Payment, Debit Note, and Credit Note.

pages.title: Adjustment Batch
pages.text: Set of individual adjustments of the same type processed at the same time.  Each adjustment within the batch can be viewed or modified until the batch is applied (processed).  An adjustment batch can be created incrementally (one or more adjustments at a time) over a period of time.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Adjustment.

pages.title: Adjustment Transaction
pages.text: Sales and Cash Receipts Journal financial transaction generated when an adjustment is applied.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Sales and Cash Receipts Journal, Normalised Event File Transactions, Invoice Transactions, and Payment Transactions.

pages.title: Adjustment Type
pages.text: Defines common parameters for adjustment records; for example, defaults or entity validation for adjustments or adjustment batches specified with that type.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Customer Management  See also Adjustment and Adjustment Batch.

pages.title: Adobe Acrobat Reader
pages.text: Used to view (and subsequently print) a generated report on a client workstation.   Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Schedule and Task.

pages.title: Advance Period
pages.text: Number of charge periods that must be paid in advance.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Charge Period and Recurring Tariff.

pages.title: Advance Reporting
pages.text: Recognises revenue when it is earned for billed in arrears amounts.  Context:  Singleview

pages.title: Advanced Search
pages.text: Search defined in the Interface Design Tool for a view.    Context:  Process Engine, Customer Management  See also Custom Search.

pages.title: Aged Debt
pages.text: Period of time a payment is overdue for accounts receivable customer accounts.  Aged debt is typically specified in ranges from 0 - 30 days, 31 - 60 days, 61 - 90 days, and greater than 90 days.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Accounts Receivable (A/R).

pages.title: Aggregation
pages.text: Process by which individual costed data records are accumulated using a predefined aggregation method.  Typically, billing records are aggregated by charge, customer, customer node, normalised event, or service so that currency and time totals are obtained.  Rating subtotals are aggregated by customer, customer node, or service.  Billing and rating subtotals can also be global (not attached to a specific entity).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Aggregation Function, Automatic Aggregation, Progressive Subtotal, and Subtotal.

pages.title: Aggregation Function
pages.text: Defines the method of aggregation performed to calculate a subtotal.  One of three aggregation methods is used:  Summation, where the value of the subtotal is calculated by summing the values of a term for each match to the record being aggregated.  Minimum, where the value of the subtotal is taken as the minimum calculated value of each eligible term.  Maximum, where the value of the subtotal is taken as the maximum calculated value of each eligible term.  Rating subtotals can be defined as read-write (master) or read-only (slave).  Slave subtotals (for example, weekly) use the aggregates of a master subtotal (for example, daily).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Aggregation, Automatic Aggregation, Progressive Subtotal, Subtotal, and Subtotal Term.

pages.title: Alias
pages.text: Refers to the following two concepts in Process Engine:  Deriving a unique value for a fact in a class, based on values in other facts.  Structured classes.  A structured alias fact identifies each combination of possible values in a structured class.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Structured Alias Fact and Derived Fact.

pages.title: Alpha Event
pages.text: Event supplied as input to the Event Normalisation (ENM) process for normalisation.  Alpha events are read by the ENM process from alpha event files or, for real-time rating, from a named pipe or a TCP/IP socket.  The term 'alpha event' does not imply a specific event format.  Reading events from a TCP/IP socket is deprecated and provided only for backward compatibility.  Alpha events are in the following formats:  Native event format 3.03, with each event consisting of data fields in a user-definable order and prefixed with a length field, each field being delimited by an ASCII 255 character.  Native event formats 4.00, 4.02, 5.00, and 5.01, similar to native format 3.03, but the ASCII 0 character (null character) is used as the delimiter.  Any format that is specified by the ASN.1 subset supported by the Data Interface Language (DIL).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Alpha Event File and Data Interface Language (DIL).

pages.title: Alpha Event File
pages.text: File containing alpha events.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Alpha Event.

pages.title: Apache Tomcat
pages.text: Open source web server and servlet container developed by the Apache Software Foundation.    Context: Process Engine web client  See also See also Application, Java.

pages.title: API
pages.text: See also Application Programming Interface (API).

pages.title: Application Complex Upgrade
pages.text: A planned event where:   Both instances are taken offline  A complex Singleview upgrade is performed  Both instances are restored, one in standby.  Context:  Singleview, High Availability

pages.title: Application Environment
pages.text: Environment in which a variable or function is used.  Must be one of the following:  Any (for functions only)  Billing  Data Entry  EVS (for Entity Validation Server (EVS) functions)  GL Guidance  IGP Report  Invoicing  PE  Rating  TRE Table (unavailable for functions).  Functions with an application environment of Any can be called from Convergent Billing or Process Engine.  The PE application environment is specific to Process Engine functions and direct variables defined in Process Engine.  Functions with an application environment of PE are read-only and cannot be deleted.  All other application environments are specific to functions and variables defined in Convergent Billing.  Functions with an application environment of EVS are read-only and cannot be deleted.  They cannot be specified or updated in Convergent Billing or Process Engine.    Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Context and Variable.

pages.title: Application Failover
pages.text: An unplanned event where:  A loss of Singleview capability is detected  The active instance is taken offline  The standby instance is made active  The original active instance is repaired  The original active instance is moved to standby readiness.  Context:  Singleview, High Availability  See also Failover.

pages.title: Application Programming Interface (API)
pages.text: Interface defined at the source code level.  Developers writing applications programs can make requests to the operating system or another application.   Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine

pages.title: Application Switchover
pages.text: A planned event where:   A minor upgrade is performed on the standby instance  The active instance is taken offline  The standby instance is made active  The original active instance is upgraded  The original active instance is moved to standby readiness.  Context:  Singleview, High Availability  See also Switchover.

pages.title: Archive
pages.text: Contains a copy of data required to be kept for historical purposes or to comply with regulatory and statutory requirements.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Archiver.

pages.title: Archive Type
pages.text: When archiving, specifies the tables and dependencies that make up the entity being archived.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Archive.

pages.title: Archiver
pages.text: Tool that allows an administrator to load and unload selected configuration and dynamic data.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Archive.

pages.title: Arithmetic Operator
pages.text: Operator used in normal arithmetic, such as addition, division, multiplication, or subtraction.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine

pages.title: Asset
pages.text: Accounting term.  Type of account that records assets owned by a company, which contribute to the company's ability to earn revenue.  For example, cash at bank, handset inventory, buildings, office equipment, network switches, and vehicles are all assets.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Account Classifications, Equity, Liability, Revenue, and Expense.

pages.title: Association Class
pages.text: Class that stores information relating to more than one logical record.  Class associations are either simple or complex.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Class.

pages.title: Asynchronous Function
pages.text: Function executed as a background task.  Asynchronous functions do not require the user to wait for completion.  The user is notified if the function is called successfully.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Built-in Function, Function, Queued Function, and Synchronous Function.

pages.title: Attribute Type
pages.text: Controls the representation of an entity's attributes.   For users of Singleview Convergent Billing, an attribute type defines the format, characteristics, and validation rules for a form field.   Attribute types are the major components for entity validation.  Based on a reference type, they also define the representation of an entity's attributes externally, allowing the entity's data model to be tailored for integration with external systems.  They can also define additional non-stored attributes that are derived from an entity's stored attributes.   Attribute types are defined independently of the data entry fields to which they relate, which allows the same attribute type to be used for multiple fields.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Derived Attribute, Derived Non-Stored Attribute, and Reference Type.

pages.title: Audit
pages.text: Process for tracking additions, updates, or deletions from fields.  An audit identifies the user making the change, date-time of the change, and changed content.  Context: Singleview, Process Engine web client

pages.title: Audit Class
pages.text: Class that is selected to be audited.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audit Profile and Audited Fact.

pages.title: Audit Group
pages.text: Group configured with operations and facts applied to an audited class.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audited Class and Audited Fact.

pages.title: Audit Log
pages.text: Set of records of audited changes.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audit Log Record.

pages.title: Audit Log Record
pages.text: Object in the Audit Log class.  Context:  Process Engine

pages.title: Audit Profile
pages.text: Set of configured audit groups for determining what is recorded in audit log records.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audit Log Record, Audit Class, and Audit Group.

pages.title: Audited Class
pages.text: Object in the Auditing Tool Object List Box. It is displayed at a level below the Audit Profile object and created when the Audit Profile object is created.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audit Log Record.

pages.title: Audited Fact
pages.text: Fact configured for auditing in the Auditing Tool.  Context:  Process Engine  See also Audit Class.

pages.title: Authentication Server
pages.text: Tuxedo server (authsvr) responsible for authenticating requests to connect to Singleview.   The Authentication server also verifies the validity and usage level of a Singleview licence.  The server monitors the active workload, and issues warnings as the maximum permitted level for each entity (user, customer, customer node, or service) is approached.  Context:  Convergent Billing, Process Engine  See also Transaction Engine and Tuxedo Service.

pages.title: Automatic Aggregation
pages.text: Process in which all numeric direct variables for costed event records are automatically aggregated using the summation aggregation function.  The resulting aggregations are used in expressions associated with tariffs, subtotals, and derived attributes, but are not stored unless defined in subtotals.  Rating subtotals have the option of being manually aggregated.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Aggregation, Aggregation Function, Progressive Subtotal, and Subtotal.

pages.title: Backend Monitor Process (BMP)
pages.text: Server process responsible for controlling and monitoring the Event Rating Broker (BKR) process, the server processes that control scheduling, namely, Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) process, and Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) process.  The BMP monitors the status of each process and restarts any that have failed.  The BMP also listens on a TCP/IP socket for connections, and subsequent commands, from the Expression Control Program (ECP).  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Expression Control Program (ECP), Event Rating Broker (BKR) Process, Expression, Scheduled Task Dispatcher (STD) Process, Task Launch and Monitor (TLM) Process, and TRE API.

pages.title: Backup
pages.text: An instance state used in multi-instance clusters. This state may differ in detail from the standby state, hence the separate terms.  Context:  Singleview, High Availability  See also Standby.

pages.title: Balance Forward
pages.text: Accounting term.  Accounting method used to track outstanding balances, issue invoices and statements, and apply adjustments on customer accounts in the general ledger by maintaining a single on-going balance of a customer's account.  The balance is modified by the posting of transactions to the account.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Open Item Accounting.

pages.title: Balance Management
pages.text: Process in which customer credit balances are maintained in real time, using a reservations system, for account balance management and event authorisation.  Context:  Convergent Billing  See also Commerce Engine and Reservation.

pages.title: Base64
